Today, I would like to emphasize the crucial role of literacy in unlocking opportunities, empowering individuals, and driving our nation forward. The Department of Education stands at the forefront, paving the way for literacy development in our country through various programs and initiatives. Our goal is to promote functional literacy and ensure that every Filipino possesses the skills and knowledge needed to thrive in today's complex world. Functional literacy goes beyond simply reading and writing. It encompasses the skills necessary to apply this knowledge in real-life situations. It equips individuals with the ability to make informed decisions, communicate effectively, and actively participate in the workforce and society. To enhance functional literacy across all levels of education, the Department of Education has taken significant steps. Let me highlight some of the key initiatives undertaken by DepEd: First, the implementation of the K to 12 Program. This is one of the most notable reforms in our educational system. It provides a holistic and well-rounded education and emphasizes functional literacy through the incorporation of practical life skills, work education, and entrepreneurship in the curriculum. The recent revision of the K to 10 curriculum under the MATATAG Curriculum ensures the development of critical thinking, problem-solving skills, good manners, right conduct, peace education, and other essential skills. This revision acknowledges the evolving demands of the 21st century, where learners must analyze complex issues and adapt to rapidly changing environments. Second, we have the Alternative Learning Systems (ALS) program, which offers education to out-of-school youth and adults. ALS has significantly expanded access to education for those who may have missed formal schooling, providing not only basic literacy skills but also life skills. This program empowers marginalized individuals, promotes social inclusion, and offers them a chance to earn a formal diploma, leading to improved job prospects and increased self-esteem. Third, to ensure that school leaders and teachers are well-equipped to teach functional literacy, the Department of Education invests in teacher training and development programs. We contribute to the professional development of teachers through training programs, workshops, and seminars that enhance their teaching methods and keep them updated with the latest educational trends and approaches. Furthermore, DepEd actively collaborates with various organizations and stakeholders, including non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and the private sector, to promote functional literacy. These partnerships aid in the development of educational materials, access to resources, and the implementation of innovative teaching methods. Through the Literacy Coordinating Council (LCC), the Department of Education strengthens its commitment to work with legislators and local government units (LGUs) to strengthen relevant policies and literacy support structures at the grassroots level. To date, more than 300 Local LCCs have been established by LGUs, ensuring community literacy mapping out in identifying out-of-school children, youth, and adults, and provide relevant literacy program interventions. Recognizing the outstanding efforts of partners and stakeholders in community-based literacy development, the LCC has awarded more than 300 LGUs and NGOs through its National Literacy Awards (NLA) program. Let me highlight an inspiring success story from the NLA winners: the Municipality of Kauswagan in Lanao Del Norte. The LCC recognized their outstanding literacy intervention called the "From Battle Ground to School Ground.‚Äù This program has seen a scaled-up response in skills and literacy in conflict-affected areas, transforming communities into productive zones with sustained peace. It has successfully engaged both Muslim and Christian individuals, young and old, and improved the lives of many. This story exemplifies the contributions of LGUs in improving literacy rates and making a difference in the lives of Filipinos. Moreover, the LCC has developed literacy-related policies, frameworks, standards, and tools based on extensive research and empirical evidence. With the support of the Philippine Normal University, research and development work of the LCC has flourished. The outputs include the National Literacy Framework, standards and monitoring and evaluation tools for exemplary community-based literacy programs, benchmarks for adult literacy competencies, and the National Literacy Information System (NLIS). 15 lessons from Emotional Intelligence: Why It Can Matter More Than IQ by Daniel Goleman: 1. Emotional intelligence (EI) is the ability to understand and manage your own emotions, as well as the emotions of others. 2. EI is just as important for success in life as IQ, and perhaps even more so. 3. EI consists of five key skills: self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. 4. Self-awareness is the ability to recognize and understand your own emotions. 5. Self-regulation is the ability to manage your emotions and impulses. 6. Motivation is the ability to set and achieve goals. 7. Empathy is the ability to understand and share the feelings of others. 8. Social skills are the ability to build and maintain relationships. 9. EI can be learned and improved over time. 10. EI can help you succeed in all areas of your life, including your personal relationships, your career, and your health. 11. EI can help you make better decisions. When you are aware of your own emotions and the emotions of others, you are better able to weigh all of the factors involved in a decision. 12. EI can help you resolve conflict more effectively. When you can understand and empathize with the other person's perspective, you are more likely to find a solution that works for everyone. 13. EI can help you build stronger relationships. When you are able to communicate your own emotions clearly and understand the emotions of others, you are more likely to build trust and intimacy. 14. EI can help you manage stress and anxiety. When you are able to identify and manage your own emotions, you are better able to cope with stressful situations. 15. EI can lead to better physical health. Studies have shown that people with high EI are less likely to suffer from heart disease, stroke, and other chronic health conditions. How to improve your emotional intelligence: ‚Ä¢ Pay attention to your emotions. Notice how you feel throughout the day and try to identify the triggers that cause your emotions to change. ‚Ä¢ Label your emotions. Once you can identify your emotions, put a name to them. This will help you to better understand what you are feeling and why. ‚Ä¢ Manage your emotions. Once you understand your emotions, you can develop strategies for managing them in a healthy way. For example, if you are feeling angry, you might try taking a few deep breaths or going for a walk. ‚Ä¢ Empathize with others. Try to put yourself in the shoes of others and see things from their perspective. This will help you to better understand their feelings and motivations. ‚Ä¢ Develop your social skills. Practice communicating effectively, building relationships, and resolving conflict. There are many resources available to help you improve your emotional intelligence. You can find books, articles, and even online courses on the topic. You can also work with a therapist or coach to develop your EI skills. "Dr. Faustus" is a famous play by Christopher Marlowe. It's a classic of English literature, and a detailed critical analysis would involve examining various aspects of the play, such as its themes, characters, and literary techniques. 1. **Themes**: - The Struggle for Knowledge: The central theme is Faustus' insatiable desire for knowledge and the consequences of his pursuit. It's a cautionary tale about the limits of human ambition. - The Conflict between Good and Evil: The play explores the eternal struggle between good and evil through the characters of Faustus, Mephistopheles, and the Good and Evil Angels. - The Tragic Hero: Faustus can be seen as a tragic hero, driven by a fatal flaw (his ambition) and doomed to a tragic fate. 2. **Characters**: - Dr. Faustus: Analyze his character development, his internal conflicts, and the choices he makes. - Mephistopheles: Examine his role as both a servant and tempter. - The Good and Evil Angels: They represent the moral conflict faced by Faustus. 3. **Literary Techniques**: - Soliloquies and Monologues: Marlowe uses these to delve into Faustus' thoughts and emotions. - Allegory: The play is rich in allegorical elements, like the characters of the Seven Deadly Sins. - Use of Blank Verse: Marlowe's use of blank verse, unrhymed lines of iambic pentameter, is noteworthy. 4. **Historical and Social Context**: - Consider the play's historical context, including the Elizabethan era's views on magic and knowledge. 5. **The Tragic Element**: - Discuss how "Dr. Faustus" adheres to the classical elements of a tragic play, such as the downfall of the protagonist and the cathartic effect on the audience. 6. **Religious and Morality Aspects**: - Analyze the religious undertones in the play and how it reflects the moral values of the time. 7. **Influences and Impact**: - Explore how Marlowe's work might have influenced later literature, especially the portrayal of Faustian bargains in literature. A detailed critical analysis would involve a deep dive into these aspects, providing textual evidence to support your analysis and considering different interpretations of the play. It's a work that has been studied and analyzed extensively, so there are many different critical perspectives to explore.

A PRAYER FOR PROTECTION O God, author and giver of peace, in whose image and likeness each of us has been created with a human dignity worthy of respect on earth and destined for eternal glory, Listen to the cry that rises from every corner of this fragile earth, from our human family torn by violent conflict: Give peace in our time, O good and gracious God, that peace which, as your son Jesus Christ told us and as we have experienced in these days, is a peace which the world cannot give. To world leaders grant the wisdom to see beyond the boundaries of race, religion, and nation to that common humanity that makes us all your children and brothers and sisters to one another. To those who have taken up arms in anger or revenge or even in the cause of justice grant the grace of conversion to the path of peaceful dialogue and constructive collaboration. To the innocent who live in the shadow of war and terror, especially the frightened children, be a shelter and strength, their haven and hope. And to those who have already lost their lives as victims of human cruelty and chemical warfare, open wide your arms and enfold them all in the embrace of your compassion, healing, and everlasting life. Grant this through Jesus Christ, your son, our Lord. Mary, Mother of all and Queen of peace, pray for us.

I've decided to take a step back tonight from Fish on Friday as after all the horrors on the news this last week I think a pause for thought is in order especially with emotions running high and the danger of misinterpretation. I'm shocked as I think we all are at the barbarity and extremism that is attempting to polarise judgement and I don't want to be drawn into it accidentally or otherwise. The total lack of humanity that I've observed and heard is sickening and has deeply disturbed me these last few days. It's a time to contemplate and for rational and careful thought in the middle of all this madness so I am holding my own counsel on it all and declining to be drawn in to comment. I think you will understand. I've been texting Elliot 'Ness' Singerman these last few days and most of you will know him as the house engineer here at the Studio and producer of 'Raingods with Zippos', 'Fellini Days' and 'Field of Crows'. He went to Israel after that last album to live and work in the live music industry in Tel Aviv. Elliot has lost a number of good friends and co workers these last days and as you'd expect is both angry and extremely saddened by the turn of events. We are both depressed at the total lack of humanity on exhibition and where the world we live on is headed . He said that for the last year he has seen this coming as the politics drove ever further to the right and religious extremism became more lunatic. The one song he couldn't get out of his head was 'The Perception of Johnny Punter'. Maybe listen to that tonight on your own and take it in . Born in Bosnia in the ever glowing embers of division and the endless circles of generations baptised in hatred, the opening words there to paint out the tribes and the cultural racism that is always hidden beneath the surface that can ignite conflict and wars on a breath of utterance. Living on the planet - we are - in another world I'll leave it at that I'll be back next week and will have news of the 2024 tour which is about to be officially announced and of the '13th Star' and Feast of Consequences' triple vinyl box sets that will be going up on preorder on the 30th October. Now does not feel like the time to go into details. Until then. take care and stay alive Fish

Your life needs only to make sense to you. It's a personal journey, not a community project. If you were accustomed to getting your parents' approval for everything you did and they never taught you freedom and self-determination, you'll find yourself waiting for approval from authority figures in your life. When you imagine going ahead without a nod from whoever you're submitting yourself to at that time, you will feel intense stress and anxiety. This is learned dependency and fear of facing life by yourself. Since people have a conflict of interest, they will mislead and confuse you to keep you under their control. The more you mature, the more you become comfortable with living a life people don't understand. And the more become centred and in control of your life, the less permission and approval you need from other people. One thing you should do when you turn thirty is to retire all authority figures in your life and become the authority figure yourself. You're socially and psychologically mature now, and you must not have external supervision or undue influence in your life. You will continue to learn and borrow wisdom from many sources, of course, but you will be making decisions yourself. You will appreciate those who contributed to your growth in the past, but you will take full control of your life moving forward. Some will hate your declaration of independence and evict you from their communities. You should take this merely as a confirmation that their role in your life is over because they can not accommodate a grown and self-reliant you. They needed you to stay weak and controllable. You don't need them anymore. (¬©Ô∏è Benjamin Zulu Global)

¬©Ô∏è When I and my fiancee were dating, we had gone a whole year without quarreling Yes! One whole year, without arguing... Just when I was thinking of proposing to her, a thought crossed my mind "We have never quarrelled before, are you sure we can cope with the conflict that comes with marriage?" I asked myself... Funny enough, I tried sparking up arguments whenever she visited, complained bitterly about anything she did but it didn't work She would either tell me "I'm sorry my love, you know I didn't mean to offend you" and smile that her irresistible smile and before I realise, I would be smiling myself... Or she would look at me with her baby face until I apologize. She never shouted back or spoke rudely...until one day, I made the mistake of asking her why she never picked a quarrel "You never shout or speak back at me, you're always too cool...I don't know if you will even be able to handle conflict in marriage sef..." I complained She looked at me, shocked and surprised at the same time... "So you want us to be quarreling?" She asked "No, but...you know, arguments bring better understanding in relationships" I explained bluntly "You think I don't understand you enough?" She asked, still calm By then I realised I was just being stupid...I kept mute "No problem, you've asked for it" she said Gbam. I started apologizing immediately but she gave deaf ears...a part of still wanted the drama to happen so I left her alone after pleading for some time I left for my room and waited for her to come and meet me but she stayed in the living room for almost an hour... Then she finally came to the room with a very strong face... "Come and eat" ...TBC... ¬©Ô∏è African Man

Machik Labdr√∂n üôè ‚ÄúPeople these days use whatever little dharma they know to augment afflictive emotion, and then engender tremendous pride and conceit over it. They teach the Dharma without taming their own minds. But as with a river rock , not even a hair‚Äôs tip of benefit penetrates the other people. Even worse, incorrigible people [are attracted] to this dharma that increases conflict. When individuals who could be tamed by the Dharma encounter such incorrigible, their desire for the sacred Dharma is lost. It is not the fault of the Dharma; it is the fault of individuals... **** Training Homage to the host of lamas, yidams, and dakinƒ±s. Bowing at the feet of the mother, the nonmortal, the dakinƒ±, I have arranged this complete explanation of casting out the body as food according to Machik‚Äôs own teachings. First, a brief explanation of Machik‚Äôs history. Previous Life in India Machik is the dakinƒ± of timeless wisdom, the birth mother of all past, present, and future buddhas. She is the vajra dakini of the mind family. With the intention to help sentient beings, she took birth [in her previous life] as the son of King Srƒ±sura Arya in Kapila in India. The young prince was called M√∂nlam Drup. He learned to read and write all the sets of letters and all other sciences with barely any studying, just by hearing or seeing them. From the age of five he could understand everything without hindrance. Everybody said that he must be an emanation of the Buddha. At the age of ten, he took monastic ordination with Pandita Pƒ±tibhadra and received the name D√∂ndrup Zangpo. He stayed with this master for three years, during which time he became more learned in grammar, logic, paramita, vinaya, and abhidharma collections than even the master himself. The master realized that he was an exceptionally talented person and so taught him the Four Tantras, in which he became particularly adept. In the presence of his master he assiduously studied the collections of scriptures (pitakas), and even made many clarifications in the Four Tantras. Most important, he offered the realizations that had arisen in his own mind. The master was utterly pleased and said, ‚ÄúD√∂ndrup Zangpo, I am not capable of being your master any longer. Now you should go north to Zangling (Tamradvipa). Guru Ratna lives there. He is a great adept of Cakrasamvara and is actually able to manifest the emanated mandala. He is learned in all the scriptures and is adorned with all good qualities. Go to him and work through all your doubts. Practice the Highest Secret Mantra and become an adept. You will help many sentient beings.‚Äù The next day D√∂ndrup Zangpo arrived before Guru Ratna. Guru Ratna could see that he was a worthy recipient and emanated the mandala of the sixty-four deities of Cakrasa¬™vara in the sky in front of him. The four empowerments were bestowed in their entirety, and D√∂ndrup Zangpo attained supreme spiritual powers (siddhi). He could travel through the pure realms of the buddhas without obstruction. He stayed with this master for three years and resolved his misconceptions concerning all the teachings of sutra and tantra. In particular, he became learned and adept in the stages of creation and completion in Highest [Secret Mantra]. Then the master told him, ‚ÄúYou should go north to the Vajra Seat at Bodhgaya and convert the heretics. There is no one able to debate as well as you.‚Äù So when he was sixteen years old, D√∂ndrup Zangpo went to Bodhgaya and debated with the heretics. They were defeated, and one hundred thousand of them entered the Buddhist order. D√∂ndrup Zangpo stayed in Bodhgaya for four years. Then Exalted Tara told him that he must go to Tibet to help the beings there. ‚ÄúHurry up and get accomplished!‚Äù she said. He decided that he should visit some sacred places and set out to the north. He came to a cemetery, and as soon as he lay down to rest, a dakinƒ± of that charnel ground appeared. She was wearing bone ornaments and carrying a hooked knife and a trident. She said, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you have anywhere to rest besides my cemetery?‚Äù and then conjured up all kinds of apparitions. But he overcame them with his meditative absorption (samadhi), and the dakinƒ± offered her life-essence and pledged herself to the Dharma. At dawn, he beheld the faces of the fifteen goddesses of Nairatmya, who said to him, ‚ÄúYogin, go to Potari and quickly become accomplished and then go on to Tibet.‚Äù Then they vanished like a rainbow. He thought to himself, ‚ÄúBeing young, I should achieve success in practice, but I wonder what practice will bring success? And taming the wild, unruly Tibetans will be difficult. I don‚Äôt have [any idea] what it takes.‚Äù Immediately the five deities of Great Magical Illusion, Mahamaya, appeared in the dim light of dawn and said, ‚ÄúYogin, go to the Bhadra cave at Potari and accomplish the heart practice of the Five Goddesses of the Black One. Thousands of Muslims across the Middle East, notably from Jordan and Yemen, took to the streets in a show of solidarity for Palestinians on the first Friday following Hamas' attack on Israel and the increased attacks on Gaza. As tensions rise with Israel contemplating a ground invasion of Gaza, there's a fear that this could lead to even more casualties and violence. In Europe, imams in countries like France and Greece used their Friday sermons to voice concerns over the increasing violence and civilian suffering, advocating for peace. Worldwide, Muslim communities, ranging from Hezbollah sympathizers in Beirut to protesters in Baghdad, displayed varied responses. Some staunchly support the Palestinians, while others mourn the tragic loss of life, hoping for a peaceful resolution. #CGTNAmerica

Dear Friends of the International Plum Village Community, Our hearts are breaking as we witness the horrific violence that is being unleashed in many parts of the world and most recently in the Middle East: in Israel and in Gaza. We know that both Palestinians and Israelis are our siblings‚Äîour brothers, sisters, children, our family‚Äîwho are being killed, and who are driven to kill. In an atmosphere of violence, accusation and retaliation, we have a tendency to dehumanize the other. Once anger, fear, and suspicion take over, it seems like there is nothing to do besides kill or be killed. Today we shed tears as we witness our Israeli and Palestinian siblings dying, sustaining severe injuries‚Äîboth psychological and physical‚Äîand losing loved ones in the hate-fueled attacks of the very few. Violence can only lead to more violence and diminish any possibility of dialogue and reconciliation‚Äîunless we go deeply within ourselves to see that human beings are not our enemy. We need a coalition of wise and courageous people‚Äîin Gaza, West Bank, Israel and in the international community‚Äîwho refuse to give in to this hate: a non-violent army. It is time for violence in all its many forms to end in the Holy Land. With compassion, love, and wisdom in our hearts we can make ourselves available to listen deeply to the cries of those now in Gaza and Israel and elsewhere in the world‚Äîthe cries of those undergoing the deep mental crisis of being trapped in a conflict zone, who are looking to keep their love strong in the midst of this horror. We need to lend them our strength. We all need to go beyond the delusive and destructive idea that we are separate from each other. Let us create islands of non-violence and peace in our hearts, in our homes and beyond, via email, phone and video. Let us live every moment seeing those we think of as the enemy as not separate from ourselves‚Äîas our own blood, skin and bones‚Äîand let us not allow hatred to take over. Let us come back and take care of our feelings with calm and clarity, holding our sadness, fear, anger, and despair and resist the temptation to blame, punish, and have to choose a side. This meditation may be challenging at this moment but it is what we as a collective need now in order to awaken from the madness and destruction. Revenge and punishment cannot be the answer. Join us to generate this imperturbable compassion in your own heart, and radiate it out in every direction to our siblings experiencing great loss, fear and pain in this moment. The war is complex and difficult to stop, but it is also impermanent. Its cessation now depends on our capacity, as human beings, to listen deeply, resist polarization and discrimination, and take concrete steps towards lasting reconciliation with love in our hearts. Love, compassion, and courage need to have a place in politics. With love for all beings suffering in the hell of war, The Plum Village International Monastic Community

They were attacked while providing humanitarian assistance. In response to the urgent situation in Israel and the Gaza Strip, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) urged all parties involved in the conflict to comply with their legal obligations under International Humanitarian Law (IHL). It emphasizes providing immediate protection to civilians and taking all possible measures to prevent further harm to healthcare workers, medical facilities, civilians‚Äô infrastructure and objects. The ICRC has been present in Israel and the Occupied Territories since 1967, and taken immediate actions to provide emergency and critical humanitarian aid, including transfer medical supplies to a hospital in Gaza, operate ambulance services and collect over 13,000 units of blood, etc.

He met with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas and reiterated that Hamas does not stand for the Palestinian people‚Äôs legitimate right to dignity, freedom, justice, and self-determination. üìçIn Doha, he met with Qatari Amir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani on to discuss the terrorist attacks and ongoing conflict with Hamas, and recognized Qatar‚Äôs diplomatic efforts to efforts to secure the return of hostages. The symbolism of Ravana‚Äôs 10 heads Every year, Sanatanis (Hindus) around the world celebrate Deepawali, a festival that commemorates Prince Sri Rama‚Äôs return to his home, Ayodhya, after defeating the powerful King Ravana. Presented as the victory of good over evil, knowledge over ignorance, and spiritual light over darkness, narrations of their conflict often convey Ravana as a one-dimensional figure, whose heinous acts, including the kidnapping of Devi Sita, slate him as irredeemably demonic. No matter how terrible a person appears, however, Sanatan Dharma teaches that nobody is ever completely evil. Ultimately, everyone originates from the Divine, and so everyone is actually pure in nature. Often caught up in the dualities of life ‚Äî like hot/cold, ugly/beautiful, and old/young ‚Äî many have a tendency to forget this nature, as they do all they can to attain what they want and avoid what they don‚Äôt want, despite how their actions might affect those around them. Hence, like all, Ravana was a complex being, who exhibited not only negative qualities, but positive ones throughout his life‚Äôs journey. An expert warrior, politician, king, as well as astrologer and doctor of ayurveda, he took great care of his kingdom, for even the poorest of its inhabitants were well off, and never poverty stricken. Also an exceptional poet and scholar, each of the 10 heads he is often depicted with are said to symbolize the six shastras and four vedas, as he was a famed devotee of Shiva, the God of Transformation. But, like many before him, and many after, he was led astray in his desire for pleasure, succumbing to a medley of life‚Äôs vices in his pursuit of so-called happiness. Thus, as his hunger for power expanded, his 10 heads of knowledge became better known as symbols of the 10 qualities that exude those who are attached to such power. They are: Kama (lust) Krodha (anger) Moha (delusion) Lobha (greed) Mada (pride) Maatsarya (envy) Buddhi (intellect) Manas (mind) Chitta (will) Ahamkara (ego) According to the Bhagavad Gita, success in spiritual life depends on a steady intelligence, which can only exist through control of the senses. When we focus too much on an object of the senses, attachment develops. Prolonged attachment turns into intense longing, or lust, and when the object of our lust is not obtained, anger arises. Becoming blinded by anger, we fall into delusion, causing bewilderment and a loss of intelligence, as we lose sight of our true spiritual identity. In the case of Ravana, Devi Sita was the object of his senses. Controlled by lust, he took her by force and grew angry when she refused to be with him. Blinded by his anger, he lost all intelligence, believing he could defeat her husband Sri Rama, an avatar of Sri Vishnu, who inevitably killed him. Good and evil, like everything in the material world, are relative, and have no real meaning in connection to divine figures like Rama and Sita. Therefore, a true characterization of Ravana is not that he was a demon, but that he was a person who failed to control his senses, going down a path that led to forgetfulness of his real spiritual identity. As such, to avoid going down a similar path, we must all strive to act selflessly by controlling our senses, practicing discipline in pursuit of spiritual advancement, rather than our own selfish desires. By such discipline, we can transcend mundane notions of good and evil, and see every person for what they truly are ‚Äî magnificent and beautiful expressions of the Divine. Jeremy Corbyn writing for the Tribune today: ‚ÄúI utterly condemn the attacks on civilians, Israeli and Palestinian. And I plead with politicians across the globe to do all they can to stop any further loss of human life. Our political leaders surely must understand that, without a serious political intervention, one tragedy will follow another, and a cycle of despair will go on and on. In the immediate aftermath of horror, we need voices for peace and de-escalation. Instead, inconceivably, both major political parties continue to give the green light to an unfolding humanitarian catastrophe. Both the Foreign Secretary and Shadow Foreign Secretary have reiterated their support for Israel‚Äôs ‚Äúright to defend itself‚Äù, yet consistently fail to offer sufficient specificity about what this means, let alone how it should be exercised within the boundaries of international law. In an interview with LBC, Keir Starmer was asked whether ‚Äúcutting off power and water‚Äù to 2 million people, half of whom are children, was appropriate. He agreed that Israel ‚Äúhas that right‚Äù. Where is the empathy for Palestinians who have lost their loved ones, their homes and their futures? What happened to the universal application of international law? We may be witnessing the beginning of the total annihilation of Gaza and its people. This is not a battle between one state and another. It is couched as an Israeli response to a non-state actor, but in fact it is a response to Palestinian people wherever they are. What is unfolding is not a conflict of equals, but the systematic starvation, subjugation and destruction of an unarmed civilian population. I wonder, if Gaza is wiped off the face of the earth, whether our politicians will look back and reflect on the reality of their unwavering support. If they had any integrity, they would mourn the innocent Palestinian lives that have been erased in the name of self-defence. They should be ashamed of their cowardice, knowing that others will pay the price for the war crimes they refuse to oppose.‚Äù

We, members of the undersigned human rightsand civil society organizations in Israel, are shocked and horrified in these dreadful days. Hamas‚Äô horrific crimes against innocent civilians - including children, women, and the elderly - have shaken us all, and we are struggling to recover from the unbearable sights and sounds. Some of us were in the Israeli communities on the Gaza border during the assault; many of us have family, friends, and colleagues who endured and are still in the midst of the harrowing events; and we all know people who were murdered, injured, or abducted. It will take time to fully understand the implications and consequences of Hamas‚Äô heinous attack, for which there can be no justification. Most of our teams include Israelis and Palestinians; therefore, some of us have relatives and colleagues in Gaza currently living under the ongoing assault of the Israeli military. Children, women, and the elderly are being indiscriminately attacked with nowhere to hide. Even now ‚Äì especially now ‚Äì we must maintain our moral and humane position and refuse to give in to despair or the urge for vengeance. Keeping our faith in the human spirit and its inherent goodness is more vital than ever. One thing is clear: We will never surrender our belief in humanity - even now, when doing so is more challenging than ever. Having always opposed the harming of innocent civilians, it remains our duty in these terrible times - as we count our dead on the Israeli side and worry about wounded, missing, and abducted loved ones, and as bombs are being dropped on residential neighborhoods in Gaza, wiping out entire families with no possibility of burying the dead ‚Äì to raise our voices loud and clear against the harming of all innocent civilians, both in Israel and Gaza. We call for the immediate release of all hostages and an end to the bombardment of civilians in Israel and in Gaza. Humanitarian aid must be allowed to reach civilian populations, medical facilities and places of refuge must not be harmed, and vital resources such as water and electricity must not be cut off. The killing of additional civilians will not bring back those who were lost. Indiscriminate destruction and a siege harming innocents will not bring relief, justice, or calm. As individuals working to promote human rights and who believe in the sanctity of life, we urgently call for an end to all indiscriminate harming of civilian lives and infrastructure. We call for negotiations and all possible action to be taken to bring about the release of the hostages - while prioritizing the civilians held by Hamas. It is the only humane and rational thing to do, and it must be done now. FOR THOSE COMPARING BIAFRA TO GAZA OR PALESTINE, READ THIS ACCOUNT By @giniedze (c)nefertari @DGiantOfAfrica If Israel just allowed the Palestinians to have a state of their own, there would be peace in the Middle East, right? That's what you hear from you and ambassadors, European diplomats, and most college professors. But what if I told you that Israel has already offered the Palestinians a state of their own, and not just once, but on five separate occasions? Don't believe me? Let's review the record. After the breakup of the Ottoman Empire, following World War I, Britain took control of most of the Middle East, including the area that constitutes modern Israel. 17 years later, in 1936, the Arabs rebelled against the British and against the Jewish neighbors The British formed a task force, the Peal Commission, to study the cause of the rebellion. The Commission concluded that the reason for the violence was that two peoples, Jews and Arabs, wanted to govern the same land. The answer, the Peal Commission concluded, would be to create two independent states, one for the Jews and one for the Arabs, a two-state solution. Rejection number one. The suggested split was heavily in favor of the Arabs. The British offered them 80% of the disputed territory, the Jews the remaining 20%. Yet, despite the tiny size of their proposed state, the Jews voted to accept this offer. But the Arabs rejected it and resumed their violent rebellion. Rejection number two. Ten years later, in 1947, the British asked the United Nations to find a new solution to the continuing tensions. Like the Peal Commission, the UN decided that the best way to resolve the conflict was to divide the land. In November 1947, the UN voted to create two states. Again, the Jews accepted the offer and again, the Arabs rejected it. Only this time, they did so by launching an all-out war. Jordan, Egypt, Iraq, Lebanon and Syria joined the conflict. But they failed. Israel won the war and got on with the business of building a new nation. Most of the land set aside by the UN for an Arab state, the West Bank and East Jerusalem, became occupied territory. Occupied not by Israel, but by Jordan. Rejection number three. 20 years later, in 1967, the Arabs led this time by Egypt and joined by Syria and Jordan, once again sought to destroy the Jewish state. The 1967 conflict, known as the Six-Day War, ended in a stunning victory for Israel. Jerusalem and the West Bank, as well as the area known as the Gaza Strip, fell into Israel's hands. The government split over what to do with this new territory. Half wanted to return the West Bank to Jordan and Gaza to Egypt in exchange for peace. The other half wanted to give it to the region's Arabs, who had begun referring to themselves as the Palestinians, in the hope that they would ultimately build their own state there. Neither initiative got very far. A few months later, the Arab League met in Sudan and issued its infamous three-NOs, no peace with Israel, no recognition of Israel, no negotiations with Israel. Again, a two-state solution was dismissed by the Arabs. Rejection number four. In 2000, Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak met at Camp David, with Palestinian Liberation Organization Chairman Nasser Arafat, to conclude a new two-state plan. Barak offered Arafat a Palestinian state in all of Gaza, and 94% of the West Bank, with East Jerusalem as its capital. But the Palestinian leader rejected the offer. In the words of U.S. President Bill Clinton, "Arafat was here 14 days and said no to everything." Instead, the Palestinians launched a bloody wave of suicide bombings that killed over 1,000 Israelis and maimed thousands more, on buses, in wedding halls, and in pizza parlors. Rejection number five. In 2008, Israel tried yet again. Prime Minister Ehud Omar went even further than Ehud Barak had, expanding the peace offer to include additional land to sweeten the deal. Like his predecessor, the new Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, turned the deal down. In between these last two Israeli offers, Israel unilaterally left Gaza, giving the Palestinians complete control there. Instead of developing this territory for the good of its citizens, the Palestinians turned Gaza into a terrorist base, from which they have fired thousands of rockets into Israel. Each time Israel has agreed to a Palestinian state, the Palestinians have rejected the offer, often violently. So if you're interested in peace in the Middle East, maybe the answer is not to pressure Israel to make yet another offer of the state to the Palestinians. Maybe the answer is to pressure the Palestinians to finally accept the existence of a Jewish state. Credit: @giniedze That‚Äôs it. And when Israel fights back. They suddenly become victims ME: If the Zoo called Nigeria had ever agreed to sit with Biafrans on a round table to seek what we want or even adhered to the one agreed in 1967 by Gowon and Ojukwu, I doubt if there would have been any war or if (truncated)

Isra√´l wil in √©√©n dag meer Palestijnen uit hun huizen en land verdrijven dan het deed tijdens de hele Nakba van 1948. Meer dan 1,1 miljoen Palestijnen wonen ten noorden van de rode lijn bij Wadi Ghazzah. Isra√´l wil ze allemaal in 24 uur naar het zuiden ervan verplaatsen. Verdrijven van de mensen, zoals in 1948. De Verenigde Naties (VN) spreken van een verwoestende humanitaire impact en roepen Isra√´l op om het bevel in te trekken. Dit is geen strijd tussen de ene staat en de andere. Vandaag zijn we misschien getuige van het begin van de totale vernietiging van Gaza en zijn bevolking. Wat zich ontvouwt is geen conflict tussen gelijken, maar de systematische uithongering, onderwerping en vernietiging van een burgerbevolking. De Wereldgezondheidsorganisatie (WHO) waarschuwt dat het gezondheidssysteem in de Gazastrook op een breekpunt staat. De organisatie roept op tot de onmiddellijke instelling van een humanitaire corridor om ongehinderde toegang te garanderen voor medische en humanitaire voorraden, evenals voor personeel, en de evacuatie van pati√´nten en gewonden. De Isra√´lische bombardementen op Gaza hebben sinds zaterdag 1.000 huizen met de grond gelijk gemaakt en velen in het gebied kampen met een nijpend tekort aan water, brandstof en medische voorraden, aldus het humanitaire bureau van de VN. Tenminste 88 onderwijsinstellingen zijn getroffen. De VN meldde dat alle 13 ziekenhuizen in het gebied slechts gedeeltelijk operationeel zijn vanwege ernstige tekorten aan brandstof en cruciale medische benodigdheden. De vermindering van de watertoevoer heeft geleid tot een nijpend watertekort voor meer dan 650.000 mensen in het gebied van 2,3 miljoen mensen. Rioleringssystemen zijn vernietigd, waardoor smerig afvalwater op straat terechtkomt en een gevaar vormt voor de gezondheid. Mensenrechtenexperts van de Verenigde Naties zijn scherp: "Wij veroordelen ten zeerste de willekeurige militaire aanvallen van Isra√´l op de toch al uitgeputte Palestijnse bevolking van Gaza, bestaande uit meer dan 2,3 miljoen mensen, waarvan bijna de helft kinderen. Ze leven al 16 jaar onder een onwettige blokkade en hebben al vijf grote brute oorlogen achter de rug. Dit komt neer op collectieve bestraffing. Er is geen rechtvaardiging voor geweld dat zonder onderscheid gericht is tegen onschuldige burgers, of het nu wordt uitgevoerd door Hamas of door Isra√´lische troepen. Dit is absoluut verboden onder het internationaal recht en komt neer op een oorlogsmisdaad. Nu het aantal burgerslachtoffers door het geweld toeneemt, roepen we op tot een onmiddellijke de-escalatie van de spanningen in de regio en een effectieve reactie van de internationale gemeenschap op basis van het internationaal recht en de bescherming van gelijke rechten en de waardigheid van iedereen."* Iedereen die ook maar enige integriteit heeft moet nu zijn stem verheffen tegen de vernietiging van Gaza, en tegen de dubbele moraal waarmee het Westen de oorlogsmisdaden van Isra√´lische bezettingsmacht verdedigt. -- * https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2023/10/israeloccupied-palestinian-territory-un-experts-deplore-attacks-civilians

UMR Mobilizes Humanitarian Relief for Gaza Collaborates with global agencies and partners to deliver urgent aid The recent crisis in Gaza is rapidly deteriorating as the concern for access and delivery of emergency humanitarian aid steadily mounts due to restrictions and blockades. Notwithstanding the difficult logistic challenges, United Mission for Relief and Development (UMR) has intensified its commitment to delivering essential life-sustaining aid to the most affected population. UMR is actively providing on the ground life-saving support by leveraging its strategic partnerships and establishing alternative distribution methods. UMR acknowledges the complexities imposed by the current restrictions in Gaza and has established a robust strategy utilizing the influence and network of the Hashemite Charity Organization, an array of local community-based organizations (CBOs) as well as the United Nations. This collaborative approach ensures the successful procurement, distribution and delivery of critical supplies, circumventing traditional barriers that have hindered numerous relief efforts. ‚ÄúWe understand that the challenges in Gaza are multifaceted and require a dynamic, collaborative approach. Our partnerships are invaluable in navigating these complexities on the ground. Together, we‚Äôre not just delivering aid but saving lives and providing hope,‚Äù commented Dr. Abed Ayoub, CEO and President, UMR. Partnering with the Hashemite Charity Organization, UMR will hand over pharmaceutical supplies and equipment capable of serving over 100,000 medical cases in Gaza. This is valued at over $1,000,000. Additionally, UMR is procuring tents, clothing and other essential items which will be delivered to Gaza through UMR‚Äôs association with the Hashemite Charity Organization. These items are crucial in providing immediate shelter and comfort to the millions who would be displaced by the conflict or facing severe economic hardship. UMR is also engaging and negotiating with UNRWA on ways it can support and expand UNRWA‚Äôs operations and programs for those severely affected by the crisis. UMR is part of a coalition of Aid NGOs that includes Rahmah Worldwide, International Humanitarian Relief, Pious Project, Medglobal, and the Palestine Tomorrow Association. This coalition is focused on fortifying ER clinics in Gaza, an urgent need given the enormity of deaths and injuries. This coalition is also mandated to procure medicines, support operational capacities, and distribute food to injured individuals and their families amidst the crisis. While UMR will do all that it can to alleviate the suffering and reduce the pain, the need is enormous. UMR calls on the international community to recognize the gravity of the situation in Gaza and encourage other humanitarian organizations to contribute to the relief efforts through direct participation or support the initiatives currently being undertaken. Solidarity with Israel against Hamas‚Äô Terrorist Attacks The Stratbase ADR Institute stands with Israel as it faces inhumane terrorist attacks by Hamas. We strongly condemn these heinous acts of terrorism and impunity, which have claimed innocent lives, including women and children. These brutal actions perpetrated by a terrorist group destroy regional and global peace and stability. Any acts of terrorism and violence have no place in our rules-based international order. The Institute emphasizes that Hamas does not represent the entirety of Palestine. The infliction of suffering upon Israelis also inadvertently harms Palestinian civilians, subjecting them to the heartbreaking consequences of conflict. The escalation of violence and military action in the region has had a shattering effect on defenseless civilians caught in the crossfire. The images of devastation and loss are profound, and it is the responsibility of the international community to help prevent these innocent individuals from suffering further harm. These terrorist attacks and the loss of innocent lives cannot further escalate. We urge the Philippine government to continue harnessing all the needed resources to ensure the safety and well-being of Filipinos residing in Israel and provide utmost support to the Filipino families left behind by those whose lives have been lost. Echoing the statements of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, the Stratbase ADR Institute condemns the ongoing terror and violence being perpetuated by Hamas and mourns the loss of innocent lives on all sides. There is never an acceptable justification for terrorism. Our steadfast belief is that violence will not result in any enduring resolution and will only serve to reopen old grievances. We implore all parties involved to prioritize the safety and well-being of their civilian populations. In these dark times, we call upon friends, allies, and partners to unite as staunch defenders of the rules-based international order. We call for the urgent resolution of the conflict with due respect for the rule of law and human rights. The path to peace may be fraught with difficulties, but it is the only way to a brighter, more secure future for all.

13 OCTOBER 2023 ‚Äî Statement Of Philippine Red Cross Chairman And CEO Richard J. Gordon On The Killing Of Five Emergency Medical Responders In The Line Of Duty In The Israel-Hamas War As of October 12, a total of five dedicated professionals from the International Red Cross and Red Crescent (RCRC) Movement tragically lost their lives in the line of duty in the ongoing armed conflict in Israel: an ambulance driver from Magen David Adom in Israel and four paramedics from the Palestinian Red Crescent Society. The Philippine Red Cross extends its deepest condolences to the families and friends of our fellow humanitarian workers from the RCRC Movement. We express our sympathy to our colleagues at Magen David Adom and Palestinian Red Crescent Society. The principles of international humanitarian law (IHL) mandate the protection of civilians and civilian infrastructure during armed conflicts. Under IHL, pillage, reprisals, indiscriminate destruction of property, and the taking of hostages are prohibited. Health care must not be disrupted and put in danger even during times of emergencies, and all providers of healthcare, such as the Magen David Adom in Israel and Palestinian Red Crescent Society emergency medical responders, must be protected. We therefore salute our folks ‚Äì our brothers and sisters at the frontlines ‚Äì who are responding to the wounded, ensuring they get medical and psychosocial relief during these times. We call on all nations to respect IHL to the utmost. #NotATarget

(Three minute read) Quick. What if everyone in San Francisco and Oakland was told to evacuate immediately or you might be killed. Where would you go? Especially if you had very little money. Very little food. And almost no water. That‚Äôs the situation in the Gaza Strip. The Israeli government has told half of Gaza‚Äôs two million people to leave so they don‚Äôt get killed by Israeli bombs, missiles, and ground forces. I totally understand what Israel is trying to do. They want to wipe out Hamas. I get it. That attack was evil and despicable. But do you agree with Israel‚Äôs response? So far more than 1500 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli missiles. A third of those deaths were kids. And it‚Äôs only going to get worse as the war goes on. I read an opinion piece in the NYT from a reserve officer in the Israeli Defense Forces who has just been called up. Major Nir Avishai Cohen wrote: ‚ÄúPalestinians aren‚Äôt the enemy. Just like the majority of Israelis want to live a calm, peaceful and dignified life, so do Palestinians.‚Äù ‚ÄúIsraelis and Palestinians alike have been in the grip of a religious minority for decades.‚Äù ‚ÄúOn both sides, the intractable positions of a small group have dragged us into violence.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter who is more cruel, or more ruthless. The ideology of both have fueled this conflict, leading to the death of too many innocent civilians.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis war will end sooner or later. I am not sure I will come back from it alive, but I do know that a minute after the war is over, both Israelis and Palestinians will have to reckon with the leaders who led them to this moment.‚Äù ‚ÄúAt the end, after all of the dead Israelis and Palestinians are buried, after we have finished washing away the rivers of blood, the people who share a home in this land will have to understand that there is no other choice but to follow the path of peace. That is where true victory lies.‚Äù I totally agree.

With mass evacuations underway across Israel and Palestine to save frightened and innocent lives, families can only grab a handful of belongings ‚Äì many leaving pets and memories behind. The distressing footage circulating on social media depicts organized gunmen callously shooting vulnerable animals without reason has compelled us to undertake an urgent mission to rescue any of these animals that we can. Animals who somehow, miraculously, survived after their human families were killed are roaming the streets alone, starving, terrified, and often severely injured. Animals have no place in the war and it is our global responsibility to come together and help civilians and helpless animals alike. Our team, Let The Animals Live (LTAL), is now in the south with veterinarians, pet food, and equipment to help as many animals as possible. The most dangerous areas are inaccessible, but your donations are going to brave volunteers who are distributing supplies to animals in dire need. Your donation is crucial for this life-saving mission. When we gain access to the high-risk areas, we will make every effort to rescue the animals. Please, let‚Äôs show these animals the compassion they deserve and donate generously today: https://bit.ly/3Fc2tBC.:=:https://networkforanimals.org/donation/ It's important to emphasize that our focus is solely on providing care and assistance to animals affected by this tragic situation and that they are not part of the ongoing conflict. We do not endorse or participate in any form of violence or warfare. Photo credit: Reuters/Ibraheem Abu Mustafa

The world is on heightened alert today The Royal Newfoundland Constabulary (RNC) is taking immediate action to ensure the safety and security of our community. In response to global online threats regarding potential events today, the RNC will be increasing patrols at cultural centers, synagogues, mosques, and all other places of worship. it is solely in place to ensure your safety. It is important for everyone to be aware that these threats are stemming from the ongoing conflict in the Middle East. While we recognize the concerns expressed by community leaders in our province, we want to assure you that we are taking proactive measures to address them. To achieve this, you will notice a heightened police presence in these areas. Officers will be working diligently to maintain peace and protect the well-being of all residents. It is worth mentioning that numerous cities in Canada and worldwide are also implementing similar precautions to safeguard their communities. By taking these steps they are prioritizing the safety of our residents and fostering unity amidst these challenging times. We encourage all individuals to remain vigilant and report any incidents or allegations of hate-motivated acts to the RNC by calling 709-729-8000. If you come across an immediate threat or emergency, please dial 9-1-1 without hesitation. #SafetyFirst #UnitedAgainstHate

Who Wins? I have no aspirations to be a political commentator ‚Äì what a minefield that would be! I have no interest in debate about political candidates and beliefs ‚Äì another minefield with the potential to end lifelong friendships, split families and, yes, cause wars. My late mother, ever sensitive to war, would stop her kids fighting with the warning, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how wars start you know.‚Äù When she was really fed up with the bickering, she sent us outside with an instruction to, ‚ÄúSort yourselves out in the garden.‚Äù We would get into the garden, forget what started the row and end up playing ‚Äì good move, Mum! But I digress. I write about war. I am not fascinated by war in an obsessive sense, but I have been compelled over some twenty-odd years to write fiction and some non-fiction rooted in a time of war because the fallout of conflict and the impact on ordinary people is often lost in statistics found in history books. The people get lost in the numbers. And I am challenged by writing about people caught in extraordinary times. I write what is known as ‚Äúcommercial fiction‚Äù so I have to walk a fine line between giving a sense of the human experience in a troubling situation, yet at the same time being respectful of the fact that any storyteller is effectively in the entertainment business. That might upset writers who do not view themselves through such a lens, but that's the bottom line. Yes, we touch upon the human condition in all sorts of situations, and we can lead our readers to universal truths ‚Äì I have always said that writers can touch ‚Äútruth‚Äù more readily with fiction than we can with fact ‚Äì but even though we take a reader along a winding path of many emotions, at the end of the journey it‚Äôs best if hope prevails. So where am I going with today‚Äôs post? Back to war. In 1989 when the Berlin wall was torn down, I remember a correspondent who had reported on a number of human disasters, commenting, ‚ÄúPeace has broken out all over the world.‚Äù If only. Over the past couple of years, it seemed as if conflict was breaking out everywhere, and now this ‚Äì the utter tragedy in Israel and Gaza. I‚Äôm not going to get into who did this and who did that, though I remember Mum watching a TV report on a war and saying, ‚ÄúThey should put these so-called leaders in a field and let them fight it out ‚Äì leave the people out of it.‚Äù I tend to agree, because the majority of people just want to get on with trying to forge a good life, or at least a bearable existence. And they trust their elected leaders to protect every single hoped-for good day. People want to look back at a well-lived life. Since childhood, in my amateurish way I‚Äôve immersed myself in trying to understand the causes of war and the human cost of conflict. I know this much: follow the money. Follow the power hungry. Put those afraid of losing power under the microscope. They are often connected, threaded together across the globe, a self-obsessed daisy chain of snake charmers. Every move is calculated because it is in their interests to have conflict in other regions of the world, if not their own. War in one geopolitical location has the potential to enhance the prospects of a leader in a country far removed from the terror. And then follow the money. Who loses money in a time of peace? You can even whittle it down to conflict within a country, a city or a village. Who wants to retain power, who wants to be right, and who wants to make money? I could give solid examples for each of those comments, but that does not serve what I want to say ‚Äì which is this: The ordinary people pay. Whether in uniform, bombed out of their homes or shot down in the streets and in their kitchens, the people pay the price in blood, in terror, grief, pain and the dying promise of tomorrow; a future lost because the lifeblood of their hopes and dreams is flowing away. I am inspired to write these thoughts having seen photos of a journalist and his cameraman in Gaza who broke down while reporting on the terrors people are suffering, just as a woman doing the same job in Israel broke down and wept two days ago. No one wins. This morning these are the words echoing in my mind: ‚ÄúO what made fatuous sunbeams toil To break earth's sleep at all?‚Äù From the poem ‚ÄúFutility‚Äù written by Wilfred Owen. Owen was killed on the Western Front just days before the Armistice declaring an end to the Great War in 1918. To lift you up when so much pain and suffering is weighing down the world, I think our greatest task is encapsulated in the prayer of St. Francis. I don't care which god or goddess a person prays to, or if they pray at all ‚Äì that's their business and it‚Äôs personal. But I love these words: ‚ÄúWhere there is hatred, let me sow love; where there is injury, pardon; where there is doubt, faith; where there is despair, hope; where there is darkness, light; where there is sadness, joy.‚Äù When I first heard those words, I thought I should take them as my marching orders for life. I‚Äôve (truncated)
WHAT IS THE ACTUAL CONFLICT BETWEEN ISRAEL AND PALESTINE

Israel‚Äôs military told some 1 million Palestinians on Friday to evacuate northern Gaza and head to the southern part of the besieged territory, an unprecedented order applying to almost half the population ahead of an expected ground invasion against the ruling Hamas militant group. The UN warned that so many people fleeing en masse ‚Äî with just a 24-hour deadline ‚Äî would be calamitous. Hamas, which staged a shocking and brutal attack on Israel nearly a week ago and has fired thousands of rockets since, dismissed it as a ploy and called on people to stay in their homes. The evacuation order, which includes Gaza City, home to hundreds of thousands of Palestinians, sparked widespread panic among civilians and aid workers already running from Israeli airstrikes and contending with a total siege and a territory-wide blackout. ‚ÄúForget about food, forget about electricity, forget about fuel. The only concern now is just if you‚Äôll make it, if you‚Äôre going to live,‚Äù said Nebal Farsakh, a spokesperson for the Palestinian Red Crescent in Gaza City, as she broke into heaving sobs. The war has already claimed over 2,800 lives on both sides and sent tensions soaring across the region. Israel has traded fire in recent days with Lebanon‚Äôs Hezbollah militant group, sparking fears of an ever wider conflict, though that frontier is currently calm. | via Associated Press

THE IMPORTANCE OF COMMUNICATION IN MARRIAGE. üëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëá 1.Understanding and Connection: Effective communication helps couples truly understand each other. It fosters a deeper emotional connection and intimacy. 2.Conflict Resolution: Open and honest communication is essential for resolving conflicts and disagreements in a constructive manner. It allows both partners to express their concerns and find solutions. 3.Building Trust: Trust is built on transparency and honesty. Consistent, truthful communication helps maintain and strengthen the trust within a marriage. 4.Expressing Needs and Expectations: Each partner has their own needs and expectations in a marriage. Communicating these needs helps prevent misunderstandings and unmet expectations. 5.Emotional Support: Marriage involves being there for your partner during both the ups and downs of life. Effective communication allows you to provide emotional support when your spouse needs it most. 6.Quality Time: By communicating about your schedules and priorities, you can ensure that you spend quality time together, strengthening the bond between you. 7.Preventing Resentment: Unspoken concerns or grievances can lead to resentment over time. Communicating them prevents these negative feelings from building up. 8.Shared Goals: Discussing your goals and aspirations as a couple helps you work together towards a common future. 9. Maintaining Romance: Open communication allows you to express your love and appreciation for your spouse, keeping the romance alive. 10.Adapting to Change: Life is full of changes, and communicating about them helps both partners adapt to new circumstances, whether it's a job change, a move, or the arrival of children.

THE IMPORTANCE OF COMMUNICATION IN MARRIAGE.
üëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëá

1.Understanding and Connection:

 Effective communication helps couples truly understand each other. It fosters a deeper emotional connection and intimacy.

2.Conflict Resolution:

 Open and honest communication is essential for resolving conflicts and disagreements in a constructive manner. It allows both partners to express their concerns and find solutions.

3.Building Trust:

Trust is built on transparency and honesty. Consistent, truthful communication helps maintain and strengthen the trust within a marriage.

4.Expressing Needs and Expectations:

Each partner has their own needs and expectations in a marriage. Communicating these needs helps prevent misunderstandings and unmet expectations.

5.Emotional Support:

 Marriage involves being there for your partner during both the ups and downs of life. Effective communication allows you to provide emotional support when your spouse needs it most.

6.Quality Time:

By communicating about your schedules and priorities, you can ensure that you spend quality time together, strengthening the bond between you.

7.Preventing Resentment:

Unspoken concerns or grievances can lead to resentment over time. Communicating them prevents these negative feelings from building up.

8.Shared Goals:

Discussing your goals and aspirations as a couple helps you work together towards a common future.

9. Maintaining Romance:

Open communication allows you to express your love and appreciation for your spouse, keeping the romance alive.

10.Adapting to Change:

Life is full of changes, and communicating about them helps both partners adapt to new circumstances, whether it's a job change, a move, or the arrival of children.

FIB COMMANDER BRIGADIER ALFRED MATAMBO VISITS KENYA QUICK REACTION FORCE SERVING UNDER MONUSCO IN BENI DRC In a gesture of solidarity and support, the Force Intervention Brigade (FIB) Commander, Brigadier Alfred Matambo, paid a significant visit to the Kenyan Quick Reaction Force (QRF) deployed under the United Nations Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo (MONUSCO) in Beni. This visit underscores the critical role played by international peacekeepers in promoting stability and security in the troubled region. The Democratic Republic of Congo, particularly the volatile eastern provinces, has been plagued by a long-standing conflict, characterized by militia activities, inter-ethnic violence, and the illicit exploitation of natural resources. The FIB, consisting of troops from various contributing countries, has been a crucial element of MONUSCO's efforts to restore peace and security in this tumultuous region. Brigadier Matambo, a seasoned military strategist and leader, arrived in Kenya QRF Base in Beni to assess the operational readiness and morale of the troops, which has been at the forefront of MONUSCO's efforts in countering armed groups and providing humanitarian assistance to the affected population. During his visit, he commended the Kenyan troops for their dedication and unwavering commitment to the mission's objectives. In a meeting with Kenyan QRF commanders, Brigadier Matambo emphasized the importance of coordinated efforts among MONUSCO forces and the need for adaptability in the face of evolving security challenges. He stated, "Our mission is not only to protect the people of the Democratic Republic of Congo but also to help create conditions for lasting peace. Your role here is crucial, and your sacrifices are not unnoticed." The Kenyan QRF, known for their rapid response capabilities, has been instrumental in thwarting attacks, protecting civilians, and providing critical medical aid to the wounded. They have also been involved in community engagement initiatives aimed at fostering trust and cooperation with local communities, a pivotal aspect of peacekeeping in conflict zones. Brigadier Matambo's visit serves as a testament to the international community's commitment to the peace and stability of the Democratic Republic of Congo. The FIB's presence, along with dedicated troop contributions from nations like Kenya, plays a pivotal role in stabilizing the region and creating an environment conducive to the political and socio-economic development that the Congolese people so desperately need. As Brigadier Matambo concludes his visit to Beni, he reaffirms the FIB's unwavering commitment to its mission and expresses gratitude to all peacekeepers, including the Kenyan QRF, for their dedication and sacrifices in pursuit of a peaceful and prosperous Democratic Republic of Congo. The international community continues to stand united in its quest to bring an end to the suffering of the Congolese people and pave the way for a brighter future in the region. https://bit.ly/3RW0atM:=:https://mod.go.ke/news/fib-commander-brigadier-alfred-matambo-visits-kenya-quick-reaction-force-serving-under-monusco-in-beni-drc-2/

NSCDC BOSS LAUNCHES 12 SECURITY BOOKS, CALLS FOR INSTITUTIONALISATION OF SECURITY THREAT PROGRAMMES. The Minister of Interior, Dr Olubunmi Tunji-Ojo, says that the role of research in the enhancement of internal security can not be over emphasised. The Minister said this during the launch of 12 security books co-authored by the Commandant General of the Nigeria Security and Civil Defence Corps, Ahmed Abubakar Audi, PhD, mni, OFR and the Academy President of International Academy for Gender and Peace, Prof Tyoor Therhemba on at the Corps National Headquarters, Abuja. He said that it was important for security personnel to be properly trained based on research peculiar to time and security threats. ‚ÄúThe battle is more ideological than physical, superior knowledge makes it ideological which comes from a place of learning. ‚ÄúThe bad guys should be running to catch up with the pace of the state and we can only achieve this in the era of intellectualism,‚Äù he said. He further said that he will ensure all agencies under the Ministry, established a functional library to foster educational growth and service delivery. Tunji-Ojo said that the Ministry will set up a team of professionals to provide technical advisory services. He said that the team, tagged Paramilitary Brain Trust (PBT), will consist of intellectuals such as retired senior officers and professors and will be given research topics to tackle depending on peculiar security situations. While addressing personnel, he said that the era of promotion just by writing exams might be over soon. He said that promotion of officers and men of paramilitary agencies will be as a result of evaluation parameters. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to be a CG to be celebrated, in your private corner, give and do your best and know that one day that little effort of yours might be what is needed to turn this country around. ‚ÄúAbility to cast problems and preorder solutions is what leadership is about,‚Äù he said. The Minister expressed satisfaction at the level of performance and capacity of the NSCDC boss, adding that the ability to turn threats to opportunities is what distinguishes successful people from others as displayed by Audi. ‚ÄúI assure you that NSCDC is doing well, we can do better and will do better as there are lots of reforms we are working on,‚Äù the Minister said. The National Security Adviser (NSA), Mallam Nuhu Ribadu in his keynote address congratulated the CG for the efforts put into the books towards solving our security threats. The NSA, represented by Major General AG Laka, called for improved synergy among all the security organisations. He assured the populace that a safe and peaceful Nigeria is sacrosant and non-negotiable, hence, all hands must be on deck to respond to emerging security threats, Dr Audi earlier in his remarks, said that Nigeria‚Äôs struggle for independence, post colonialism, slavery, Cold War amongst other situations had affected Nigerias security landscape in a peculiar way, leading to emerging security threats such as terrorism, cyber crimes. ‚ÄúAlongside organised trans-border crimes which have over time intertwined and confounded the nation‚Äôs security situation. According to him, to tackle Nigerias security threats, adequate research and institutionalisation of programmes that aim to provide solutions to these threats must be priotised. Audi said that one of the researches carried out revealed that no kidnap occurred without the involvement of an insider, hence the need for more of such researches. He enjoined citizens to reflect on what they can do for the country and not just what the country can do for its citizens. The NSCDC boss however frowned at the absence of indigenous instructional materials to adequately guide security studies in line with peculiar security threats faced by Nigeria. He said that the books were aimed at promoting national security, identitying security bridges, proffer recommendations, contribute to policy, studies and knowledge of security. ‚ÄúThe 12 books are titled; Civil Defence and Military under the Geneva Conventions, Critical Dictates of International Humanitarian Law and the Development of the Civil Defence, Readings on Nigeria‚Äôs National Security. ‚ÄúPeace, Conflict and Human Security in Africa, International Cooperation Against Trafficking in Persons, Terrorism and Threat to Food Security in Lake Chad Region, amongst other publications,‚Äù Audi listed. Signed : BABAWALE ZAID AFOLABI (CSC) CORPS‚Äô NATIONAL PRO NSCDC HEADQUARTERS ABUJA. Hon. Olubunmi Tunji-Ojo Ministry of Interior Nigeria Nigeria Security and Civil Defence Corps

15 lessons from the book "The Culture Code: The Secrets of Highly Successful Groups" by Daniel Coyle: 1. Purpose is the foundation of a strong culture. Groups with a clear and shared purpose are more likely to be successful than groups without one. 2. Psychological safety is essential for collaboration and learning. People need to feel safe to take risks, share ideas, and admit mistakes in order to learn and grow. 3. Shared rituals help to build trust and cohesion. Groups that have shared rituals, such as team celebrations or regular meetings, are more likely to be successful. 4. Communication is key to success. Groups need to be able to communicate effectively both internally and externally. 5. Feedback is essential for learning and improvement. Groups need to be able to give and receive feedback constructively. 6. Conflict is not always a bad thing. Groups can benefit from healthy conflict, which can lead to new ideas and solutions. 7. Diversity is a strength. Groups that are diverse in terms of their members' backgrounds, perspectives, and skills are more likely to be successful. 8. Inclusion is essential for a strong culture. All members of a group need to feel valued and respected. 9. Leadership is important, but it is not the only thing that matters. Groups need strong leaders, but they also need collective intelligence and collaboration. 10. Culture is not static. It is constantly evolving, and leaders need to be able to adapt to change. 11. Build safety. This means creating an environment where people feel safe to take risks, share ideas, and admit mistakes. 12. Share vulnerability. This means being willing to be open and honest with each other, even about our weaknesses. 13. Establish purpose. This means having a clear and shared goal that everyone is working towards. 14. Create a culture of learning. This means encouraging people to ask questions, share ideas, and learn from each other. 15. Celebrate success. I hope these lessons are helpful! Former US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger has criticized European nations for being too accepting of mass immigration of people of different cultures. Specifically, cultures that now openly cheer on the Hamas attack against Israel. He also warned that soon, European people may find themselves under attack. In an interview with Mathias Dopfner, the CEO of German media group Axel Springer, Kissinger said it was ‚Äòpainful‚Äô seeing Arabs celebrating the death of Jews in the streets of Berlin. ‚ÄòIt was a grave mistake to let in so many people of totally different cultural and religious concepts because it creates a pressure group inside each country that does that,‚Äô he said. Kissinger, who himself fled persecution for being Jewish, also called for ‚Äòunconditional‚Äô support for Israel, and that there should be a ‚Äòpenalty‚Äô placed on Hamas. However, he warned of the dangers of escalating the situation stating, ‚Äòthe Middle East conflict has the danger of escalating and bringing in other Arab countries under the pressure of their public opinion.‚Äô He also noted that, thanks to mass migration, Europe may find itself part of this conflict whether it likes it or not. ‚ÄòEvery European nation has the same interest because the same attitude might erupt in the direction of Europe,‚Äô he concluded.
