Qantas evacuation flight on the way to rescue stranded Australians in Israel Charles Miranda October 13, 2023 5:25 pm https://www.flightradar24.com/ASY1168/326ad55b The first of two Qantas flights has left London bound for Tel Aviv to collect hundreds of stranded and desperate Australians looking to flee the conflict. ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE Flight ASY1168 VH-ZNN Snowy River, the 236-seater 787-9 Dreamliner, had to be pulled from its normal commercial international route to Australia to make the trip to the Israeli capital with three senior captains on board. Qantas does not normally fly into Tel Aviv, so it has also had to carry, as well as a full cabin crew, specialist ground crew to board the passengers, engineers and medical personnel. The aircraft is carrying enough fuel to make the round trip to and from London without refuelling, about a five-hour flight. The mammoth operation to reroute the aircraft at short notice to make the rescue mission is being coordinated from an Integrated Operations Centre at Qantas headquarters in Mascot, Sydney. Personnel from 15 different areas of the business had to come together along with embedded DFAT officials to see the flight through, given the complexity of flying to a new airport and flight path destination and during a declared war. The second flight will leave Sunday on the same run as the first and then next Tuesday the larger Airbus A380 will fly the passengers from London to Sydney via Singapore. Qantas agreed to pick up all the costs for the flight, which is free for passengers, as it has done for other mercy flights. ‚ÄúGiven the uncertain situation in the region, these flights are subject to ongoing safety and security assessments, and regulatory approvals in several countries,‚Äù Qantas‚Äô head of Integrated Operations Centre Daniel Dihen said ‚ÄúMore than 900 Qantas crew put their hands up to operate these flights, far exceeding the 70 required. We sincerely thank all of them, and all those working behind the scenes to make these special assistance flights possible.‚Äù The national carrier has a proud history of flying into war zones beginning in World War 2 carrying US and Australian troops into battle, evacuating after the fall of Saigon during the Vietnam War, the Iraq war in 2003 then part of the biggest airlift in history after the fall of Kabul in Afghanistan where it collected refugees and others from a military air base in the UAE. In January 1993 a Qantas B747 made two flights as it joined the ADF‚Äôs Operation Solace and delivered 644 soldiers, mostly from 1RAR in Townsville, to Mogadishu ‚Äúwar zone‚Äù as part of a UN backed mission to regain order in the country torn apart by feuding warlords. Crews were fired on from the perimeter fence of the airstrip forcing the ADF troops, yet to unload weapons, to scramble from the apron. From ca350

I NO LONGER LOVE MY WIFE "She didn't do anything and that's what makes it even more difficult. You know when you wish there was a reason so you can just hold on to that but deep down you know even you cannot just explain it." He said. Is there anyone in the picture? I asked, knowing what the answer was likely to be. Of course there was someone in the picture, there always seems to be someone. ------------------------- Now, hold on. That, right there, is how many see it when it comes to a man. Strange how a woman can understand that a certain sequence of events can lead to losing emotions for the husband yet, with a man, it is almost always reduced to it being about another woman. It is not always about another woman. This happens to men too. Yes, many of the reasons track back to the man not paying full attention to his own emotions for her at the beginning but it is not always so. A man can start out with full affections and wake up one day to find it all gone. Unfortunately, the lady begins to try it all; sexual remedies, lingeries, new styles and new meal recipes but really, how does one find the solution to an issue whose trigger you don't understand? This is where effective nuptial communication comes into play but then many have no idea what it is or how to put it into use. You'd see her and feel nothing. Spark gone. The sex is affected too, she knows it is but you are too far gone to notice that turgidity is not even happening for you....then that leads to talks about the possibility of an erectile issue but deep down, when you refuse to take the pills, herbs and miss appointments, you know it's because the emotions are simply gone. Sometimes you want to leave, but you know it would feel wicked yet, (you know it probably is) but within you, your heart is already elsewhere. A place where the smile costs nothing, the conversation is endless and the sync seems perfectly aligned. A place of little things and conflicts that end up in seemingly beautiful things and non conflict places. For others, it is not as complicated because this began with the feeling that the home became a warfront, a place of intimidation and fear perpetrated by she who should be a significant other.....yet, if the desire is to truly create or recreate emotions lost from home, the solutions lie at home, and in you. ------------------------- You want to go and try again, together, but how can you resolve an issue you dare not share? Good friends would come in handy here but half of them are doing worse, and the other half would just crush and blame. Again, if the desire is to truly create or recreate emotions lost from home, the solutions lie at home, and in you. Speak with someone you can trust to stay neutral and help you back to where you need to be.

Europe was a theater of incessant imperial conflict for centuries after the fall of the Roman Empire. City-states often struggled to retain autonomy for long in the entanglements. Dubrovnik, a historic city in modern-day Croatia, was an exception. It had navigated successfully in the orbits of the Byzantine Empire, the Republic of Venice and the Ottoman Empire, ascending to a commercial stronghold that connected the East and the West by trade. Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque architectures all have their proud representatives in the city today, some preserved for centuries and others restored. Together with the scenic Dalmatian coastline, they‚Äôve earned Dubrovnik the fame of ‚ÄúPearl of the Adriatic.‚Äù In 1979, UNESCO recognized the old city of Dubrovnik as a World Heritage Site. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

The *chills* run in when the body doesn't cry. The *sore throat* stinks when the woes can't be communicated. The *stomach* burns when the tantrums can't go out. *Diabetes* kicks in when it's lonely. *body fat* when dissatisfaction kicks in. The *headache* depresses when doubts creep in. The *heart* gives up when the meaning of life seems to end. The *allergy* sets in when perfectionism becomes unbearable. The *nails* break when the defenses are threatened. *chest shrugs* when pride slaps. The *pressure* rises when fear grips. The *neuroses* freeze when the "inner child" tyrants. The *fever* heats up when the defenses break the boundaries of immunity. Your *knees* hurt when pride doesn't bend. *Cancer* kills when you don't forgive and/or get tired of living. What about the *silent pains* ? How they speak in our bodies! *Illness is not bad, it warns you when you've lost the direction*. The *road* to happiness is not straight, there are curves called *Mistakes*. A powerful engine called *Love* A good insurance called *FAITH* Abundant fuel called *Patience* Author unknown Love and Light Michelle Price Release and balance your feet with the energy of Mother Earth. The Chess Scene This post was prompted by another post regarding the intentional destruction of the camp. While this scene has been discussed quite often, I do not personally subscribe to the theory that MacReady gave Childs a Molotov cocktail to drink, since I assume that a perfect imitation would know the difference; therefore, that element of the scene will be outside the scope of my post, along with the question as to whether Childs was a Thing. I think that the chess scene was important for two main reasons - it provided characterization for MacReady and it foreshadowed MacReady's future conflict with the Thing. Regarding the characterization aspect, we are introduced to a man who likes his booze, who is somewhat aloof from the rest of the group, and who is presumably a strategic thinker since he enjoys playing chess. It's worth noting that forty years ago, there was more of a stigma or stereotype associated with chess, video games, and computers that does not exist today, so I think that it's fair to state that given the context of its time, the movie wanted to show us that MacReady was smart. In addition, we see his reaction to losing a game of chess. While I won't argue that the computer actually cheated, if you look at the board before the computer declares "Rook to Knight six," it is apparent that there was no move the black Rook could have made that would have resulted in checkmate (the white King could have moved one space left to either eliminate or avoid the black Rook). This can easily be attributed to filmmaker error or lack of care so I won't dwell on it, but what's important is that MacReady decided to "flip the table" rather than accept defeat. He might not win this game of chess, but the computer would be destroyed in a scorched earth ploy. This scene was somewhat of a microcosm of the rest of the movie and foreshadowed the ending. When MacReady assumed command of the group, he engaged in a metaphorical game of chess against the Thing. The Thing clearly identified MacReady as a threat and engaged in its own strategic moves, which is why the Thing was keen to frame MacReady. After the blood test scene, MacReady finally had the upper hand, just as he thought he did during the chess scene when he stated, "Poor baby, you're starting to lose it, aren't you?" However, the Thing essentially "cheated" to avoid defeat. Rather than continuing its game of strategy against MacReady, it decided to remove the camp's generator so that it, and everyone else, would freeze. At that moment, MacReady knew that he had lost the game and explicitly acknowledged that they were all dead men. However, rather than accept defeat, he again "flipped the table" and went scorched earth by destroying the entire camp and presumably killing Blair-Thing rather than allowing it to go into hibernation (although that's another discussion as to whether Blair-Thing was actually destroyed).

The Ju 52 was similar to the company's previous Junkers W 33, although larger. In 1930, German aeronautical engineer Ernst Zindel and his team designed the Ju 52 at the Junkers works at Dessau. According to aviation author J. Richard Smith, the Ju 52 directly drew upon the company's First World War-era Junkers J 1 - the world's first all-metal aeroplane. On 13 October 1930, the first prototype, designated Ju 52ba, performed the type's maiden flight; it was initially powered by a single Junkers-built liquid-cooled V-12 engine, capable of generating up to 800 hp. During the aircraft's extensive trials, it was reengined with a 755 hp BMW IV water-cooled inline-6 powerplant. The second prototype, designated Ju 52de, featured an increased wing span and was powered by the BMW IV engine at first; it was soon reengined with the 750 hp 14-cylinder twin-row air-cooled radial Armstrong Siddeley Leopard and re-designated Ju 52di. Later on, the Ju 52di was again reengined with the 750 hp Junkers Jumo 204 air-cooled inverted inline-6, after which it was re-designated Ju 52do. The third prototype, designated Ju 52ce, had a strengthened structure, a modified leading edge, and was fitted with both a wheeled and float undercarriages. During May 1931, one of the prototypes, designated Ju 52cai, was written off after a crash. While these initial aircraft had been powered by a single engine, Junkers decided to develop the Ju 52 into a trimotor configuration. Accordingly, the Ju 52/3m (drei motoren‚Äî"three engines") was developed, being powered by an arrangement of three radial engines. According to Smith, the earliest known Ju 52/3m was delivered to Bolivian airline Lloyd A√©reo Boliviano during 1932. During its initial production years, airlines were the type's most common customers. By the mid-1930s, the Ju 52/3mce and Ju 52/3fe, were the two primary production variants, both being powered by the BMW 132 radial engine. During 1934, work commenced on a militarised model of the Ju 52/3m, designated Ju 52/3mg3e, on behalf of the then-secret Luftwaffe. This model could function as a medium bomber, being furnished with a pair of defensive gun turrets and operated by a crew of four. Between 1934 and 1935, a total of 450 Ju 52/3mg3e aircraft were delivered to the Luftwaffe. Numerous improved models would be introduced prior to and during the Second World War. The dominant production model was the Ju 52/3mg7e, featuring advances such as an autopilot, enlarged doors to the cabin, and other general enhancements.[5] It was configured as a pure transport aircraft, being capable of carrying up to 18 fully-equipped troops. Defensive armaments comprised a dorsal-mounted 13 mm MG 131 machine gun and a pair of sideways-mounted 7.9mm MG 15 machine guns.[5] Successive models saw other improvements, such as revised glazing, newer engines, undercarriage strengthening, and increased take-off weight. The final wartime model to be developed, designated Ju 52/3mg14e, featured improved armour protection for the pilot and a bolstered defensive armament. From mid-1943 onwards, the Luftwaffe began to make less use of the Ju 52, interest having waned in the type. German officials were interested in procuring a successor to the type; at one stage, the Reich Air Ministry showed enthusiasm for the Junkers Ju 352, a larger transport aircraft somewhat resembling the Ju 52. Actions were taken to convert Junkers' Ju 52 production lines to instead manufacture Ju 352s; however, the conflict's end in May 1945 led to the effort being abandoned in an unfinished state. As such, German production of the Ju 52 was terminated during 1944; Smith claims that a total of 3,234 aircraft of various models were constructed during the conflict. In the postwar era, manufacture of the Ju 52 resumed, albeit in foreign countries. It was constructed in France by Avions Amiot as the Amiot AAC.1 Toucan; it was also produced in Spain by Construcciones Aeron√°uticas SA (CASA) as the CASA 352. A handful of captured wartime aircraft were also rebuilt by Short Brothers of Northern Ireland for civilian service. Development of the Ju 52 commenced during 1930, headed by German aeronautical engineer Ernst Zindel. The aircraft's design incorporated a corrugated duralumin metal skin as a strengthening measure, which was very unusual at the time. The Ju 52's maiden flight was performed on 13 October 1930. It was initially designed with a single engine; however, it was produced in quantity as a trimotor. The primary early production model, the Ju 52/3m, was principally operated as a 17-seat airliner or utility transport aircraft by various civil operators during the 1930s. Following the rise of Nazi Germany, thousands of Ju 52s were procured as a staple military transport of the nation. The Ju 52/3mg7e was the principal production model. The Ju 52 was in production between 1931 and 1952. In a civilian role, it flew with over 12 airlines, including Swissair and Deutsche Luft Hansa, as both (truncated)

text: ¬©Ô∏è When I and my fiancee were dating, we had gone a whole year without quarreling Yes! One whole year, without arguing... Just when I was thinking of proposing to her, a thought crossed my mind "We have never quarrelled before, are you sure we can cope with the conflict that comes with marriage?" I asked myself... Funny enough, I tried sparking up arguments whenever she visited, complained bitterly about anything she did but it didn't work She would either tell me "I'm sorry my love, you know I didn't mean to offend you" and smile that her irresistible smile and before I realise, I would be smiling myself... Or she would look at me with her baby face until I apologize. She never shouted back or spoke rudely...until one day, I made the mistake of asking her why she never picked a quarrel "You never shout or speak back at me, you're always too cool...I don't know if you will even be able to handle conflict in marriage sef..." I complained She looked at me, shocked and surprised at the same time... "So you want us to be quarreling?" She asked "No, but...you know, arguments bring better understanding in relationships" I explained bluntly "You think I don't understand you enough?" She asked, still calm By then I realised I was just being stupid...I kept mute "No problem, you've asked for it" she said Gbam. I started apologizing immediately but she gave deaf ears...a part of still wanted the drama to happen so I left her alone after pleading for some time I left for my room and waited for her to come and meet me but she stayed in the living room for almost an hour... Then she finally came to the room with a very strong face... "Come and eat" ...TBC... ¬©Ô∏è African Man

October 14 | Saint of the Day ‚ûï POPE SAINT CALLISTUS I Also known as ‚Ä¢ Callixtus I ‚Ä¢ Calixtus I Profile Born a slave, owned by Carpophorus, a Christian in the household of Caesar. His master entrusted a large sum to Callistus to open a bank, which took in several deposits, made several loans to people who refused to pay them back, and went broke. Knowing he would be personally blamed and punished, Callistus fled, but was caught and returned to his owner. Several depositors begged for his life, believing he had not lost the money, but had stolen and hid it. They were wrong; he wasn't a thief, just a victim, but he was sentenced to work the tin mines. By a quirk of Roman law, the ownership of Callistus was transferred from Carpophorus to the state, and when he was later ransomed out of his sentence with a number of other Christians, he became a free man. Pope Zephyrinus put Callistus in charge of the Roman public burial grounds, today still called the Cemetery of Saint Callistus. Archdeacon. Sixteenth Pope. Most of what we know about him has come down to us from his critics, including an anti-Pope of the day. Callistus was on more than one occasion accused of heresy for such actions as permitting a return to Communion for sinners who had repented and done penance, or for proclaiming that differences in economic class were no barrier to marriage. This last put him in conflict with Roman civil law, but he stated that in matters concerning the Church and the sacraments, Church law trumped civil law. In both cases he taught what the Church has taught for centuries, including today, and though a whole host of schismatics wrote against him, his crime seems to have been to practice orthodox Christianity. Martyred in the persecutions of Alexander Severus. Papal Ascension c.218 Died ‚Ä¢ martyred c.223 ‚Ä¢ legend says he was killed by being thrown down a well with a millstone around his neck, but there is no solid evidence Patronage cemetery workers Representation pope with a millstone on him or nearby St. Pope Callistus I, Pray for us! Source | Laudate #TheBeautyOfMyCatholicFaith #Laudate

Israel Palestine Conflict: ‡§∏‡•à‡§ï‡•ú‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ü‡•à‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§¨‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§§‡§≠‡•Ä... | Breaking News #israelvshamas #gazastrip #palestine #gazastrip

‚ÄúIdentification with the aggressor‚Äù (or defensive identification) is an unconscious defence mechanism whereby a victim of aggression and suffering (an alienated child) aligns with and behaves like someone (the alienating parent), who is more powerful, hostile, poses a threat, or cannot be overcome. In this way, an alienated child will learn to lie and manipulate as their ‚Äòwinning‚Äô and ‚Äòstronger‚Äô parent does. Alignment and identification with the bully/aggressor also helps to suppress deeper feelings of guilt, vulnerability and shame. It‚Äôs like Stockholm Syndrome when a hostage feels powerless and aligns with their captor. They start to feel gratitude towards the aggressor when they are kind and (conditionally) loving. Deep down, the child/hostage will be aware that their alienating parent isn‚Äôt particularly healthy-minded or loving. The child knows, from experience, this parent is unpredictable, selfish/narcissistic, volatile, they run hot/cold - their parenting involves reward/punishment. The children are parentified, their childhood sacrificed to the adult problems of the alienator, and their reaction to narcissistic wounding as a result of what is usually a high conflict separation or divorce. To love a parent like this the child often will ‚Äòsplit‚Äô in order to cope. To make the alienated parent the villain/baddie is to make their life easier in dealing with the painful experience of alienation, and no longer being allowed to spend time with a loving and loved parent. It‚Äôs to switch off, and totally align with the alienating aggressor. The child is actually afraid of the alienator, and they can partially conquer that fear by becoming more like them, and that pleases the alienator too, which means the child may be less abused. Also, when a child witnesses emotional, psychological (or physical) abuse of a parent, it‚Äôs intimidating, terrifying, confusing, upsetting, and as a survival tactic, they feel that it‚Äôs best for them to be with the terrorising parent, the one it seems unwise to fall out with. There will be consequences. They are afraid and feel they‚Äôve lost one parent and don‚Äôt want to lose the other. What they see their alienating parent is capable of could be turned on them. The child ‚Äòtrauma bonds‚Äô with the parent who poses the biggest threat. This is why the child feels negatively towards the things the alienator/aggressor is negative towards ‚Äì it‚Äôs safer and easier to do so. They forget that their aggressor is really the origin of their suffering. I hope this goes some way to explain the phenomenon of why an alienated child supports, defends, loves and aligns with an abusive, mentally unstable parent while rejecting their more balanced and loving one. #charliemccready #parentalalienation #highconflictcoparenting #rejectedparent #alienatedchild #alienatedparent #parentalalienationischildabuse #narcissisticchildabuse #coercivecontrol #traumabond #traumabondingisnotlove #traumabonding #healingtrauma #custodybattle #highconflictdivorce #divorcesupport #splitting #enmeshment

CALLING ALL INVENTORS! The Grizzly & Wolf Discovery Center is hosting The Kirk Horn Memorial Inventor‚Äôs Challenge Conflicts with humans get bears and wolves into trouble, but innovative product designs help protect people and their property as well as wildlife. Products like bear-resistant coolers and garbage cans, bear spray, fladry, and electrical deterrents all started with someone‚Äôs clever idea. Do you have the next great idea that would help reduce bear and wolf conflict? We are calling all inventors to come up with and submit their new design ideas here at the Discovery Center. The winning applicant will be awarded up to $10,000 to take their idea to the next step! Want to know more? Visit our link: https://www.grizzlydiscoveryctr.org/inventors-challenge ‚Ä¢ Sign up here to receive Inventor‚Äôs Challenge details: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScANypCIDhlHTp-tUqJQYZzcUDJLJR2HXv5XOZlGS_2iNEEEw/viewform:=:https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScANypCIDhlHTp-tUqJQYZzcUDJLJR2HXv5XOZlGS_2iNEEEw/viewform?usp=embed_facebook ‚Ä¢ Shape your ideas for a complete design proposal to be submitted in SPRING 2024. ‚Ä¢ A panel of experts, including biologists and engineers, will review all Challenge proposals. ‚Ä¢ The winning design will be announced in LATE SPRING 2024. The Challenge supports projects that engage diverse communities and integrates equity and inclusion. Every inventor‚Äôs intellectual property is protected and the GWDC or its Board will not own any rights, titles, liabilities, or financial interests in its future development.

DAMINI'S GIRLFRIEND CHAPTER TWO As the days went by, tensions began to rise between Ebere and me. It started with a simple disagreement over food and quickly escalated into a full-blown conflict. One evening, I decided to surprise Damini by cooking yam, his favorite meal. I worked diligently in the kitchen, carefully following the recipe and putting my heart into every dish. The aroma filled the house as I set the table, eagerly waiting for Damini to arrive. When Ebere walked into the dining room and saw the food I had prepared, her face contorted with disdain. "What is this?" she exclaimed, looking at the dishes with disgust. "Damini and I can't eat such mediocre food. He deserves better." My excitement quickly turned to hurt and confusion. I couldn't understand why Ebere would react so harshly. "But I put a lot of effort into this. It's Damini's favorite," I said, my voice trembling with disappointment. Ebere scoffed. "Well, I don't care. I'll cook something better for him." Without hesitation, she marched into the kitchen and started preparing her own meal, completely disregarding my efforts. My frustration grew as I watched Ebere take over the kitchen. I approached her, trying to reason with her. "Ebere, please, let's not fight over this. I made this meal with love for my brother. Can't we enjoy it together?" But Ebere remained stubborn, her eyes fixed on her own cooking. "No, I won't settle for your inferior food. Damini deserves the best, and that's what I'll provide." Not wanting to escalate the issue, I decided to ignore her. I served myself the food I had prepared and went to my room to eat in peace. From that day onwards, I started avoiding Ebere. I didn't want to do anything that would make my brother regret inviting me over for the holidays. However, no matter how much I avoided her, she would always find a way to pick on me. One afternoon, I was peacefully doing my brother's laundry, humming a tune under my breath, when Ebere stormed in with a hostile demeanor. I watched in disbelief as she grabbed the clothes I was washing and carelessly threw them on the floor. "What are you doing?" I exclaimed, my voice filled with both shock and anger. "These clothes are dirty. I'll wash them properly," Ebere retorted, her eyes fixed on me with a challenging gaze. I couldn't bear to see my efforts trashed once again. I lunged forward, trying to stop Ebere from damaging the clothes any further. A physical struggle ensued as we fought bitterly, our emotions running high. Damini, alerted by the commotion, rushed to the backyard. Instead of calming the situation, he stood by Ebere's side, blindly supporting his girlfriend without considering the impact of his actions on me. "That's enough, Nancy!" Damini's voice boomed. "Stop causing trouble. Ebere is right. You didn't need to wash my clothes in the first place!" The words cut deep into my heart. I never expected my own brother to take sides against me, especially when I had done nothing but try to create harmony within the house. Heartbroken and feeling betrayed, I retreated to my room, tears streaming down my face. I immediately picked up my phone and called my mom, telling her I wasn't interested in staying any longer at Damini's house. Written by Madu Chioma Nuela

text: De oorlog tussen Isra√´l en Palestina dat ons allen diep raakt weegt zwaar. Het is een onderwerp dat met veel geschiedenis en emotie beladen is. Wat ik elke dag opnieuw herhaal is dat elke vorm van geweld en verlies van mensenlevens tragisch is en diep pijn doet. Mijn hart huilt voor alle mensen die lijden binnen dit conflict. Het is dan ook uiterst pijnlijk om zelfs in ons land politici te zien die de vlag hijsen voor enkel 1 kant van het conflict. De enige vlag dat gehezen dient te worden is de witte. De vlag van vrede en het einde aan geweld. Ik geloof in vrede, begrip en mededogen. Het is van belang dat we blijven streven naar een oplossing die rechtvaardig is met prioriteit voor de rechten en waarden van onschuldige mensen. Er worden op dit moment ernstige mensenrechten geschonden die niet onopgemerkt kunnen voorbij gaan. Het afsluiten van water, elektriciteit en blokkeren toevoer van voeding hebben we tussen Rusland en Oekra√Øne zien gebeuren, het herhaalt zich nu in een ander continent en het aantal slachtoffers tellen op. Staatshoofden dienen druk op te voeren om rust in regio te verkrijgen. Het is misschien een droom, maar ik blijf geloven in mijn dromen. We zijn medemensen verplicht samen te werken aan een wereld waarin vrede en harmonie heersen. Waar verschillen worden gevierd en begrepen, en waar iedereen in vrede kan leven, ongeacht hun afkomst. Mijn diepste steun gaat uit naar alle mensen die getroffen zijn door dit conflict, en ik bid voor een toekomst waarin vrede uiteindelijk zal zegevieren. Met liefde en hoop,

Israel tells civilians to leave Gaza City as military amasses tanks Israel's military on Friday called for all civilians of Gaza City, more than 1 million people, to relocate south within 24 hours, as it amassed tanks ahead of an expected ground invasion after a devastating attack by the militant group Hamas. "Now is a time for war," Defence Minister Yoav Gallant said on Thursday as Israeli warplanes continued pounding Gaza in retaliation for the weekend attacks by Hamas militants that killed more than 1,300 Israelis, mostly civilians. The Israeli military said it would operate "significantly" in Gaza City in coming days and civilians should only return when advised. More than 1,500 Palestinians have already been killed in retaliatory attacks. "Civilians of Gaza City, evacuate south for your own safety and the safety of your families and distance yourself from Hamas terrorists who are using you as human shields," the military said. "Hamas terrorists are hiding in Gaza City inside tunnels underneath houses and inside buildings populated with innocent Gazan civilians." A Hamas official urged citizens not to fall for what it called "fake propaganda". Its military wing later said that 13 among scores of people it captured from Israel had been killed in the latest Israeli air strikes. The Palestinian envoy to Japan accused the Israelis of seeking to completely destroy Gaza while the United Nations said it considered it impossible for such a movement of people to take place "without devastating humanitarian consequences". Israel's ambassador to the U.N., Gilad Erdan, described the U.N. response to Israel's early warning to the residents of Gaza as "shameful". Israel has vowed to annihilate the Hamas militant group which led Saturday's attacks and said Hamas tunnels, military compounds, senior operatives' residences and weapons storage warehouses were among 750 military targets struck overnight. A ground invasion of the narrow and densely populated Gaza Strip, home to 2.3 million people, poses serious risk, with Hamas threatening to kill its hostages. Hours after the Israeli evacuation call, there were no signs people were leaving Gaza City, where dozens gathered at the al-Shifa Hospital, vowing to stay put. Pro-Palestinian protests were expected around the world and the United States and regional leaders planned meetings amid fears that conflict could spread. The U.N. humanitarian office (OCHA) said more than 400,000 people had fled their homes in Gaza and 23 aid workers had been killed. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) said generators at hospitals in Gaza could run out of fuel within hours and the U.N. World Food Programme (WFP) warned food and fresh water were running dangerously low. "The human misery caused by this escalation is abhorrent, and I implore the sides to reduce the suffering of civilians," ICRC regional director Fabrizio Carboni said. The U.N. Palestinian refugee agency (UNRWA) said it had moved its central operations centre and international staff to Gaza's south and urged Israel to spare its shelters. Source: Reuters PICTURED: Israeli artillery fires near Israel's border with the Gaza Strip, in southern Israel, October 13, 2023. Photo: REUTERS/Violeta Santos Moura Acquire Licensing Rights

Secretary Blinken‚Äôs Meeting with Jordanian King Abdullah II Readout - Office of the Spokesperson, October 13, 2023 - Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met today in Amman with His Majesty King Abdullah II of Jordan to discuss the horrific Hamas terrorist attacks on Israel and efforts to secure the release of all hostages and prevent the conflict from widening. The Secretary underscored that Hamas does not stand for the Palestinian people‚Äôs right to dignity and self-determination and discussed ways to address the humanitarian needs of civilians in Gaza while Israel conducts legitimate security operations to defend itself from terrorism. The Secretary reaffirmed the strength of the bilateral partnership and the U.S. commitment to Jordan‚Äôs security and economic prosperity, and expressed enduring U.S. appreciation for Jordan‚Äôs special role in Jerusalem and as a force for stability in the region. 90 former rebels receive livelihood grants from DSWD Kidapawan City, Cotabato Province - "Ating isipin na hindi na tayo matatawag na FR or former rebels, tayo na po ay magiging partners. Partners tungo sa kapayapaan" These are the words of one of the 90 former rebels who received a P20,000 livelihood settlement grant from DSWD through the Sustainable Livelihood Program in Cotabato Province on October 12, 2023 This grant can be used as seed capital to start new or enhance existing micro-enterprises or purchase the necessary inputs and starter kits for identified micro-enterprises. In his message, Loreto Jr. V. Cabaya, the Director of DSWD XII, emphasized that this provision aims to institutionalize the Whole-of-Nation approach, encouraging a unified national effort to support the country's peace goals in conflict-affected areas and vulnerable communities through collective action. Governor Emmylou "Lala" Tali√±o-Mendoza was also present to encourage the former rebels to cooperate with the government. "Kung nais ninyong patuloy na suportahan kayo ng gobyerno, tulungan ninyo kami na tiyakin na ang mga nasa pamumuno ay hindi konektado sa mga rebeldeng grupo. Magtulungan tayo sa labang ito." Congresswoman Ma. Alana Samantha Tali√±o-Santos, the 3rd district representative of Cotabato, who graced the event, said, "Maraming salamat po sa pagbabalik loob, dahil dito binalik niyo rin po ang tiwala at pagmamahal niyo sa Cotabato." Also present at the event were other partners of DSWD who provided assistance, including the DILG, 39th Infantry Battalion, 72nd Infantry Battalion, 90th Infantry Battalion, and other government officials of Cotabato province. These former rebels were formerly members of CPP-NPA-NDF and their families, Militia ng Bayan and their families, and individuals and families in conflict-affected and vulnerable communities. #BawatBuhayMahalagaSaDSWD #SustainableLivelihoodProgram

We denounce the outbreak of war between Hamas and Israel and call for an immediate cessation of hostilities and a negotiated settlement of the crisis before it grows and engulfs the region. Posted on October 13, 2023 We are outraged by the attacks launched by Hamas, and the disproportionate response of a declaration of war from Israel. Both have resulted in an immense loss of civilian lives and untold suffering, disproportionately affecting women, children and marginalized groups. We call for the protection of all civilians, the opening of a humanitarian corridor to Gaza, for international law and human rights to be upheld, and women‚Äôs voices to be heard. The context and root causes of the escalating violence must be acknowledged, including the long-standing illegal and inhumane occupation of Palestinian territories and its devastating consequences on the Palestinian people, including displacement, restricted access to basic services, and erosion of human rights. We stand in solidarity with all people affected by the escalating violence. The parties to the conflict, regional actors and the international community have a duty to uphold international law and protect human rights. We issue the following calls to them: 1. Civilians must be protected. Civilians have borne the brunt of the occupation, as well as the violent confrontations between Hamas and Israel. Hamas has targeted and taken civilians hostage, including children. The inhabitants of Gaza currently face a siege. It is a cornerstone of international humanitarian law that civilians must under no circumstances be targeted, and all parties have the utmost duty to protect civilian lives. Therefore: * At this critical time, the international community must continue to call for an end to all hostilities, and the implementation of a ceasefire. * All humanitarian aid to the Palestinian people must be restored, a humanitarian corridor for the transportation of aid and safe passage for civilians must be established and protected. * Governments of the USA, France, Germany, the UK and others, who have expressed unequivocal support for Israel, must make this support conditional on protection of civilians in the occupied Palestinian territories, including provision of basic supplies being immediately returned and the siege lifted. 2. Human rights and international law must be upheld. Deprivation of human rights and basic needs constitutes a war crime. The suspension of power, water, food, and fuel to Gaza by the Israeli authorities amounts to unlawful collective punishment, is unacceptable and disproportionately affects women and children, increasing risk to their physical safety. The taking of hostages by Hamas is unequivocally illicit. Therefore: * The international community must push for the application and implementation of international agreements and laws, including the Geneva Conventions, and all relevant UN General Assembly resolutions, in particular, UNGA resolution 3236, which explicitly recognizes the right to self-determination of the Palestinian people. * The international community must push for the immediate release of all hostages and captives. * The international community must strongly condemn and hold accountable states which fuel militarism including those who fund and arm Hamas and other militant groups, notably Iran. * The International Criminal Court and other relevant bodies should conduct a complete inquiry into violations and war crimes that were committed. 3. Women‚Äôs voices must be heard and women‚Äôs rights protected. War and conflict disproportionately affect women, yet women‚Äôs voices are often overlooked and excluded. The Israeli occupation and the Gaza siege have specific gendered impacts that obstruct women's access to basic human rights, social services, and political life, and increase their susceptibility and exposure to gender-based violence. Therefore: * Responses to the escalating conflict must recognize and take into consideration the disproportionate gendered (truncated)

Israel tells more than 1 million Gazans to relocate within 24 hours Israel's military has called for the immediate relocation of over a million Gaza City residents to the south, in anticipation of a potential ground invasion. This strategic move comes on the heels of a harrowing attack by the militant faction Hamas. The United Nations has voiced grave concerns regarding the feasibility of such a mass evacuation, especially given the dire conditions in Gaza. With dwindling power supplies, and food and water shortages exacerbated by a week of retaliatory air strikes and a full Israeli blockade, the humanitarian situation is nearing a critical point. The international community is on high alert, with top U.S. officials rushing for emergency talks in Israel. The geopolitical ripples of this conflict have reached as far as Iran, which has issued warnings of potential retaliatory actions from its allies, including Hamas and Hezbollah. Pro-Palestinian protests are gaining momentum globally, sparking fears within some Jewish communities of potential retaliatory attacks, especially in light of the recent assault by Hamas inside Israel that claimed over 1,300 lives, predominantly civilians. In a show of defiance against the Israeli directive, Muntadhar Kareem, a 25-year-old teacher from Baghdad, rallied with thousands, declaring, "We are ready to join the fight and rid the Palestinians of the Israeli atrocities." The Israeli military's announcement was punctuated by a stern warning to Gaza City's civilians, cautioning them against the potential human shield tactics employed by Hamas militants. Despite these warnings, the morning saw little movement from the city's residents, with many dismissing the evacuation call as "fake propaganda." Palestinian representatives abroad are sounding alarms over what they perceive as Israel's intent to obliterate Gaza. The enclave, housing over 1.5 million Palestinians, many of whom are descendants of refugees from Israel's 1948 inception, has already seen a death toll surpassing 1,500 in the current conflict. Israel remains resolute in its stance, citing the recent gruesome attack on its civilians as a justifiable pretext for its aggressive measures against Hamas. The nation's military reported overnight strikes on over 750 militant targets, including weapons caches and tunnels. As diplomatic efforts gain momentum, with U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and other global leaders converging on the region, the situation remains precariously balanced. Blinken condemned the violence, urging restraint while reiterating U.S. support for Israel. Security concerns are prompting swift actions worldwide, with countries like the U.S. and Japan offering evacuation flights for their nationals in Israel. Jewish institutions in various cities have heightened security measures in response to potential threats. The conflict, now shining a spotlight on the long-standing grievances of Gazans who have endured economic hardships and recurrent Israeli strikes, has reignited discussions on the broader Palestinian struggle. The coming days will be pivotal in determining the course of this conflict, with diplomatic interventions and ground realities converging in a volatile mix.

ùóßùóµùó≤ ùóôùó∂ùòÉùó≤ ùóñ‚ÄôùòÄ ùóºùó≥ ùóòùó≥ùó≥ùó≤ùó∞ùòÅùó∂ùòÉùó≤ ùóüùó≤ùóÆùó±ùó≤ùóøùòÄùóµùó∂ùóΩ Gaining leadership skills isn‚Äôt easy, and it‚Äôs fair to say that some people find taking the lead easier than others. But no matter what your background, experience or character, everyone has the potential to become a great leader provided they take the right steps to build confidence and hone their skills. That includes building the TOP 5 C's of effective leadership. In this guid I'm going to carefully walk you through this five Cs that will enable you to become not just and effective but one that will drive results in your organization, industry or workplace. Let's take a look. 1.ùóñùóºùó∫ùó∫ùòÇùóªùó∂ùó∞ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª Being a good leader requires excellent communication skills, this means possessing the ability to listen to people as well as the ability to share ideas. These skills also relate to the capacity to negotiate when necessary and manage issues of conflict. To become a great leader, you must be able to communicate with people in a variety of situations; and not only communicate but communicate well. Effective leaders share ideas with their team as well as listen to what their teams have to say, aware of the importance of building relationships with colleagues. They create a bond of trust, showing interest in their team‚Äôs professional and personal goals. 2.ùóñùóºùóªùó≥ùó∂ùó±ùó≤ùóªùó∞ùó≤ To be an effective leader, you will need to display confidence. You can demonstrate this trait through both the way you conduct yourself and your actions. It‚Äôs important to be aware that being confident does not mean being brash and pushy. Rather, you can display it through more subtle actions, like being decisive and having faith in your abilities. Faith. Effective leaders have faith in themselves, believing in their abilities. When people believe in themselves, those surrounding will also believe it. A leader is someone who uses their best judgment and is confident when making decisions. 3.ùóñùóºùó∫ùó∫ùó∂ùòÅùó∫ùó≤ùóªùòÅ Demonstrating commitment to the cause or organisation you are working for will create goodwill and overall positive outcomes. Showing commitment to those around you also contributes to good relationships and, in turn, can inspire similar commitment at every level of the organisation. Commitment is among the most difficult ‚ÄúC‚Äôs‚Äù to embody as a leader. It relies on a principled, resolute approach, wherein all avenues have been explored and all ideas investigated. It also requires a good degree of self-confidence, and a belief that your approach is best for the outcome of the wider business or project of the organization. 4.ùóñùóøùó≤ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùòÉùó∂ùòÅùòÜ The best leaders are often those who can think in a creative, innovative way. If you find it hard to look at situations from different perspectives, you will find it more of a challenge to lead since leaders need to be able to look at the big picture. Being creative will also help when it comes to problem-solving and making decisions. Leaders must be quick on their toes, able to adapt to a variety of situations. A leader can make magic happen by thinking outside of the box. Of course, not everyone is naturally gifted with creativity‚Ä¶ The good news is that it is possible to enhance creativity by training the way you think. 5.ùóñùóÆùóøùó≤ Exceptional leaders are empathetic, caring for their people, not just the work they do. People want to feel valued. They want meaningful connection at work. As a leader make sure you ask them about their life. WhaHow is their family doing? Did they find time to relax on them. Work isn‚Äôt everything, and your people will develop loyalty only when you care about them as people, not as productivity generators. In conclusion Effective leaders are wise, nurturing, and take fate into their own hands. They mentor those around them and can bring the wildest dreams to fruition. Some people are natural-born leaders, while others don‚Äôt have that luxury. Regardless of where you fall on the spectrum, everyone has room to improve their leadership skills and can become an effective leader with enough faith and determination. We are here to help you build and nurture your leadership skills. Follow me for more leadership development, personal growth, and high-performance business management! CLICK BELOW FOR VIDEO: https://youtu.be/f_RRt6B-dxY:=:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f_RRt6B-dxY The feature-length documentary commemorates 80 years since the legendary Easy Company were stationed in Aldbourne, Wiltshire, England ahead of D-Day. The eagerly anticipated documentary sees Time Team working with Operation Nightingale in an English village linked to the United States Army‚Äôs most famous regiment of the Second World War ‚Äì the legendary ‚ÄòBand of Brothers‚Äô. Aldbourne, Wiltshire, was once home to the iconic Easy Company of the US 101st Airborne Division. The paratroopers were stationed here in 1943, before engaging in pivotal actions of World War II ‚Äì among them Operation Overlord, Operation Market Garden and the Battle of the Bulge. 80 years later, in May 2023, Time Team visited to explore the traces they left behind through an archaeological investigation. The excavation was spearheaded by Operation Nightingale, a Ministry of Defence initiative that uses archaeology to support the recovery of servicemen and women returning from conflict. Reached for comments by this Swaziland News, Jabu Shiba, the Swaziland Union of Financial Institutions and Allied Workers Union(SUFIAWU) Secretary General(SG) confirmed that, there would be a strike action by FNB employees as negotiations were not successful. ‚ÄúWe can confirm that there would be a strike action to commence on the 20th October 2023, tinkhulumo tehlulekile lokusho kutsi mhlaka twenty(20) kucala umsebenti Nkhosi‚Äù, said the SUFIAWU Secretary General. But in the email seen by this Swaziland News,Futhie Magagula, the FNB Eswatini Manager Employee Relations stated categorically clear that, the bank was committed to finding a resolution without the need for the substantial cost to both affected employees and the Bank that,disruption and avoidable conflict create. ‚ÄúThe Bank is committed to finding resolution without the need for the substantial cost to both affected employees and the Bank that disruption and avoidable conflict create. The pending matters will be resolved and will be resolved within reasonable and sustainable means, and it is the intention of the Bank that post the resolution of these matters, employee-employer engagement be sustained to mitigate misinformation and misunderstanding risk‚Äù, reads the email in part. Reached for comments by this publication,Futhie Magagula, the FNB Manager Employees Relations said, the email was directed to Bank employees hence,she can‚Äôt comment. ‚ÄúGood Day Nkhosi.We respect communications between the Bank and its employees and we would like to protect the integrity of internal conversations,‚Äù said the FNB Manager Employees Relations. http://www.swazilandnews.co.za/fundza.php?nguyiphi=5352

From: I‚Äôm Going to War for Israel. Palestinians Are Not My Enemy. By Nir Avishai Cohen (Mr. Cohen, a major in the reserves of the Israel Defense Forces, is the author of the book ‚ÄúLove Israel, Support Palestine.‚Äù) https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/13/opinion/israel-military-war.html I was in Austin, Texas, for work on Saturday when I received a call from my commander in the Israel Defense Forces to return to Israel and head to the front line. I didn‚Äôt hesitate. I knew that the citizens of my country were in real danger. My duty first and foremost is to join the fight against those who unleashed a massacre on my people. I boarded the first flight I found out of Austin to head home to join the I.D.F. reserves, where I serve as a brigade operations command officer. During my long flight to Israel, my mind couldn‚Äôt rest. I was trying to write down my feelings and thoughts about everything happening ‚Äî and everything that‚Äôs about to happen ‚Äî in my beloved country. Little by little, the dimensions of the horrors of the most brutal attack that Israelis have experienced since the establishment of the state were being revealed. Hundreds of Hamas terrorists slaughtered more than 1,200 people, including women, children and older people. About 150 citizens and soldiers have been taken captive. There‚Äôs nothing in the world that can justify the murder of hundreds of innocent people. But I‚Äôd like to say one thing clearly, before I go to battle: There‚Äôs no such thing as ‚Äúunavoidable.‚Äù This war could have been avoided, and no one did enough to prevent it. Israel did not do enough to make peace; we just conquered the Palestinian territories in the West Bank, expanded the illegal settlements and imposed a long-term siege on the Gaza Strip. For 56 years Israel has been subjecting Palestinians to oppressive military rule. In my book ‚ÄúLove Israel, Support Palestine,‚Äù I wrote: ‚ÄúIsraeli society has to ask itself very important questions about where and why the blood of its sons and daughters was spilled. A Messianic religious minority has dragged us into a muddy swamp, and we are following them as if it were the Piper from Hamelin.‚Äù When I wrote these words last year, I didn‚Äôt realize how deep in the mud we were, and how much more blood could be shed in so little time. I am now going to defend my country against enemies who want to kill my people. Our enemies are the deadly terrorist organizations that are being controlled by Islamic extremists. Palestinians aren‚Äôt the enemy. The millions of Palestinians who live right here next to us, between the Mediterranean Sea and Jordan, are not our enemy. Just like the majority of Israelis want to live a calm, peaceful and dignified life, so do Palestinians. Israelis and Palestinians alike have been in the grip of a religious minority for decades. On both sides, the intractable positions of a small group have dragged us into violence. It doesn‚Äôt matter who is more cruel, or more ruthless. The ideology of both have fueled this conflict, leading to the death of too many innocent civilians. As a major in the reserves, it is important to me to make it clear that in this already unstoppable new war, we cannot allow the massacre of innocent Israelis to result in the massacre of innocent Palestinians. Israel must remember that there are more than two million people living in the Gaza Strip. The vast majority of them are innocent. Israel must do everything in its power to avoid killing innocent people, and focus on destroying the militant army of Hamas. This war, like others before it, will end sooner or later. I am not sure I will come back from it alive, but I do know that a minute after the war is over, both Israelis and Palestinians will have to reckon with the leaders who led them to this moment. We must wake up and not let the extremists rule. Palestinians and Israelis must denounce the extremists who are driven by religious fanaticism. The Israelis will have to oust National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich and their far-right circle from power, and the Palestinians will have to oust the leadership of Hamas. I try to look for shreds of hope. The Yom Kippur War, the most difficult war that Israel had known until this week, started by surprise in 1973. After a peace agreement between Israel and Egypt was finally signed in 1979, the border with Egypt ‚Äî one that was once the site of the dead and wounded ‚Äî became a border of peace. Israelis must realize that there is no greater security asset than peace. The strongest army cannot protect the country the way peace does. This current war proves it once again. Israel has followed the path of war for too long. At the end, after all of the dead Israelis and Palestinians are buried, after we have finished washing away the rivers of blood, the people who share a home in this land will have to understand that there is no other choice but to follow the path of peace. That is where true victory lies.

"Any loss of innocent life is tragic, but sometimes it is lawful. Both things can be true. And as Israel exercises its right to defend its very existence, they very likely will be. As Israel does just what it needs to do, may God protect the innocent ‚Äî because we know Hamas will not."

text: Human Rights Watch has unequivocally confirmed the use of white phosphorus by Israeli forces during military operations in Lebanon and Gaza on October 10 and 11, 2023. Verified through video evidence and witness accounts, the footage portrays numerous artillery-fired white phosphorus airbursts, observed over the Gaza City port and two rural locations along the Israel-Lebanon border. White phosphorus, known for its dual use as a smokescreen or a weapon, carries significant risks for civilians due to the severe burns it inflicts and its enduring, detrimental impact on survivors. Its deployment in densely populated regions of Gaza represents a blatant violation of international humanitarian law, mandating conflict parties to take all possible precautions to prevent harm to civilians. Moreover, this distressing revelation underscores the imperative to critically review the adequacy and standing of Protocol III of the Convention on Conventional Weapons (CCW), the sole international legislation dedicated to regulating incendiary weapons. Source: Human Rights Watch #news #israel #gaza #lebanon #hrw #humanrightswatch

THINGS YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT MARRIAGE üëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëáüëá 1. Communication is Key: Open and honest communication is the foundation of a healthy marriage. It's essential to discuss your feelings, expectations, and concerns with your spouse. 2. Expectations and Compromise: Discuss and manage each other's expectations. Compromise is necessary to find middle ground in disagreements. 3. Trust and Honesty: Trust is vital in a marriage. Being honest and transparent with your partner builds and maintains trust. 4. Emotional Support: Marriage is about being each other's emotional support system. Be there for your spouse in times of joy and sorrow. 5. Quality Time: Spend quality time together to strengthen your bond. Date nights and shared activities are essential. 6. Finances: Openly discuss finances, including budgeting, saving, and long-term financial goals. 7. Conflict Resolution: Learn healthy ways to resolve conflicts without resorting to destructive arguments. Couples counseling can help if needed. 8. Intimacy: Physical and emotional intimacy are crucial aspects of a successful marriage. Keep the spark alive in your relationship. 9. Individuality: While you're a couple, it's important to maintain your individuality and personal interests. 10. In-Law Relationships: Navigating relationships with in-laws can be challenging, so clear boundaries and communication are essential. 11. Changing Roles: Be prepared for roles and responsibilities to evolve over time, especially if you have children. 12. Patience and Forgiveness: Marriage is a journey, and there will be ups and downs. Practice patience and forgiveness to overcome challenges. 13. Shared Goals: Identify common goals and work together to achieve them. This can help strengthen your partnership. 14. Legal and Financial Considerations: Understand the legal aspects of marriage, such as property rights, inheritance, and potential tax implications. The past week has shown humanity at its worst: A horrific terrorist attack left at least 1,300 Israelis dead, among them peace activists and even innocent children. The fates of many more kidnapped civilians still lie in the balance. Meanwhile, statements from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu suggest retaliation against Palestinians in Gaza will be swift and merciless. More than 1,500 Gazans are already dead, and 338,000 others have been displaced. In moments of turmoil such as this, some believe it is the responsibility of a newspaper of record like The Onion to delve fully into the nuances of a complex and multifaceted conflict that stretches back not just decades but centuries. These people are wrong.‚Å†
‚Å†
Instead, this editorial board wishes to take this opportunity to declare its full and unequivocal support for Israel because, frankly, it seems like you get in way less trouble for that.‚Å†
‚Å†
Let us be clear: This is a fraught moment, and one that has polarized not only Americans but people all over the world. It demands incredible sensitivity and strict adherence to journalistic standards of objectivity, and simply put, that is something we aren‚Äôt willing to do. Rather, we‚Äôre just going to say The Onion expresses its steadfast solidarity with Israel and leave it at that.‚Å†
‚Å†

At a time when Indian media is more concerned about Israel-Palestine conflict than Manipur violence, the Manipur government has banned the circulation of videos and photos of violence that hit the northeast state in May.

The directive comes just days after a video, purportedly showing a man being burnt, had surfaced on social media, triggering fresh outrage and condemnation. The police had said that the video was related to the May 4 strip-parade case which the CBI is probing.

Grappling with frequent tension following sharing of videos and photographs, the govt said its a "positive step" towards bringing normalcy to the conflict-hit state.

An order by the Governor issued through the state Home Department on Wednesday stated that the state government took circulating images of violent activities ‚Äúvery seriously and with utmost sensitivity.‚Äù It stated that images of activities such as inflicting bodily harm and damage to public or private property are likely to facilitate the mobilisation of ‚Äúmobs of agitators and demonstrators,‚Äù aggravating the law and order situation in the state. 

 It went on to say that anyone in possession of such images should approach the nearest Superintendent of Police and submit them for legal action, but if they are found to be circulating such images through social media, they shall be booked and prosecuted ‚Äúunder relevant provision of the law of land.‚Äù It also stated that those found ‚Äúmisusing technology for inciting violence/hatred‚Äù will be dealt with under provisions of the IT Act and the IPC.

Mobile internet services were again suspended in the state till October 16.

Human Rights Watch (HRW) has alleged that Israel used white phosphorus in its recent military strikes in Gaza and along the Israel-Lebanon border.

On October 10th and 11th, HRW researchers claimed to have verified the use of white phosphorus, highlighting videos that reportedly depict "multiple airbursts of artillery-fired white phosphorus" both over Gaza's port and in areas close to the Israel-Lebanon boundary. 

Another view:
Lt. Col. Peter Lerner, an IDF spokesperson, said, "The current accusation made against the IDF regarding the use of white phosphorus in Gaza is unequivocally false."

The substance, which can cause significant burns and ignite structures, has been a point of contention among human rights advocates, even though it's not typically labeled a chemical weapon. HRW's Middle East and North Africa director, Lama Fakih, expressed concerns, noting that "any time that white phosphorus is used in crowded civilian areas, it poses a high risk of excruciating burns and lifelong suffering."

Latest death toll numbers:
IDF reports: 1,300 dead, 3,000 wounded
Gaza Ministry of Health: 1,799 dead, 7,388 wounded.

Almost 70 percent of registered voters side with Israelis over Palestinians, although support for Palestine increases among younger generations, according to a portion of a Fox News poll conducted during and after Hamas‚Äôs terrorist attacks on Israel last weekend. 

The poll, published Wednesday, asked voters, ‚ÄúIn the Middle East conflict, do you side more with the Israelis or more with the Palestinians?‚Äù

The results show that 68 percent of Americans support Israelis versus just 18 percent who support Palestinians. Majorities in both major political parties back Israel, but support among Republicans is more potent than Democrats. 

Per the poll, jointly conducted by Beacon Research and Shaw & Company Research, 59 percent of Democrats support Israel, as do 79 percent of Republicans. Conversely, one in four Democrats back Palestine, while just over one in ten Republicans side with Palestine. 

Support for Israel has jumped nine percentage points since a May 2021 Fox News poll. Back then, 59 percent of Americans sided with Israelis versus 24 percent who backed Palestinians. This marks a fifteen-point swing in public opinion in two-and-a-half years.

‚ÄúThe main reason for the overall increase in support for Israel is Democrats have dramatically changed their position,‚Äù Republican pollster Daron Shaw told Fox News. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve moved from +7 Israel to +34, which undoubtedly reflects revulsion over the nature of the attacks.‚Äù

A trend evident among age demographics in the current poll shows younger Americans are more inclined to support Palestine than their older counterparts. For instance, among survey respondents under 35, 49 percent back Israel, whereas 34 percent moreso side with Palestine. 

A majority of 55 percent of those 44 and younger side with Israelis. Less than one in three respondents in the demographic says they back Palestinians. 

Among those 45 and older, support for Israel grows dramatically to 76 percent, while support for Palestine shrinks to 9 percent.

The sample included 1,007 registered voters who were surveyed between October 7-9. The margin of error registers at plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.

French authorities have banned all pro-Palestine demonstrations, citing "increased antisemitic incidents" within the country. This comes as France is home to Europe's most substantial Jewish community of around 500,000 and one of its largest Muslim populations, estimated at 5 million. 

Since the conflict broke out between Israel and Hamas, French Interior Minister G√©rald Darmanin informed a local radio station that the country had witnessed 100 antisemitic incidents ranging from graffiti depicting swastikas and messages like "death to Jews" to more severe cases where individuals were apprehended trying to bring knives into educational institutions and places of worship. In light of these events, Darmanin announced plans to enhance security around Jewish landmarks such as schools and synagogues. He also announced that foreigners violating the protest ban would face "systematic" expulsion from the country. 

Despite the ban on pro-Palestinian protests, people continue to show up in sizable numbers to protest, prompting police intervention with tear gas and water cannons to end the protests. 

Protestors echoed sentiments like "Israel murderer" and "Macron accomplice," alluding to Macron's denunciation of Hamas and his backing of Israel. 

France's death toll:

Amid the ongoing conflict and the strained geopolitics of the Middle East, I'm reminded of my experiences serving in various disaster-stricken and war-torn regions. One crucial lesson I've learned is that when the dust settles, the true victims are often innocent people, regardless of which side they were on. The human suffering, the loss, the pain‚Äîthey don't discriminate.

It's not about taking sides; it's about recognizing our shared humanity. I've seen the tears, the anguish, and the resilience of people who yearn for peace and a chance at a better life. Regardless of where we come from, our dreams, our hopes, and our families are interconnected by our common desire for a safer, more peaceful world.

It's not about politics; it's about compassion, kindness, and the pursuit of a better future. Together, we can stand for unity, for healing, and for a brighter tomorrow. üïäÔ∏èü§ù

Cardinal Pietro Parolin, the Vatican‚Äôs secretary of state, condemned Hamas‚Äô Saturday terrorist attacks against Israel, called for peace in the Holy Land, and said the Vatican is ready to help mediate a peace agreement, in an interview published by Vatican News Friday.‚Å£
‚Å£
Parolin told Vatican News that the Hamas attacks were ‚Äúinhuman,‚Äù and that the Holy See expresses ‚Äúcomplete and firm condemnation.‚Äù ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúWe express our solidarity with the affected families, the vast majority of whom are Jewish,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe pray for them, for those still in shock, for the wounded.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
He also expressed the Vatican‚Äôs concern for the civilians in Gaza and the ‚Äúmen, women, children, and the elderly held hostage.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
It is necessary,‚Äù Parolin said, ‚Äúto regain a sense of reason, abandon the blind logic of hatred, and reject violence as a solution. It is the right of those who are attacked to defend themselves, but even legitimate defense must respect the parameter of proportionality.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
Parolin said that the Vatican‚Äôs chief concern amid the conflict is ‚Äúthe release of Israeli hostages and the protection of innocent lives in Gaza.‚Äù ‚Å£
‚Å£
He posited that these two concerns are a matter of ‚Äújustice.‚Äù ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúIt is just ‚Äî indeed, essential ‚Äî that in this conflict, as in any other, humanitarian law be fully respected,‚Äù he said. ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúIt is just for the hostages to be returned immediately, even those held by Hamas since previous conflicts,‚Äù Parolin said, adding that it is also ‚Äújust that in Israel's legitimate defense, the lives of Palestinian civilians living in Gaza should not be endangered.‚Äù ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúI do not know how much room for dialogue there can be between Israel and the Hamas militia,‚Äù Parolin said. ‚ÄúBut if there is ‚Äî and we hope there is ‚Äî it should be pursued immediately and without delay.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
He said that the Holy See is ‚Äúready for any necessary mediation.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúThe greatest possible justice in the Holy Land,‚Äù Parolin claimed, ‚Äúis the two-state solution, which would allow Palestinians and Israelis to live side by side in peace and security, meeting the aspirations of the majority.‚Äù‚Å£

Amid the ongoing war between Israel and Hamas in the Gaza Strip, the Delhi Police has sounded a security alert in the national capital.

The Delhi Police has also beefed up security around the Israeli embassy and Chabad House located in Chandni Chowk in central Delhi in the wake of the Israel-Hamas conflict, an official said.

The officer added that authorities have directed to increase the vigil around both installations.

"Security has been also beefed up at the Chabad House (Jewish prayer house) and other parts of Delhi as well. Security arrangements have been made wherever there are Jewish establishments," the officer said.

On Thursday, the Delhi Police also carried out a late-night patrol around the Jama Masjid in the walled city area.

Video clips shared on social media showed a squad of bike-borne police personnel patrolling the Jama Masjid area, followed by another group of policemen on foot patrol.

According to officials, the patrolling is part of an "institutionalised mechanism" conducted by Delhi Police from time to time.

Delhi Police said the exercise was conducted in the wake of certain "inputs" they received amid the ongoing Israeli offensive in Gaza.

Delhi Police has also urged Muslim community members to offer namaz at mosques in their areas of residence and not venture elsewhere to offer prayers.

While the nature of the current "inputs" the Delhi Police have received is unknown, it should be noted that Israeli and Jewish establishments in India have been targeted by terrorists in the past.

Human Rights Watch has determined based on verified video and witness accounts that Israeli forces used white phosphorus in military operations in Lebanon and Gaza on October 10 and 11, 2023, respectively. The videos show multiple airbursts of artillery-fired white phosphorus over the Gaza City port and two rural locations along the Israel-Lebanon border.

White phosphorus, which can be used as a smokescreen or a weapon, has the potential to cause civilian harm due to the severe burns it causes and its lingering long-term effects on survivors. Its use in densely populated areas of Gaza violates the requirement under international humanitarian law that parties to the conflict take all feasible precautions to avoid civilian injury and loss of life. It also highlights the need to reexamine the status and adequacy of Protocol III of the Convention on Conventional Weapons (CCW), currently the only international law dedicated to governing incendiary weapons.

‚ûñ‚ûñ‚ûñ
U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned a small group of U.S. lawmakers during a phone call on October 3, 2023, that his department is tracking the possibility that Azerbaijan could soon invade Armenia, reports POLITICO citing two people familiar with the conversation.

During the call, U.S. lawmakers pressed Blinken on possible measures against Aliyev in response to Azerbaijan‚Äôs attack on Artsakh (Nagorno-Karabakh) in September, said the people who were granted anonymity to discuss the sensitive call.

Blinken responded that the State Department was looking at avenues to hold Azerbaijan accountable & isn‚Äôt planning to renew a long-standing waiver that allows the U.S. to provide military assistance to Baku. He said the State Dept. saw a possibility that Azerbaijan would invade southern Armenia in the coming weeks.

Azerbaijan‚Äôs President Ilham Aliyev has been calling on Armenia to open a ‚Äúcorridor‚Äù along its southern border, linking mainland Azerbaijan to its Nakhichevan exclave that borders Turkey & Iran. The ‚Äúcorridor‚Äù would cut through Armenia‚Äôs southern Syunik region to enable road traffic to bypass Iran.

Aliyev has threatened to solve the issue ‚Äúby force‚Äù & said, ‚ÄúWe will be implementing the Zangezur Corridor, whether Armenia wants it or not.‚Äù

Still, Blinken expressed confidence about ongoing diplomatic talks between Armenia & Azerbaijan to the Democratic lawmakers, including Reps‚ÄîNancy Pelosi & Anna Eshoo of California, & Frank Pallone of New Jersey.

In a statement, the State Dept. declined to comment on the call but emphasized the department‚Äôs commitment to ‚ÄúArmenia‚Äôs sovereignty & territorial integrity‚Äù & resolving conflict through ‚Äúdirect talks.‚Äù

Every year since 2002, the U.S. has issued the waiver, allowing it to sidestep a provision of the Freedom Support Act that bars the U.S. from providing military assistance to Azerbaijan in light of its ongoing territorial disputes with Armenia. The waiver lapsed in June & the State Dept. had previously provided no explanation as to why it hadn‚Äôt yet requested a renewal.

Exclusive: On video obtained by Axios, former President George W. Bush - in his first comments about the attack on Israel - warned that the expected Israeli ground offensive in Gaza is "going to be ugly for a while."

Why it matters: Bush, calling himself "kind of a hardliner," said out loud what other leaders won't - that he believes there'll be a temptation for the public to buckle and think peace is an option.

Flashback: Bush endorsed Israel Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's disengagement from Gaza in 2005 as a positive step toward peace.

Bush also supported the 2006 Palestinian elections, which Hamas won before seizing control of the Gaza Strip in 2007 - setting the conditions for many of the conflict's current dynamics.

Over the weekend, the George W. Bush Institute, which speaks for the former president, issued a statement strongly condemning "the heinous terrorist attacks on Israel."

Human Rights Watch has confirmed the use of white phosphorus by Israeli forces during military operations in Lebanon and Gaza on October 10 and 11, 2023. Verified through video evidence and witness accounts, the footage portrays numerous artillery-fired white phosphorus airbursts, observed over the Gaza City port and two rural locations along the Israel-Lebanon border.

White phosphorus, known for its dual use as a smokescreen or a weapon, carries significant risks for civilians due to the severe burns it inflicts and its enduring, detrimental impact on survivors. Its deployment in densely populated regions of Gaza represents a blatant violation of international humanitarian law, mandating conflict parties to take all possible precautions to prevent harm to civilians. Moreover, this distressing revelation underscores the imperative to critically review the adequacy and standing of Protocol III of the Convention on Conventional Weapons (CCW), the sole international legislation dedicated to regulating incendiary weapons.

Source: Human Rights Watch

Israel deployed white phosphorus over Gaza and Lebanon during its conflict with Hamas, said Human Rights Watch on October 12. White phosphorus is known to ignite when it comes in contact with air, leading to intense burning that can extend to cloth, fuel, ammunition, and various combustible materials.

Human Rights Watch, an international non-governmental organization headquartered in New York City said it has verified videos of October 10 and October 11. It videos show ‚Äúmultiple airbursts of artillery-fired white phosphorus over the Gaza City port and two rural locations along the Israel-Lebanon border.‚Äù

The HRW report also states that the use of white phosphorus ‚Äúmagnifies the risk to civilians and violates the international humanitarian law prohibition on putting civilians at unnecessary risk‚Äù. 

What is White Phosphorus?
White phosphorus is a highly reactive and controversial chemical compound which has unique properties that make it both a versatile industrial tool and a source of significant concern. White phosphorus exists as a waxy, translucent substance that can spontaneously ignite when exposed to air, emitting a luminous glow.

This nature of the compound has led to its use in various applications, from military applications like smoke screens to industrial processes such as manufacturing fertilizers. 

Why Is White Phosphorus Dangerous For Human Health?

One of the major concerns is that it can spontaneously ignite upon exposure to air. This property, while useful in industrial applications like military smoke screens, becomes a perilous attribute in warfare. The intense burning it produces upon ignition can lead to severe and potentially life-threatening burns when it comes into contact with human skin. 

In addition to its direct impact, white phosphorus can release toxic fumes when burned. Inhalation of these fumes can cause respiratory distress and damage the respiratory system, leading to long-term health issues. Moreover, the substance‚Äôs ability to adhere to the skin makes decontamination challenging, exacerbating the health risks for those exposed.

Israel's army has said that all the people living in northern Gaza must move to the southern region within the next 24 hours, the United Nations has said. This indicates that a massive ground invasion may be on the cards.

Israel has been bombing the isolated coastal strip in retaliation to Hamas' attacks, which began on October 7. Thousands have died in the escalation of the conflict, that has seen severely polarised reactions from global leaders. The Israeli air force has dropped 6,000 bombs on Gaza since October 7, it has announced on X

Already, the UN has announced that no aid has been able to come in from the outside of the Gaza Strip for its 2.3 million residents. There is a water crisis, no food and no electricity as Israel has blocked access to such essentials in a move that has been called "inhuman, violent and brutal" and a distinct war crime. In addition, the Human Rights Watch has reported that white phosphorus is being used by Israel on the Gaza Strip. It is used for signalling, obscuring, or to set fires but can severely burn people and set structures on fire.

The New York Times has reported that Israeli military officers conveyed the information to the leaders of the U.N. Office of the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs and the Department of Safety and Security in Gaza just before midnight local time on Friday, October 13.

The UN's spokesperson St√©phane Dujarric has told reporters that such a direction would lead to "devastating humanitarian consequences."

Guardian has quoted Dujarric as having also said, "The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation."

The reactive-legal abuse cycle is the downward spiral many abuse victims get caught in when dealing with a narcissistic ex in the family court system.
