The first charter flight carrying 212 Indians from conflict-torn Israel arrived at the Delhi airport on Friday morning. This was part of the government's Operation Ajay. The flight took off from Israel's Ben Gurion Airport on Thursday, amid the country's raging war with the Palestinian militant group Hamas. The Indians departed on a "first-come-first-serve" basis. Union minister Rajeev Chandrasekhar was present at the airport to welcome them. Chandrasekhar greeted them with folded hands, and interacted with students. The union minister reassured the passengers, saying: "India's commitment to the safety of every Indian is unwavering. Prime Minister Modi is determined to protect India's people," he added.

In a heartening development, the first charter flight under 'Operation Ajay' successfully facilitated the return of 212 Indian citizens stranded in Israel due to the ongoing conflict. The flight, organized by the Indian government, landed at Delhi Airport on Friday morning, bringing relief to those affected by the war.

Union Minister Rajiv Chandrashekhar welcomed the passengers with a 'Namaste' gesture, emphasizing the government's commitment to ensuring the safety of its citizens. "Our government will never leave any Indian behind. Our Prime Minister is determined to protect them, bring them back home safely," stated Chandrashekhar. Passengers were chosen on a "first come first serve" basis, and the government bore the entire cost of their return. The evacuation became crucial as Air India had suspended its flights on October 7, leaving many stranded.

Chandrashekhar expressed gratitude to External Affairs Minister Dr. S Jaishankar, the ministry's team, and the Air India flight crew for their efforts in making the evacuation possible. He reassured the returning citizens, saying, "We are grateful...for bringing our children back home safely and soundly and back home to their loved ones." A relieved Indian national, evacuated from the war-battered region, conveyed appreciation for the government's prompt response, stating, "We are very thankful to the Indian government, especially Prime Minister Narendra Modi for bringing us back." Expressing hope for peace, the individual added, "We are hoping for peace as soon as possible so that we can go back to work at the earliest."

The evacuation was conducted under 'Operation Ajay,' and the passengers were selected based on registrations in the Indian embassy's database. Despite the challenges, the Indian embassy's coordination and timely notifications provided a sense of relief to the stranded citizens. Shubham Kumar, a student in Israel, expressed gratitude, saying, "We felt like the embassy of India is connected with us, which was a kind of relief to us. And then we got all the arrangements."

There is a dangerous development in the campaign to hold the fossil fuel industry accountable for damage caused by climate change.

While the war between Israel and Hamas consumes the world's attention, the fossil fuel industry is quietly working to delay and sabotage legal proceedings in the US to hold it accountable for its leading role in creating global warming. There are about 25 legal cases pending in US courts brought by cities and states against the oil majors and the industry lobbying group The American Petroleum Institute.

The fossil fuel industry's latest gambit is to try to dismiss these cases by arguing the industry is not responsible for the massive damage caused by climate change because it had no "duty to warn" the public. Industry lawyers cynically claim oil companies had no "duty to warn" because knowledge of climate change was available decades ago -- even though oil majors like Chevron and Exxon tried to deceive the public by hiding that very information. They did this by suppressing their own internal scientific research pointing to inevitable and drastic climate change, while at the same time paying lobbyists at front groups like the Heartland Institute to create "uncertainty" about the issue in public.

A mastermind of the new industry legal strategy is none other than Ted Boutrous of Gibson Dunn, the same fossil fuel law firm Chevron paid to orchestrate my private corporate prosecution after we helped Indigenous peoples in Ecuador's Amazon win a historic $10 billion pollution judgment. Boutrous also represents the New York Times in its media and First Amendment work ‚Äì a clear conflict of interest for the newspaper which might help explain why it never covered Chevron's orchestration of my illegal 993-day detention in retaliation for winning the Ecuador pollution case. Boutrous himself was intimately involved in the targeting of me and the affected Amazon communities of Ecuador.

You can read details of this latest industry legal gambit in the article available through the link in the bio. üëä

According to sources at POLITICO, Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned a small group of lawmakers last week that his department is tracking the possibility that Azerbaijan could soon invade Armenia, according to two people familiar with the conversation.

The call indicates the depth of concern in the administration about Azerbaijan‚Äôs operations against a breakaway region in the west of the country and the possibility of the conflict spreading, reports POLITICO.

Azerbaijiani President Ilham Aliyev has previously called on Armenia to open a ‚Äúcorridor‚Äù along its southern border, linking mainland Azerbaijan to an exclave that borders Turkey and Iran. Aliyev has threatened to solve the issue ‚Äúby force.‚Äù

In an Oct. 3 phone call, lawmakers pressed Blinken on possible measures against Aliyev in response to his country‚Äôs invasion of the Nagorno-Karabakh region in September, the people said, who were granted anonymity to discuss the sensitive call.

Blinken responded that the State Department was looking at avenues to hold Azerbaijan accountable and isn‚Äôt planning to renew a long-standing waiver that allows the U.S. to provide military assistance to Baku. He added that State saw a possibility that Azerbaijan would invade southern Armenia in the coming weeks.

Still, Blinken expressed confidence about ongoing diplomatic talks between Armenia and Azerbaijan to the Democratic lawmakers, among them Reps. Nancy Pelosi and Anna Eshoo of California, and Frank Pallone of New Jersey.

Two additional people confirmed that a briefing happened on the situation in Azerbaijan, but did not provide details.

‚ú®When there is turbulence in the world, it can be a delicate balance for yoga teachers as we discern the difference between knowing what to say and knowing when to remain silent. Whether the conflict is political, societal, or global, I feel that it is important for us to help hold space for all emotions, opinions, and ways of being.

üíïHere are 11 Ways to Hold Space for Difficult Emotions in Your Yoga Classes from an article I wrote for Yoga Journal. Your role is not to have all the answers for students...

1. Leave your politics at the door.
2. Encourage students to set an intention for their practice.
3. Channel your emotions.
4. Be honest.
5. Practice self-care.
6. Hold space for all your students‚Äô emotions.
7. Do what feels authentic to you‚Ä¶ within reason.
8. Be sensitive to everyone.
9. Bring everyone‚Äôs attention to their breath.
10. Minimize your alignment cues.
11. Remember why you wanted to teach yoga.

At a time when Indian media is more concerned about Israel-Palestine conflict than Manipur violence, the Manipur government has banned the circulation of videos and photos of violence that hit the northeast state in May.

The directive comes just days after a video, purportedly showing a man being burnt, had surfaced on social media, triggering fresh outrage and condemnation. The police had said that the video was related to the May 4 strip-parade case which the CBI is probing. Grappling with frequent tension following sharing of videos and photographs, the govt said its a "positive step towards bringing normalcy to the conflict-hit state.

An order by the Governor issued through the state Home Department on Wednesday stated that the state government took circulating images of violent activities "very seriously and with utmost sensitivity." It stated that images of activities such as inflicting bodily harm and damage to public or private property are likely to facilitate the mobilisation of "mobs of agitators and demonstrators," aggravating the law and order situation in the state.

It went on to say that anyone in possession of such images should approach the nearest Superintendent of Police and submit them for legal action, but if they are found to be circulating such images through social media, they shall be booked and prosecuted "under relevant provision of the law of land." It also stated that those found "misusing technology for inciting violence/ hatred" will be dealt with under provisions of the IT Act and the IPC. Mobile internet services were again suspended in the state till October 16.

Employers are often reluctant to fire workers. They need to offer severance packages and risk having the employee accuse the company of discrimination or prejudice for letting them go. It‚Äôs among the worst, most uncomfortable tasks for a human resources professional or manager. Supervisors may want to avoid conflict with employees. Nudging them to leave of their own volition can be a way for companies to manage their workforce and reduce costs.

In behavioral economics, a ‚Äúnudge‚Äù is a gentle prompt that influences people‚Äôs behavior. It refers to how HR and business leaders can use gentle cues to encourage employees to behave in a specific manner‚Äîlike investing in their pension, exceeding deadlines, participating in feedback surveys, or pushing a worker out the door.

Read more at the link in the bio.

Fascinating isn't it? The way the world divides when it comes to the Israeli Palestinian conflict.

First you have identity. Which becomes conflated with a plot of land. Suddenly the inhabitants of the land become synonymous with genetic similarity and by extension religion.

So when something occurs on that land, those that identify with the symbol think it's actually happening to them, even if they've never been to the land, etc.

A person could be born in California, never leave, never encounter racism or antisemitism in their own life, and still feel a connection to Israel because of a parent's heritage. 

It's basic religious nationalist tribal identity stuff.

On the news they reported how many "Americans" died in the horrible Israeli massacre by Hamas -- as if it really means anything. 

And then you have people sympathetic to Palestine which spirals into another array of associations.

Indigenous cultures may see the Israeli occupation of Palestine as representative of their own history. 

Academics and people who have studied the conflict for the past 75 years may have moral outrage at the double standards that have been fostered and in that outrage they put themselves in the perceived position, charging their own emotions.

At the end of the day what we appear to be doing is putting/feeling ourselves in hard positions and that ability to have sympathy and empathy is a positive human characteristic as deep down we all wish to take care of others, as we see others as ourselves.

Yet, when we start to have preferences; one assumed group loyalty over another, ‚Äì that is where the real trouble resides. 

Because it takes on a life of its own.

We all link back to mitochondrial Eve. We are all brothers and sisters biologically. What we call ethnicity and race are illusions, driven simply by regional exposures. A group on one side of the planet has darker skin and different physical features than a group on the other side of the planet as a process of evolution.

Our brains remain fundamentally the same in the average capacity to learn, develop and adapt.

That means national, religious, ethnic and so-called racial identity is all a delusion.

Helps nothing.

Mideast conflict: Laying the dead to rest

Relatives of 22-year-old Israeli-Irish woman Kim Damti mourn during her funeral on Thursday at a cemetery in Gedera, Israel. Damti was one of the 260 people killed by Hamas militants when they infiltrated a music festival near the border with Gaza in the early morning of October 7. More than 1,200 Israelis have been killed and over 3,000 others injured since the Islamist movement Hamas launched attacks on Israel from the Gaza Strip. More than 4,000 people, including 1,500 militants from Hamas, have been killed and thousands injured in both Gaza and Israel since the conflict erupted, according to Israeli military sources and Palestinian officials.

New Delhi: In a hurry to get on to his party‚Äôs bandwagon against opposition Congress‚Äôs statement on the Israel-Palestine conflict, Nagaland deputy chief minister and a top Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) leader from the Northeast, Yanthungo Patton, seemed to have only flaunted his ignorance about the country he was siding with.

The Hindutva brigade came out in full support of Israel and termed Hamas (and also all of Palestine, civilians included) a ‚Äòterrorist‚Äô on social media platforms in tandem with Prime Minister Narendra Modi‚Äôs all-out support to Israel.

Northeast BJP leaders like Assam chief minister Himanta Biswa Sarma soon jumped on to X to follow the prime minister‚Äôs line. Patton seemed to have thought of adding an extra angle to grab the attention of the Christian-majority population of his state. In an upload on X, he accused the Congress of being ‚Äúanti-Christian‚Äù by claiming that Israel is a ‚ÄúChristian country‚Äù.

‚ÄúCongress party is anti-Christian party. PM Modi stood in solidarity with a Christian country ‚Äì Israel, but Congress party instead of supporting Israel supports terrorist Hamas. So Congress Party is anti-Christian,‚Äù he wrote.

Soon, Patton, an MLA from the Christian-majority Tyui assembly constituency, was trolled for not knowing that Israel is a Jewish state and yet commenting on the Israel-Palestine face-off. It pushed him to delete the text, but not before it went viral in the region.

‚ö†Ô∏è Police told a BBC team to stay still or they would be shot.
BBC journalists covering the attack on Israel were assaulted and held at gunpoint after they were stopped by police in the Israeli city of Tel Aviv.
Muhannad Tutunji, Haitham Abudiab and their BBC Arabic team were driving to a hotel when their car was intercepted.
They were dragged from the vehicle - marked "TV" in red tape - searched and pushed against a wall.
A BBC spokesperson said journalists "must be able to report on the conflict in Israel-Gaza freely".
While attempting to film the incident, Mr Tutunji said his phone was thrown on the ground and he was struck on the neck.
"One of our BBC News Arabic teams deployed in Tel Aviv, in a vehicle clearly marked as media, was stopped and assaulted last night by Israeli police. Journalists must be able to report on the conflict in Israel-Gaza freely," a BBC spokesperson said.
The BBC has contacted Israeli police for comment.

An exhibition of my work "No Surrender: The Protestants" is currently up at @bx_gallery until October 28th.

Created between 1988 and 1991, the photographs predate the 1993 Joint Declaration on Peace and the subsequent periods of ceasefires and Peace Process. It is an unsentimental view of working-class loyalist communities in both Belfast and further afield during that time, capturing the often surreal nature of daily life set in the backdrop of conflict.

The work is presented in Belfast in a new light, over three decades after it was first published and now in tandem with Mariusz Smiejek's Not Surrendering - which provides a contemporary view of many of the issues and communities featured in my earlier work.

Join Mariusz and I for a joint artist talk on October 19 to learn more about this work.

Omara "Bombino" Moctar is out with his seventh album, Sahel, which is named after his homeland. On the project he pays tribute to his fellow Tuareg, who are indigenous to the eponymous African region that runs from the Atlantic Ocean to the Red Sea.‚Å†
‚Å†
"It looks like where we live is abandoned on purpose," Bombino told NPR's Leila Fadel, speaking in French. "We have to talk about the Sahel through our albums, through our songs, through an understanding of the entire world."‚Å†
‚Å†
The region has been wracked by violent conflict. Bombino himself has fled his home country of Niger twice due to a series of Tuareg uprisings. Tuareg rebels took up arms against the government, seeking autonomy.‚Å†

Pray for Israel & America, and family members of those massacred by Hamas Terrorist. 

Israeli soldiers found an ISIS flag among the belongings of a Hamas operative, drawing a connection between the two terrorist groups.

ISIS, also ISIL or the Islamic State, is an Iranian funded terror group that in 2014 declared a caliphate in Iraq and Syria. 

Hamas brought ISIS flags to massacre Israeli children, women and men.

Hamas is a genocidal terrorist organization. Hamas is worse than ISIS.

A connection between the two terror groups was also made by U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and¬†Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

Netanyahu made a direct connection between the two terror groups, saying: "Hamas is ISIS."

"Just as ISIS was crushed, so too will Hamas be crushed and Hamas should be treated exactly the way ISIS was treated," Netanyahu said. "They should be spit out from the community of nations. No leaders should meet them. No country should harbor them. And those that do should be sanctioned." And, "There will be many difficult days ahead, but I have no doubt that the forces of civilization will win."

Blinken highlighted the brutality of Hamas, including beheadings and the burning of victims, which the world also saw during ISIS's rise to power.

"Hamas has only one agenda: to destroy Israel and to murder. No country can or would tolerate the slaughter of its citizens or simply return to the conditions that allowed it to take place," he said. "Israel has the right, indeed, the obligation to defend itself and to ensure that this never happens. So the prime minister and I discussed how Israel does this matters. Our humanity, the value that we place on human life and human dignity. That's what makes us who we are. And we count them among our greatest strength."¬†

Blinken followed up these remarks by underscoring U.S. support for Israel amid its conflict with Hamas.

"My message to Israel is this: You may be strong enough on your own to defend yourself but as long as America exists, you'll never have to," he said.

The U.S. State Department has designated both ISIS and Hamas foreign terrorist organizations.

It has been more than 24 hours since Fatima has heard from her only daughter Lubna Nazir as she is stranded in Gaza amid the recent Israel-Palestine conflict. Now she is struggling to get in touch with Nazir to hear from her for once.

Lubna Nazir is a 52-year-old Kashmiri woman living in the Gaza Strip with her husband and two children ever since she got married to a Palestinian man some 20 years ago.

Israel says it has dropped 6,000 bombs in six days of bombardment of Gaza. On Friday, the zionist military asked over 1.1 million Palestinians to evacuate northern Gaza in 24 hours.

‚ÄúThis could be my last call as my phone doesn‚Äôt have enough battery and there is no electricity, water, or food here. Don‚Äôt know for how long we will survive, there is shelling and bombardment all over,‚Äù these were Nazir‚Äôs words when she spoke with her mother Fatima and cousin Adnan.

Two days ago, Israel imposed a complete siege on the already blockaded Gaza Strip cutting off all food, water, electricity, and fuel supply. Gaza‚Äôs sole power plant has also collapsed leaving the conflict-ridden area in a complete blackout. The internet services have also been snapped with no further notice of restoration.

Nazir told her mother that her family in Gaza is not being able to lead their usual day or step out of the house as White Phosphorus starts pouring anytime during the day or night. Her kids and husband have not gone to school and work as there is shelling all around, as narrated by Adnan Jaan, Nazir‚Äôs maternal cousin to Maktoob on Thursday, October 12.

‚ÄúShe has been living there for years and it has always been a conflict zone, but this time it was different, we could hear the sound of bombs falling in the background while we were talking with her‚Äù, said Jaan.

Jaan told Maktoob, ‚ÄúShe told us that she would try to relocate to some nearest safe place but commuting is also unsafe at the moment. She can‚Äôt stay there and she can‚Äôt move out.‚Äù

Fatima,80, is worried to the extent that she has not been able to eat or sleep ever since she last spoke with Nazir.

That is called Carpet Bombing. Evacuate 1,100,000 people‚Ä¶ Where? They can‚Äôt leave a blockade. Hospitals are packed to the brim. The injured can‚Äôt move. And now white phosphorus is being used against innocent civilians. This smells like ethnic cleansing.

The propaganda machine that is fueling increased divisive speech throughout communities worldwide leaving a vacuum where our greatest assets of love, compassion and unity should flourish, is now being filled with the immoral rhetoric of hatred, indifference and bigotry. All this is inevitably propelling us into further conflict and escalation of violence, the end result of which will not bring peace. If history has taught us anything, it‚Äôs that we learn nothing from history. 

Picking sides is a tiresome and petty form of conflict resolution. Don‚Äôt fall for it. Appeal to your logic, not your emotion. Tribalism is death. At its core it poses an existential threat. Don‚Äôt engage. You are human. That‚Äôs it. The loss of Israeli life is horrific. The loss of Palestinian life is horrific. It‚Äôs all barbaric and unconscionable. 

Our world is being pushed to the brink of irreparable harm by the decisions of adult children who are playing Battleship. They want you to turn a blind eye to the ramifications of war. Don‚Äôt play their game. Your hatred is their commodity. There‚Äôs no hatred ‚Äúout there.‚Äù Hatred is in the mind. Abandon it and you will never find it ‚Äúout there.‚Äù Let ‚Äúother‚Äù be the object of your compassion, not the object of your hatred. ‚ÄúNever again‚Äù CANNOT be a moniker of relief for some and for others a fantasy they will never be recognized within.

Waylands Smithy Neolithic Long Barrow.
Wayland‚Äôs Smithy is a Neolithic burial site. It was a tomb (grave) built of of stone and wood. There was a narrow wooden box, into which people were successively placed. The remains of 11 men, 2 women and a child, were discovered when it was excavated in 1963. New radiocarbon dating has shown that the first burials were probably placed there in 3590-3555 BC, and the last in 3580-3550 BC. The barrow was therefore used for no more than 15 years, less than a single generation. It is also possible that the barrow was used for an even shorter period of time, perhaps just a year. We don‚Äôt know what circumstances caused this group of people to be interred over such a short period. Perhaps the group suffered some illness or injury during conflict. There are potentially three or more people who suffered lethal arrowhead strikes, and two individuals whose remains were subject to scavenging by animals before burial. After a period of between 40 and 100 years, the structure was covered by an oval mound of chalk and earth. This formed a monument that would today be described as a long barrow. This mound signalled the closure of the barrow.

The F9F Panther, Grumman‚Äôs first jet fighter in its line of Fighting Cats, started its life during the late stages of the Second World War. Keen to capitalize on the emergence of jet technology, Grumman submitted their G-75, a four engine fighter similar in configuration to the F7F, model to a Navy competition seeking a jet powered night fighter. The G-75, however, would lose the contract to the Douglas F3D Skyknight. Despite this, the Navy issued a contract to Grumman to produce two G-75 Prototypes, designated XF9F-1, as a backup in case the F3D ran into developmental issues. Grumman eventually decided that the G-75 did not have much potential, and started working on a single engine day fighter, internally known as the G-79. Choosing not to cancel the G-75 contract, the Navy updated the request to include three prototypes of the entirely different G-79. (Note: No G-75 prototypes were ever constructed)

The G-79 would be powered by an imported Rolls Royce Nene engine, as there were no American built engines that were reliable enough for the rigors of navy operation. The Nene would be produced under license as the P&W J42. A larger version of the same engine, the RR Tay, would be used in later models, as the P&W J48.¬†

By 1947, the Prototype Panther, the XF9F-2, conducted its maiden flight, piloted by Corky Meyer. Initial flight testing revealed issues with stability, These issues would quickly be polished out, and by 1949, the Panther would undergo carrier trials. While the USAF was still content with the WWII arrangement of .50 caliber MGs, the Navy had already moved to standardizing a quartet of 20mm cannons, which would be fitted to the Panther.¬†

The panther would prove to me a critical asset during the Korean War, and would be the widest used Navy jet fighter in the conflict. Over 78,000 sorties would be flown by panthers, and would down seven enemy MiGs.¬†

The Durability of the Panther was impressive, and deserves its own post.¬†

The headlines we scroll past are more than mere statistics; they're a mirror reflecting the wounds of our shared humanity. Each life lost, each home shattered‚Äîthese are calls to action that reverberate in each of us.

To my fellow Americans, your voice has the power to turn the tide. The link in my bio will guide you to your elected representatives and a script you can use.  Make the call and demand an immediate ceasefire and a move toward peace and justice.

WASHINGTON - U.S. Capitol Police and several law enforcement agencies in the D.C. area say they are increasing security and visibility as rumors circulate on social media about a threatened "day of rage."

Law enforcement in the nation‚Äôs capital and other major cities including New York and Los Angeles are preparing following reports that former Hamas leader Khaled Meshaal made a call for global protests to be held Friday. 

Historically, these kinds of calls have caused widespread demonstrations in the Palestinian territories of Gaza and the West Bank but haven‚Äôt led to any large-scale action in the U.S. But considering the unprecedented circumstances surrounding this war, federal, state and local leaders are erring on the side of caution.

The call to action comes days after war broke out between Israel and Hamas following a surprise attack by the militant Islamist group that killed hundreds and left thousands more injured. 

As the rocket attacks and deadly raids continue, the death toll has steadily risen with more than 1,200 now reported dead and more than 3,000 injured. Along with that, Hamas claims to have taken at least 150 hostages into Gaza.

More than 1,100 people have already been killed in Gaza as Israel continues to strike back. At least 27 American citizens have died in the conflict and another 14 are missing, National Security Council official John Kirby confirmed Thursday.

The extraordinary escalation of the decades-long conflict between Israel and pro-Palestinian radicals sent shockwaves across the globe and enormous suffering on both sides has sparked demonstrations. 

Rallies were held in D.C. Sunday at the Washington Memorial, the White House and the Israeli Embassy after the violence broke out. Tributes were set up to honor and remember the hundreds of people killed in Israel while pro-Palestinian demonstrators were also present, holding flags and standing in solidarity.

BREAKING: France declares maximum security alert due to the terror threat

The French prime minister has put the country on its highest state of counter-terrorism alert after an assailant fatally stabbed a teacher and seriously injured two others.

Witnesses say the knifeman shouted "Allahu Akbar", or "God is greatest", during the attack at a school in Arras, northern France. He is now in custody.
The "attack emergency" level has been used in previous counter-terror cases.

The alert can trigger extra security deployments and public warnings.

The attack came amid rising tensions in France's sizeable Muslim and Jewish communities due to the conflict between Israel and Hamas.

This photo has been making the rounds of what looks like an Israeli Yasur helicopter in flames (based on the American CH-53)

Palestinian sources say that militants shot it down but the IDF has not mentioned anything of the sort, but the photo allegedly comes from an Israeli Channel 12 broadcast.

Ive seen one source saying 50 soldiers died in the crash, however this seems highly unlikely as the Yasur has a maximum suggested capacity of 30 passengers and four crew.

There also no confirmation this is even from the current conflict - yet.

Please be aware of misinformation and seek out common sense facts. For example, what tipped me off mostly here was the "50 people died". Its easily googleable.

That being said, it could be true. Its not just confirmed. So keep your wits about you when seeing conflict news.

Will update you if its real, because that would be a huge loss.

In a recent meeting with Malta‚Äôs Foreign Affairs Minister, the Ambassador of the State of Palestine to Malta raised his concerns regarding the ongoing conflict in the Gaza Strip.

Ambassador Fadi Hanania discussed the latest developments in the conflict which includes ‚Äúmore than 1,200‚Äù people that have signed and agreed on the importance of ‚Äúintervening to end the aggression on Gaza.

Hanania also briefed Minister Ian Borg about decisions taken to prevent the entry of essential materials, such as medicines and food. He stressed the importance of ensuring open passages to meet basic human needs.

Minister Borg acknowledged the grave nature of the situation and confirmed he has been in touch with the Palestinian Foreign Minister. 

Borg also noted that he has consulted with fellow EU Foreign Ministers on this pressing matter.

Despite calls from some European countries, Borg assured that Malta  remains steadfast in its support for Palestine and will not yield to pressures to cease such backing.

In a heart-wrenching account from a Roya journalist in Gaza, @wizard_bisan1, the unfolding crisis continues to expose the dire circumstances faced by innocent civilians.

The journalist highlights a horrifying event in #Gaza, demonstrating the severe consequences of the ongoing conflict.

Earlier, it was reported that civilians were urged to evacuate from northern areas to southern regions via a "safe route."

However, Bisan Odeh reveals the grim reality of this evacuation attempt. Instead of ensuring the safety of those fleeing the conflict, the so-called safe route became a treacherous journey.

While attempting to follow the guidance and leave their homes behind, people were met with targeted attacks on ambulances, cars, and buses traveling along the road.

She said, in an Instagram video posted on her official account, ‚ÄúDo you remember when I said that they pushed people to evacuate from the northern to the southern areas via a safe route, as they said? Okay, that was a trick. It was a trick‚Äù

The consequences have been devastating, with more than 70 killed and 200 injured.

The journalist emphasizes the tragic loss of life, particularly among children, and the harrowing scenes they have witnessed.

‚ÄúInnocent people took anything from their homes and went to the southern areas and they killed them. They literally killed them. Literally,‚Äù she said, emotionally.

The horror of this reality, she says, is ‚Äúhard to comprehend, and the emotional toll it takes on those living through it is immeasurable.‚Äù

We write this in the wake of the horrific events that have taken place in recent days and that continue to unfold. There is deep pain felt in the Jewish community around the world. We have been processing our shock and grief at the atrocious terrorist attacks by Hamas, the devastating loss of life, and the continued anguish and worry for the safety of the hostages. We are heartbroken for the innocent Israeli and Palestinian families who are suffering from historical trauma, current violence, and palpable dread for what is to come.‚Å†
‚Å†
Here in our own Bay Area community, we anticipate that recent events may lead to a spike of antisemitism and Islamophobia. Since its inception, The Contemporary Jewish Museum has upheld Jewish life and culture, carried it out into the wider world, and taught ways to work against prejudice to build a world free of intolerance. As school groups entered The Museum these past few days, we continued to engage in important conversations with young people about how Jewish culture can foster belonging, empathy, and acceptance of others.‚Å†
‚Å†
In this dark moment, as we process the horrible trauma, we open our hearts and find connection through our shared humanity. Art and community can offer some comfort during times of immense challenge and heartache. To provide a space for respite, we are opening our doors for free this weekend, and we invite you to come and spend time in community at The CJM. ‚Å†
‚Å†
At The Museum, we work to manifest a world free of hatred and bigotry, one in which people of all backgrounds and identities may flourish. We pray for a resolution that enables all people impacted by this tragic conflict‚ÄîIsraelis, Palestinians, and people around the globe‚Äîto live in peace and safety. ‚Å†
‚Å†
We pray for peace.

Israel has bomb shelters everywhere: Indian students

NEW DELHI: Glad to be home and traumatised by what they had seen in the last few days, the first batch of over 200 Indians returned from Israel on Friday with the sound of air raid sirens, rocket fire and screams ringing loud in their ears. Israel witnessed a surprise and unprecedented attack by Hamas in its southern parts on Saturday morning. 

At least 700 people have been killed and more than 2,100 injured in Israel the deadliest day for the country in at least 50 years. 

 "We woke up to sounds of air raid sirens. We stay in central Israel and I don't know what shape this conflict will take," said Shashwat Singh soon after landing at Delhi airport along with his wife. 

 The post-doctoral researcher in agriculture, who has been staying in Israel since 2019, said the sound of those sirens and the nightmarish experience of the past few days still haunt him. The evacuation of Indians is a "praiseworthy step", Singh said soon after the flight landed.

Last Saturday (7 Oct), Palestinian militant group Hamas launched a surprise attack on Israel. In response, Israel declared a state of war and has since launched air strikes against Gaza with plans for a ground assault.

As of Wednesday noon (11 Oct), at least 950 deaths in Gaza and over 1200 deaths in Israel were reported. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) reports that nearly 200 000 people in Gaza have been displaced.

‚ÄúThe most recent violence does not come in a vacuum. The reality is that it grows out of a longstanding conflict, with a 56-year old occupation and no political end in sight.‚Äù ‚Äî UN Secretary General, Antonio Guterres. 

There are people dying from both sides of the war. So as you look to the news to form your opinions on the matter, please remember that human loss of life has always been used by governments to justify aggressive political or military action, and that more often than not, civilian losses outweigh military ones. If escalating violence continues to be the only way forward, then this will just be another incident in a pattern for years to come.

‚úÖPolitico just published a report that Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned a small group of lawmakers last week that his department is tracking the possibility that Azerbaijan could soon invade Armenia, according to two people familiar with the conversation.

The call indicates the depth of concern in the administration about Azerbaijan‚Äôs operations against a breakaway region in the west of the country and the possibility of the conflict spreading. Azerbaijiani President Ilham Aliyev has previously called on Armenia to open a ‚Äúcorridor‚Äù along its southern border, linking mainland Azerbaijan to an exclave that borders Turkey and Iran. Aliyev has threatened to solve the issue ‚Äúby force.‚Äù
In an Oct. 3 phone call, lawmakers pressed Blinken on possible measures against Aliyev in response to his country‚Äôs invasion of the Nagorno-Karabakh region in September, the people said, who were granted anonymity to discuss the sensitive call.

Blinken responded that the State Department was looking at avenues to hold Azerbaijan accountable and isn‚Äôt planning to renew a long-standing waiver that allows the U.S. to provide military assistance to Baku. He added that State saw a possibility that Azerbaijan would invade southern Armenia in the coming weeks.

Still, Blinken expressed confidence about ongoing diplomatic talks between Armenia and Azerbaijan to the Democratic lawmakers, among them Reps. Nancy Pelosi and Anna Eshoo of California, and Frank Pallone of New Jersey.

Two additional people confirmed that a briefing happened on the situation in Azerbaijan, but did not provide details. Report by Politico #armeniannews #armenia #hayastan

On Thursday, Oct. 12, Tritons for Israel, partnered with UCSD Hillel, SDSU Hillel, Chabad UCSD, and SDSU Students Supporting Israel, hosted a walk for Israeli solidarity in front of Geisel Library at 12 p.m.

Later that same day, Students for Justice in Palestine at UC San Diego hosted a vigil called Honor Our Martyrs at 6 p.m. in front of Geisel Library, alongside the Palestinian Youth Movement, SJP at SDSU, and Palestine Solidarity Committee at University of San Diego.

Both events come after a series of attacks in Israel from Hamas, a political and militant organization from Palestine. Starting early Saturday, Hamas is said to be responsible for firing on Israeli civilians in communities near the Gaza strip and abducting an unknown number of people. 

This led to Israel‚Äôs declaration of war on Hamas, an escalation of 75 years of Israeli subjugation of Palestine. The Israeli military stated that they have largely regained control of areas attacked by Hamas members. It has continued a siege and heavy bombing of the Gaza Strip. Israel has also cut off water, food, fuel, Internet access, and energy to the city of Gaza in Palestine and its 2.3 million civilians.

every facet of our mission here at The Conversationalist is driven by one fundamental belief: that our shared humanity is more powerful than any form of hate or division.

as we've witnessed in horror the acts of Hamas and the suffering and terror that continues to unfold in Israel and Gaza - the brutal escalation of a conflict that has inflicted violence against civilians across the region for decades - this belief can feel further from our reality than ever, but that's also why it‚Äôs never been more important to hold onto.

no matter your religion, race, background, upbringing, nationality, culture, or political beliefs, it‚Äôs imperative that we resist retreating into hate or misunderstanding and instead come together to recognize that no person or group of people should be denied their humanity in this way. this has always been true and will always be true. when we ignore this truth ‚Äî or worse, attempt to justify the opposite ‚Äî history repeats itself. it can stop with us. it has to stop with us.

there‚Äôs no easy way to do this, but there are ways we can try. we have to meet each other as human beings first. we have to listen, not just consume. we have to remember that we are all entering conversations with perspectives shaped by our unique backgrounds, lived experiences, and level of knowledge on the issues at hand. we have to remember that misinformation is rampant. we have to remember that there are gray areas in most conversations and situations. we have to remember that encouraging the elimination of other human beings is never one of them.

for anyone who doesn‚Äôt know where to start when it comes to these conversations, but feels ready to have them - we‚Äôve shared some tips above we‚Äôve found helpful as we navigate this, too. 

please share any additional conversation tips in the comments. for anyone who is trying to start a conversation from a place of justification for violence against any person or group of people, rather than human empathy or understanding, we are not hosting or participating in that discourse right now.

to everyone affected, we're praying for your safety.

We condemn the recent Hamas terrorist attacks on Israel. The brutality and dehumanizing violence is barbaric, grotesque and has genocidal intent. We mourn for those affected and grieve knowing that the devastation caused by these actions will endure for generations to come. 

Conflict in the Middle East can often be traced to the First World War. Lines were drawn, treaties written, promises were made then and since ‚Äì often without the participation of the very people and lands that they purported to help. A century later, we witness the ongoing suffering of millions of innocent people. The enduring impact of the Great War includes unintended consequences. 

History is difficult and complex. Often what appears to be a solution to the problem causes others to become more acute. Understanding our history can help us create sustainable solutions that uphold democratic values and honor the worth of all people. We stand with those who work for peace and informed decision-making. 

At the National WWI Museum and Memorial we seek to provide a forum for discussion and debate about the enduring impact of the Great War. We firmly believe there is no better path to understanding than by learning. 

Image: An Assyrian Sphinx guards the entrance of the National WWI Museum and Memorial. ‚ÄúMemory‚Äù faces east, shielding its eyes from the horrors of war.

Santa Monica City Hall is lit up in blue and white this week in remembrance of the many lives that have been lost from the conflict happening in Israel.

Our hearts go out to all who are impacted by this week‚Äôs tragic events.

It‚Äôs with absolute horror, revulsion and a deep deep sadness that I‚Äôve watched the events of the past few days unfold in the Middle East. It takes me back to nearly 20 years ago when I witnessed first hand the unfolding 2006 war with Hezbollah. Having graduated in a degree for War Studies and History I naively took myself off to witness the real thing. What I saw was a country unite and fight in an uncompromising manor. This latest war however I imagine will be on a completely different level. The desire for revenge will be so great that it is hard to see how this will end. Israel is in the unenviable position of trying to eradicate a movement born out of trauma, hatred and desire for revenge, that is right on its doorstep. How you do this without furthering that idea through collective punishment and collateral damage seems difficult to imagine. I‚Äôve always had a deep sympathy for the Palestinian cause; having witnessed the dehumanising policies that have furthered their pain and humiliation, but I also fully respect Israel‚Äôs need for security and the right to exist - the balance for all of that takes real leadership. The events of the past few days have knocked all of this off kilter for at least another few generations. My sympathies lie with all of those caught up in it.

Imam Muhammad Musri is the president of the Islamic Society of Central Florida. Rabbi David Kay is the chair of the Interfaith Council of Central Florida. ‚¨á

"As faith and worldview leaders in Central Florida, we are unshakably committed to stand together. We call on our communities to model peaceful coexistence, upholding the principle of ‚ÄúLove your neighbor as yourself‚Äù. We must not allow the tragic events and the ongoing war in the Middle East to divide our Central Florida community or to let hate and anger develop among us.

We call on our elected political leaders and all world leaders to do everything possible to bring a speedy end to the war, to save the lives of all innocent civilians, and to bring a lasting peace.

We have seen so many peaceful solutions crumble and fail. Yet, we have not lost hope; hope that hearts will open to the wisdom and understanding that peace cannot be achieved through violence and justice cannot be achieved through unjust means.

This is what those of us who pray are praying for, what those of us who do not pray are longing for, and what all of us are working to achieve."

Now that the proverbial smoke has cleared, and I've laid a ground floor for my contextual reasons for my opposition to the Israeli/ Palestine issues unfolding on the Gaza Strip. It seemed fitting to unveil some dark satire of how folks are sounding to me these days.

Especially the "woke Jesus" slide. God never condones Christians to slay others in His name. This mentality is but an offshoot of a Crusaders' mentality of "Deus Vault!" ("God wills it!") before rushing into battle to slay innocent bystanders. Why? The reasons are always numerous and justified, to spare family members' souls from purgatory if you slay an infidel for the Catholic church. To reclaim the "Holy Land" from the Saracens and give it to "Christians." To eradicate "terrorists" from these barbaric people. To protect God's "chosen people."

The list goes on and on, and the lies and narratives adapt. But one thing remains certain, wars in the Middle East grieve God's heart. The Talmud j-ws forged Catholicisms early roots under Emperor Constantine. Catholicism, in turn, then created Islam, as a modern Rabbi, phrased it as, "Islam is the broom of Israel." Basically, send in their ethnicity to create populous dissent, then come in as the shining knights in armor to restore order. 

Most folks don't seem to realize that the Old Testament promise to Abram is not applicable to present-day Israel. Rather, the parasites who claim their ethnicity to that region use it as a ploy to manipulate sympathy from Christian dupes to fight their battles. Then, when called out for what they truly are, they pull the "antisemitic" veil over their heads. The equivalent analogy of a bully once confronted saying, "You wouldn't hit a kid with glasses, would you?" 

Christians, if we're joint heirs according to Abrams' promise,...doesn't that make us as equals? I'm not sure how many times Christians need to hear this verse, but again, 

"For there is neither j-w nor Greek, neither slave nor free, nor male or female, for ye are all one in Christ Jesus." - Gal. 3:28

Yes, for the true innocent citizens of this conflict and any country's conflict, I pity and sympathize with 100%. My heart grieves for their hardships.

‚Ä¢ @momwell - Do you ever feel like having a baby changed your relationship completely‚Äìand not in a good way? 
 
You‚Äôre not alone. It‚Äôs common for couples to face more conflict and dissatisfaction after a baby is born. 
 
In fact, 67% of couples report a decline in their relationship satisfaction during the first three years of their baby‚Äôs life.* 
 
There are many reasons why new parents often feel dissatisfied: 
 
„Ä∞ Both partners are transitioning into their new roles, which can be difficult. 
„Ä∞ They're sleep-deprived, making them both more irritable and less able to navigate conflict. 
„Ä∞ They are often overstimulated and overwhelmed with new parental responsibilities. 
„Ä∞ They might not see eye-to-eye on parenting decisions or how to adapt to life with a child. 
„Ä∞ Having children comes with new responsibilities and mental labor, which might not be shared fairly. 
 
It‚Äôs no wonder so many new parents are struggling! Navigating these changes takes skills‚Äìskills that so many of us were never taught. 
 
But the good news is that we CAN learn them. We don‚Äôt have to live in conflict and resentment. 
 
*source: https://www.gottman.com/about/research/parenting/

This is our proudly Jewish-blended family with dear ones on both sides of the conflict and a call for peace.

Jews make up a smaller percentage of the population than many realize. Most sources put the global Jewish population at 16 million. To put that into pop culture context, Kim Kardashian has 22x more followers on Instagram than there are Jews living worldwide.

For that reason, an attack on Jews ripples from the head to the toe of our global community in a heartbeat. 

I share that information with non-Jews in the hope of explaining why attacks are felt so profoundly & as anyone who has felt truly othered may understand. 

And still, calls to stand with Israel are not compelling to our family. I would never&will never pledge my loyalty to a state. Stateheads do not represent the collective best interest as is laid bare in the horrific events unfolding right now. 

Here is who I will fight like hell for - mothers having their babies ripped from their arms, women whose bodily autonomy is sacrificed as a bargaining chip in wars they didn‚Äôt ask for, young people who deserve to grow up freely and safely. I care not what God you pray to nor what country issues your passport.

I will fight like hell for anyone who is living with a boot on their neck. Horrifically, this happens everywhere from right outside my doorstep to half way across the world. 

A thought I cannot get over: according to reports, two weeks ago 2,000 Israeli& Palestinian women gathered in a show of solidarity and to demand that women be given a seat at the negotiating table - these women are fighting for peace.

Put women at the table who speak the universal language of living in a world not made for us; put women at the table who would never rip a child from another woman‚Äôs arms knowing she could never perpetrate that kind of violence from mother to mother; put women at the table who would never trap another family as bombs are dropped on their homes with borders blocked; put women at the table who would never see another woman raped. 

Put women at the table. 

Our hearts break for each dear, sweet, beloved human life at risk. Where is our humanity?

 @womenwagepeace @women.of.the.sun_

The fire burned all night from the smoking tree, alone on the floodplain, burnt every season but alive. Anxiety burns inside us like a fire in the heart of a tree; unfamiliar and life-threatening. The heartwood is dead and dry, hard as steel, it‚Äôs the unconscious isolated from the entirely undefinable something which is everything. In looking out upon the world, we forget that the world is looking upon itself. You are the soul that is threatened in this tree.

For the ego exists as an abstraction from memory, like a long exposure of a fire burning in a tree beyond reality, immortalized. Like a photo, the past from which our ego is gains meaning has disappeared entirely. Actions guided by ego are doomed to frustration in a false image of yourself. Self-conscious, dualistic, and insecure, you can‚Äôt let go of yourself as you search for certainty and security in a city designed to control you.

You burn inside with stress and anxiety as you exist in between not doing what you are doing and wanting to do what you aren‚Äôt doing. You feel that you shouldn‚Äôt be what you are, and want to be what you aren‚Äôt. When attempting to exert power over someone else, you can‚Äôt avoid giving them power over you. Actions according to ego give your power away from you in the compulsive desire to control and guarantee.

A fire shouldn‚Äôt be burning in the heart of this tree. Spontaneity isn‚Äôt a blind, disorderly impulse or disorder. Driven by ego, the language and convention of modern society can‚Äôt imagine an intelligence that doesn‚Äôt work according to plan, that flows uncontrolled, connected with everything without ordered thought. The tree was meant to burn, spontaneously. Cultivating spontaneity helps us recognize anxiety as our natural reaction to ego.

There is no duality, no conflict between natural spontaneity and human control. Our constructive and destructive powers are the formative, spontaneous actions of trees, bees, and all life. We shouldn‚Äôt be trying to control everything. The root of unrecognizable anxiety, the fire burning in our hearts as the darkness approaches, is an abstraction of ego in memory that consumes our identity and halts serendipity.

This war memorial is one of many created around the country following the First World War. It was erected in 1921 on the boundary of the boroughs of Bermondsey and Rotherhithe as a memorial to local men who had died in the war. It was largely funded by the nearby Peek Frean biscuit business, with the factory owner giving the opening speech. The unveiling was undertaken by local mother Mrs. Speer who had lost three sons in the conflict. #londonhistory #warmemorials #rotherhithe #bermondsey #peekfrean #linkinbio

text:
There are moments when we feel like outsiders, disconnected from the world as a whole. We observe how people can turn against one another for the sake of power, and we question why God doesn't intervene despite the majority of us praying for harmony. I contemplated this during my morning meditation, and here is what I discovered:

As a collective, we have stopped caring. Some individuals feel powerless, others are too self-absorbed, and there are those who have become desensitized or overwhelmed by the pain and suffering we witness through the news - the wars, crimes, and violence that plague our world.

It is essential to remember that every thought, word, and action we take contributes to the unfolding of the universe. We are active participants in this ever-evolving world, and everything we perceive has been shaped by the collective consciousness of humanity.

These are crucial moments we are living in. The world, as we once knew it, has been disrupted once again by terrorism and the senseless killing of innocent people,  in both side of this horrific story, who share the same dreams and aspirations for themselves and their children.

Our world may be divided, but it doesn't have to be. Darkness thrives in a divided world, and predators prey on the weak. Nothing occurs by chance. Everything in the universe exists in harmony, except for humanity, as we have forgotten how to love one another. The transformation of our collective consciousness begins with each individual.

Take a moment to ask yourself: Am I currently feeling insulted, angry, upset, or harboring dislike towards someone? If your answer is yes, then you are contributing to the cosmic energy of conflict in the world.  How can we expect the world to change if we cannot change ourselves?

Prayers for peace cannot be heard if there is no peace within our own hearts. I understand that for many of us, especially given the current state of the world, letting go of these negative emotions will be incredibly challenging. However, peace for the masses begins with individual forgiveness. Namaste. #peace #nomorebloodshed #protectheinnocent  #peaceforisraelandpalestineüïäÔ∏è

The United Arab Emirates has launched a campaign to provide relief aid to the Palestinian people impacted by the war in the Gaza Strip, under the theme ‚ÄòTarahum - for Gaza‚Äô.

The campaign will establish centers to collect and mobilize humanitarian relief packages in partnership with humanitarian and charitable institutions, volunteer centers, the private sector, media and all segments of society. As part of the humanitarian efforts undertaken by the UAE to provide urgent assistance to the Palestinian people, the relief campaign is in cooperation with the World Food Program, and in coordination with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Community Development.

Moreover, in solidarity with the Palestinian children and families affected by the ongoing conflict, the ‚ÄòTarahum - for Gaza‚Äô campaign aims to mitigate the severity of the humanitarian conditions, and alleviate the suffering of the most vulnerable groups, especially children, who constitute nearly half of the population of the Gaza Strip. More than one million children are affected by the current conflict, and the campaign will work towards providing children and mothers with basic needs, in addition to health supplies and general hygiene materials.

The campaign will be inaugurated on Sunday, 15th October 2023, in Abu Dhabi, under the supervision of the Emirates Red Crescent at the Abu Dhabi Ports Hall in Mina Zayed from 9 am - 4 pm, and will be organized across the rest of the Emirates at a later date.

„ÄêICRC calls on all parties to respect IHL„Äë
In the past few days, five members of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement have tragically lost their lives, including four Palestinian Red Crescent Society paramedics and one ambulance driver of Magen David Adom in Israel. They were attacked while providing humanitarian assistance.

In response to the urgent situation in Israel and the Gaza Strip, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) urged all parties involved in the conflict to comply with their legal obligations under International Humanitarian Law (IHL). It emphasizes providing immediate protection to civilians and taking all possible measures to prevent further harm to healthcare workers, medical facilities, civilians‚Äô infrastructure and objects.

The ICRC has been present in Israel and the Occupied Territories since 1967, and taken immediate actions to provide emergency and critical humanitarian aid, including transfer medical supplies to a hospital in Gaza, operate ambulance services and collect over 13,000 units of blood, etc.

As the world reels from recent terrorist attacks launched by Hamas and the Israeli military action unfolding in Gaza, and our friends and colleagues feel their impacts, we‚Äôre reflecting on how we can do better, collectively, in the pursuit of peace.

How can we do more to reject the politics of ‚Äúus‚Äù vs. ‚Äúthem‚Äù that lead us further down the path of fear and division? How can we resist hate, racism, antisemitism and Islamophobia? How can we help each other better understand the context of this conflict and the long struggle for universal rights and freedom that continues today?

We ask these questions because the only way to realize a world where all human beings live free and equal, in dignity and rights, is through embracing our shared humanity, engaging in dialogue and ensuring mutual respect and recognition.

On the ground, Israeli and Palestinian peacemakers have long worked to build bridges, defend their collective human rights and secure a peaceful resolution of this longstanding conflict. That same work also happens here in Canada. It is that work, those people and their remarkable accomplishments over decades that we uplift today.

They are examples to all of us why we cannot afford to decide there are problems so complex that there is nothing to do but throw up our hands, absolve ourselves of responsibility and walk away. Each of us has the capacity, in our own way, to take action.

I spent nearly a week thinking about what to say. I, like many of you have been deeply impacted and affected by the horrific and tragic events from last weekend. The honest raw vulnerable truth is that I have never felt so unsure about what to say. I‚Äôm jewish, but not super religious, but this is about humanity. For me, social media is a great tool to spread positivity, inspirational nuggets, mindset and connect with other like minded humans. I‚Äôm a believer in humanity even though at times I‚Äôm let down. I admittedly and by design, don‚Äôt watch too much of the news so I don‚Äôt know every detail of the conflict in the middle east. But what I do know is this. I am heartbroken, upset, angry and at times feel paralyzed and my thoughts and prayers go out to all the innocent people who have lost their lives and who have suffered a loss as a result of this situation. Everyone to some degree is impacted by this awful situation. This week in my Kabbalah class we spent the entire class discussing what‚Äôs going on in Israel and how we feel, what we can do, and just all the things about this heartbreaking and awful situation. And our teacher said aside from the physical stuff such as donating, sending Zohar‚Äôs to Isreali solders and so forth, the most important thing that we can do is to identify the hatred and darkness inside ourselves, because weather we want to admit it or not everyone has some, and then correct it and turn it into light and love. This is so that as a whole collective consciousness we can create more light and less hate and prevent events like this from happening again. I would also suggest to be super intentional with the news, and footage that you consume. It‚Äôs important to see the horror that is going on, but to a degree. Exercise kindness. Remove negativity. Work on becoming the best version of you. If everyone just committed to that, then we can create the world we truly want to see. It starts within each of us. Be the light and contribute to creating more light. Thats our responsibility. Please be smart and safe üíû.

Join BMW‚Äôs visit to Art Car Artist #20 Julie Mehretu‚Äôs new exhibition at White Cube.

‚ÄòThey departed for their own country another way (a 9x9x9 hauntology)‚Äô debuts three new bodies of work consisting of nine paintings each. A dialogue between Mehretu and artist Baghramian is introduced in the exhibition, placing the paintings in conversation with Baghramian‚Äôs abstract sculpture ‚ÄúS‚Äôasseyant‚Äù (2022).

Mehretu‚Äôs works focus on themes of enduring conflict, widespread displacement, and power dynamics. The exhibition is on view at White Cube through 5 November 2023. Lets take a look!

As many American Jews remain focused on mourning the 1,300 Israelis killed in the attack by Hamas Saturday ‚Äî and on crushing the terrorist organization‚Äôs infrastructure in Gaza ‚Äî Palestinian Americans are wracked with fear for their families and frustration with the U.S. government, which is sending military aid to Israel.

Israeli forces have killed 1,800 Palestinians and left 400,000 homeless, according to local officials. The Israeli military told Palestinians living in the northern Gaza Strip, where more than one million people live, to evacuate south Friday.

While many Palestinian Americans have long been frustrated with their government‚Äôs approach to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, feeling that it has been biased in favor of Israel, they said that imbalance feels especially extreme following the Hamas attack on Israeli civilians.

Israel has said it is seeking to destroy Hamas and pressure the terrorist group to free dozens of hostages kidnapped Saturday. Military officials said they were aiming only at legitimate targets but acknowledged they had abandoned the doctrine of "surgical" strikes used to limit civilian casualties in past Gaza conflicts.

"I wish I could say that taking measures to stay safe is something that is applicable here,‚Äù said Dorgham Abusalim, a communications professional in Washington, D.C. whose parents are in Gaza. "The reality is there is no safety to be found anywhere in the Gaza Strip."

üîó Tap the link in our bio to read more from Arno Rosenfeld.

üì∏ A cameraman films while smoke plumes billow during Israeli air strikes in Gaza City Thursday. Palestinian Americans are watching the conflict unfold with mounting dread, as the U.S. government has thrown its weight behind Israeli military action. (Photo by Getty Images)

Pay attention to the words used. 'But' keeps us problem focused and in the past, whereas AND has the potential to shift the forces and/or narrative to be future focused and solution oriented. 

Because perspectives clash, finding common ground may feel like an impossible task. The ongoing conflict has given rise to coutless debates, leaving us standing at the crossroads of frustration, anger, betrayal and confusion. But amidst the chaos and disagreements, there lies a truth that unites most: the condemnation of the loss of innocent lives.

Inspired by the resilience of those affected, we must come together, engage in meaningful dialogue, and forge a path towards peace by finding the root cause and the right perpetrators: the sponsors of terror. Let us transcend the boundaries of blame and awaken our collective consciousness to the urgency of this situation. It is not enough to cast our sorrowful glances from a distance; now is the moment to ask ourselves, "What can we do to fix it?"

The key lies in embracing the transformative power of unity. By recognizing the humanity that exists within each individual, regardless of their nationality or background, we open doors to breaking down barriers and building bridges. It is through understanding and compassion that we can dismantle the walls of ignorance and pave the way for a brighter future.

Our duty extends beyond mere empathy; it demands action. Let us not underestimate the power we each possess as individuals, for it is within our reach to make a difference. Educate yourself about the complexities of the situation, share information to raise awareness and contact local representatives. Let us never forget that every life lost is a piercing reminder of our responsibility to strive for a world where peace, justice, and understanding prevail.

I‚Äôve been stunned and saddened about the horrific terrorist attacks against Israel, the senseless loss of life and people being taken hostage, and all of the tragic killings the actions of Hamas have catapulted into action in both Israel and Gaza.  I have not known what to say or do, except research how to effectively stand with my Jewish friends while also looking for ways to help innocent Palestinian children. At first, I donated to the USO because they sent me an email. While that can‚Äôt hurt, it sure didn‚Äôt feel like enough, so I asked one of my best friends who is Jewish and has been hurting tremendously. You break her heart, you break mine. You attack her family, you attack mine. 

She suggested jgive.com. I donated to their National Emergency Fund. (Tip: Change the site to English in the upper left dropdown, and $s). All the donations collected will be distributed to Israeli charities that offer relief services, welfare, equipment, food and other necessities to the victims of the war and their families.  I‚Äôll share more options on Instagram stories. 

I invite comments by those that have done research and want to share with others how they can help. 

While you, like me, may not be qualified to comment on the conflict, or say or post the right. thing, we are human to suffer when other humans suffer. We are more human when we don‚Äôt let others suffer alone. To all of my friends hurting, I am sorry, and I hurt when you hurt. 

There is too much hate in the world, and surely, this a time for more love. Consider that when commenting on this post and any other.

Happy 248th Birthday, United States Navy! ü•≥

248 years of Power, Presence, and Protection

The U.S. Navy is always ready to defend our shores, maintain sea control, and protect our national security and economic interests. 

We are 100% on watch 24 hours a day, seven days a week‚Äîand have been for 247 years.

Since our Nation‚Äôs founding, through peace, war, and every challenge in between, the U.S. Navy has stood the watch to protect America‚Äôs economic vitality, sustain our Nation‚Äôs influence, support our Allies and partners, deter conflict, and when called upon, defended our freedom through combat.

For generations, a strong Navy has ensured American influence across the world, expanded economic opportunities for the American people, and guaranteed the rules-based order underpinning global security and prosperity.

#NavyBirthday

The Conflict Resolution Time Machine provides a framework to help all members of a family or classroom learn to resolve conflict peacefully. The Time Machine process starts with the steps of calming and wishing well before trying to resolve conflict. Both individuals must be in a calm, integrated Executive State in order to problem-solve and learn. Both parties then learn the assertive language to get their needs met. Finally, they share a connecting activity that shows the relationship is still whole.

Learn more and purchase your own Time Machine mat for your home or school by clicking the link in our bio @consciousdiscipline #iHeartCD #consciousdiscipline #timemachine #consciousparenting #conflictresolution

President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa has expressed readiness to mediate in the Israel-Palestinian conflict. 

He has called for an immediate ceasefire and cited South Africa's experience in conflict resolution within Africa and globally. 

President Ramaphosa expressed deep concern over the atrocities against civilians and urged the immediate and unconditional opening of humanitarian corridors to reach those in need.

Israeli authorities have cut off electricity, water, and fuel supplies to the Gaza Strip, with the condition that they will only end the blockade once all Israeli hostages are returned.

The African lion is listed as vulnerable on the IUCN red list of threatened species - their population has decreased by 75% in just five decades. Increasing human populations reduce available lion habitat, leading to a rise in human-lion conflict. Science and research are essential if we are to preserve future lion populations.

The @‚Äåsactrust (SACT), @tkpp_wildcru (TKPP) and Nelson Mandela University require GPS satellite collars to track the natural movement of lions between protected areas and develop lion management plans. These collars provide data to computer simulations that allow TKPP to monitor lion prides situated on park boundaries. They also provide an early-warning system to local communities about the whereabouts of lions and allow them to react quickly to potential problems and avoid human-lion conflict.

Find out more about sponsoring a lion collar and what your sponsorship will include under the 'Collar a lion' tab in our bio link.

I am deeply concerned for the innocent people on both sides of this conflict. I fear for a massacre of the innocent Palestinians. Not all of them support Hamas. I am worried that people are not well informed. There is a lot happening rather quickly. It‚Äôs sometimes difficult to know where the truth lies. News travels fast these days in the age of social media. We have already learned this is an easy way to receive fake news. I urge everyone to exercise caution here. Hamas is the enemy. Not all Palestinians support Hamas. It‚Äôs important we know the difference. 

I pray for the innocent people of Israel who have been subjected to this hate that has gone on for far too long now. It‚Äôs unacceptable to me. Something must be done to combat that. It‚Äôs how that is done that concerns me as a ground war seems all but inevitable at this point. I can not help but consider the innocent Palestinians, who don‚Äôt support Hamas nor have hate towards the Jews. These people are literally and figuratively caught in this middle here.

 I hate wars because too often innocent people become victims and that doesn‚Äôt sit well in my heart. I wish I had the answers, however, the truth is I don‚Äôt. I‚Äôm not sure my thoughts here will matter to anyone else, yet I felt the need to express them nonetheless. I hope you don‚Äôt mind and more importantly I hope you don‚Äôt take offense to my sentiments. It‚Äôs certainly not what I want to happen and yet to be honest it‚Äôs a fear I have as I prepare to let go of this statement.  My intentions are good ones and I certainly hope it comes across that way to everyone who has taken the time to read this üôè‚ù§Ô∏è

Workshop on ‚ÄòMatrix of JustPeace‚Äô at Patkai

Patkai:

The Department of Mass Communication, Patkai Christian College (Autonomous) organised a workshop on ‚ÄúMatrix of JustPeace‚Äù on Friday, October 13 with Dr. Ak√ºm Longchari, peace and conflict activist and publisher/editor of The Morung Express, as resource person.

During the day-long workshop, Dr. Longchari engaged the students in several exercises as he broke down concepts of conflict, power, power dynamics, how it manifests in society, peace, justice, and JustPeace.

He pointed out that most nation-state approach peace from a security perspective and so there is a lot of investments on defence and law enforcement whereas there is little investment in peace studies. ‚ÄúIf there is a need to approach peace from a security perspective, it should be from a human security perspective,‚Äù he asserted.

Dr. Longchari said that conflict affects four dimensions of life ‚Äî personal, relational, structures and culture. When there is a conflict, it changes the person, their relationships, existing structures and their attitudes and behaviours, he explained. 

He argued that to achieve JustPeace, one should look at truth, mercy, justice and peace as the anchor points.

The Iranian Foreign Minister, Hussein Amir Abdullahian, issued a warning from Beirut, indicating that the ongoing Israeli attacks against Palestinians will not go unanswered. He mentioned that crimes against Palestinians could trigger a response from other factions, referring to them as the "rest of the axis," with Israel bearing responsibility for the consequences.
This statement suggests the possibility of an escalation of an already tense situation, including the potential for opening new fronts in the conflict, particularly in Lebanon. 
Abdullahian's arrival in Beirut was welcomed by representatives of Hamas, Islamic Jihad, the Lebanese Foreign Ministry, and representatives of Hezbollah and the Amal Movement.
Meanwhile, Abdullahian met with the acting Prime Minister, Najib Mikati, today, where he called for maintaining calm and security in Lebanon. Mikati, in turn, emphasized the need for all parties to make diplomatic efforts to stop the events in Gaza and protect Lebanon.

Hyderabad, Oct 13 (IANS) A group of women students staging a protest to express solidarity with Palestinians here on Friday, were detained by police.

Raising slogans denouncing Israel for its bombardment of Gaza, they gathered at B. R. Ambedkar statue near Tank Bund in the heart of the city.

They were carrying a placard reading "Long live Palestine".

The police detained the protestors who were raising slogans "down down Israel". The police personnel were seen taking away the protestors in a police vehicle.

A police officer said there was no permission for the protest. This was the first protest in Hyderabad since the latest conflict between Israel and Palestine began last week.

Activists have condemned the police action. "The shrinking spaces for protests in Telangana is a indication of police authoritarianism in Telangana," wrote Srinivas Kodali on 'X' (formerly Twitter).

ü¶í This is the last weekend to see Brett's 'Zoo' and 'Christie' series before they go for a break.

The ‚ÄòZoo‚Äô and ‚ÄòChristie‚Äô series were developed in London between 1964 and 1965 and show Brett‚Äôs interest in the duality of the human psyche: the conflicting and coexisting animal instinct and human rationality. The caged animals in the London Zoo inspired the first series, and the creepy accounts of the serial murders committed by John Christie in London between January and March 1953 were the subject of the latter body of work. The current display brings this conversation/conflict to life once again; a unique opportunity for visitors to revisit Brett‚Äôs interests during those days.

After this weekend, the smaller gallery space on the Studio's ground floor will receive a changeover, and between 19 October and 26 November the space will showcase this year's Brett Whiteley Travelling Art Scholarship recipient and finalist works.

The rest of 'Chapters 1959‚Äì69' ‚Äì the Studio's current exhibition ‚Äì will remain on display during the Scholarship's show.

We are open Thursday ‚Äì Sunday between 10am and 4pm with free entry. Come along this weekend for Brett's early works, then return from 19 Oct to see the new generation of Australian painters.

__

Images: Installation views of ‚ÄòChapters 1959-69‚Äô at the Brett Whiteley Studio, Surry Hills. Photo ¬© Art Galley of NSW, Mim Stirling

Doctors Without Borders is horrified by the brutal mass killing of civilians perpetrated by Hamas, and by the massive attacks on Gaza now being pursued by Israel. Doctors Without Borders calls for an immediate cessation to the indiscriminate bloodshed, the establishment of safe spaces and safe passage for people to reach them as a matter of urgency. 

People must be afforded safe access to essential supplies like food and water and health facilities. Essential humanitarian supplies like medicine, medical equipment, food, fuel and water must also be allowed to enter the Gaza enclave.

Cardinal Pietro Parolin, the Vatican‚Äôs secretary of state, condemned Hamas‚Äô Saturday terrorist attacks against Israel, called for peace in the Holy Land, and said the Vatican is ready to help mediate a peace agreement, in an¬†interview¬†published by Vatican News Friday. 

Parolin told Vatican News that the Hamas attacks were ‚Äúinhuman,‚Äù and that the Holy See expresses ‚Äúcomplete and firm condemnation.‚Äù¬† 

He also expressed the Vatican‚Äôs concern for the civilians in Gaza and the ‚Äúmen, women, children, and the elderly held hostage.‚Äù 

‚ÄúIt is necessary,‚Äù Parolin said, ‚Äúto regain a sense of reason, abandon the blind logic of hatred, and reject violence as a solution. It is the right of those who are attacked to defend themselves, but even legitimate defense must respect the parameter of proportionality.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do not know how much room for dialogue there can be between Israel and the Hamas militia,‚Äù Parolin said. ‚ÄúBut if there is ‚Äî and we hope there is ‚Äî it should be pursued immediately and without delay.‚Äù He said that the Holy See is ‚Äúready for any necessary mediation.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe greatest possible justice in the Holy Land,‚Äù Parolin claimed, ‚Äúis the two-state solution, which would allow Palestinians and Israelis to live side by side in peace and security, meeting the aspirations of the majority.‚Äù

"However, any mediation to end the conflict must take into account a series of elements that make the issue very complex and articulated, such as the issue of Israeli settlements, security, and the issue of the city of Jerusalem," he said. 

‚ÄúA solution can be found in direct dialogue between Palestinians and Israelis, encouraged and supported by the international community, even though it will be more difficult now,‚Äù Parolin said. Parolin also expressed special concern for the Christians in Israel and in the Gaza Strip.¬†

‚ÄúChristians are an essential part of the land where Jesus was born, lived, died, and rose again,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNo one can imagine Palestine or Israel without a Christian presence, which has been there from the beginning and will be there forever.‚Äù (Read more below)

I‚Äôm consumed with sadness and concern for everyone in Palestine and Israel these days, especially all the wonderful people who welcomed me into their homes and lives in the occupied West Bank.
