I grieve for all the innocent civilians who have lost their lives in this devastating conflict. Opposing occupation and condemning terrorism against civilians should go hand in hand and never be seen as mutually exclusive.

Hundreds of people in pro-Israeli and pro-Palestinian groups gathered in Monument Circle Thursday night to show support for their respective sides in the Middle East conflict.

On one side of Monument Circle, a pro-Palestinian group called for an end to the Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip.

On the other, a group of pro-Israel counter-protestors gathered to show their support for the country following a violent attack from the terrorist group Hamas last weekend.

Malkah Bird is a member of Jewish Voice for Peace Indiana and helped organize the pro-Palestinian event.

‚ÄúOur goal tonight is just to show there is a place where everybody can live peacefully. It does not have to be one or the other,‚Äù she said.

Bird called for the U.S. to de-escalate the conflict and create a ceasefire.

Protestors said that Gaza is experiencing a humanitarian crisis. Israel has cut off food, water, fuel, and electricity in retaliation for the attack Hamas carried out in Israel's southern towns that left at least 1,300 people dead, NPR reported.

Mohammad Abu Hummos, a Fishers resident with the Palestinian Youth Movement, said he worries for his family members in Palestine.

‚ÄúThey have been in a hallway for an entire week because they don‚Äôt want to risk the chance of mourning each other,‚Äù he said. ‚Äú...I haven‚Äôt had time to process the entire thing so I can be here for my community and give them this outlet to come out today.‚Äù

Across the circle, Marina Teremets, an Israeli resident, is part of a counter-protest. She was visiting Indianapolis when her flight home was canceled because of the conflict.

‚ÄúWe heard this pro-Palestinian thing is happening and no representation on the Israeli side and that‚Äôs the least we can do for our country,‚Äù she said. ‚Äú...We don‚Äôt know how long to rent Airbnbs for, how long to rent cars for ‚Äî we just don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

Allon Friedman, who helped organize the pro-Israel rally with the Jewish American Affairs Committee of Indiana, denied it was specifically in response to the pro-Palestinian event across the plaza. 

Reporting: BENJAMIN THORP

McDonald's Peace Theory is not widely recognized, but rather a concept often associated with the term "McDonald's Peace" or the "Golden Arches Theory of Conflict Prevention." This idea, often attributed to journalist and author Thomas L. Friedman is an informal theory that suggests that countries with McDonald's franchises are less likely to go to war with each other.
The underlying notion is that countries with a middle class large enough to support a McDonald's restaurant and other elements of globalization are less inclined to engage in conflict with one another. The theory is based on the idea that globalization, economic interdependence, and cultural exchange created by companies like McDonald's promote peaceful relations between countries, as war could disrupt the economic ties and cultural exchange that have been fostered. It is important to remember that correlation does not mean causation. Friedman‚Äôs theory, although humorous at first, is a hauntingly accurate indication of the connection that trade holds with peace. The more rational explanation of this phenomenon is that countries with McDonald‚Äôs in them tend to be more economically developed and open to trade. This is because, for a business to invest a large amount of capital, the region must be stable, or else there is a high risk of losing that investment. 
It's important to note that the McDonald's Peace theory is more of an observation than a formal academic theory, and it has been met with both support and criticism. Some argue that economic and cultural factors play a role in reducing the likelihood of conflict between countries, while others point out that the theory oversimplifies the complex dynamics of international relations and conflicts. Regardless, it serves as a popular and accessible way to discuss the potential impact of economic and cultural ties on global peace.

Here‚Äôs half of my face for the algorithm. Just popping in to say no matter your faith, no matter your heritage, please light a candle or do whatever you can to hold space for the people of Palestine right now. I fear the worst for them as their neighborhoods, homes, and family members are turned to dust before our very eyes.

I am of Jewish decent, among other things. My father was raised a Jew, my mother a Roman Catholic, and they did not dictate for me a specific faith tradition. But I am alive today in part because my Jewish ancestors were clever, spry, or lucky enough to evade persecution.  I say that for context, but the truth is that being Jewish (or Jew-ish in my case) is not the only qualifier for speaking out against what is happening to Palestinians right now. This is genocide. Full stop. And if you live in the US and you pay your taxes, you are funding it. 

It IS NOT antisemitic to speak out against the siege in Gaza, to call out the Israeli government for ruling Palestinians under apartheid, or to oppose the colonization of Palestine by Israelis. The UN has condemned the actions of the Israeli government as war crimes over and over again.  It is possible to love and care for a group of people and disagree with the tactics of a government charged with representing them. Netanyahu‚Äôs approval ratings were extremely low even among Israeli‚Äôs leading up to the events of the last week. 

A member of my family has already told me they no longer respect me for posting the video I posted yesterday. The video features a Jewish American author who compassionately innumerates the offenses committed by the Israeli government. The author didn‚Äôt spout any hateful rhetoric, they simply spoke out as a Jew against the documented actions of the Israeli government and its military while also condemning Hamas.

It is precisely because I love and respect my family that I have to tell them to consider another point of view.  You can love someone and call them out on hypocrisy.  Never again means never again for everyone.  I‚Äôm sending light to all affected by this conflict. May it offer clarity, warmth, and comfort through this dark time.

It‚Äôs taken me a long time to process what‚Äôs been happening in the Middle East over the last few days.

As a Jew I am appalled by the massacres in Israel of a lot of people who were actually working towards peace with Palestinians and were murdered in cold blood. As a humanitarian I am also appalled by what is happening in Gaza and what has been happening to Palestinians for decades. 

With that said I don‚Äôt want to talk about sides I want to talk about all the mis Information I‚Äôm seeing on social media. There are too many of what I call "Graduates of the University of Google‚Äù. Please do your research. Please don‚Äôt just post some thing, just because you think it will support your argument, without actually researching  facts and educating yourself. Honestly has anyone ever seen someone win an argument on social media? The only real winners are the owners of these platforms whose business thrive on promoting discourse. 

So instead of us wasting our time being armchair experts from the comfort of our homes - we need to go out and do something positive and constructive for the cause we support - and work towards peace for both sides. Because at the end of all this horrific tragedy there has to be peace and hope. We need to get rid of the evil on both sides, that has driven us into this situation. 

I‚Äôd also like to address some misinterpretations that I keep seeing. 
Not all Zionists are Jews and not all Jews are Zionists. 
Not  all Palestinians are Hamas, besides Muslim Palestinians they were also Christians, Druze, and yes even some Jews. 
Not  all Israelis are Jews and they are not all originally from Eastern Europe, many are from North Africa and the Middle East. There are also Arab Israeli‚Äôs who are Muslim & Christians, plus a small population of Armenians, Circassians to name a few.

Let's put our energy into something positive In this terrible terrible terrible time. I have posted some charities to contribute to whatever side you support (links in bio) I wish you all peace and and pray for a quick resolution and a real long-term solution to this conflict. #peaceinthemiddleeast #tikkunolam

Condemning hate; Supporting one another (message from Thursday evening, 10/12): "I write with a heavy heart as I, like many in our community, continue to reflect on Israel and Gaza, the deaths of innocent victims and the unfolding humanitarian crisis.

First, we condemn the unspeakable atrocities perpetrated last weekend, along with all acts of antisemitism and hatred. 

We are also saddened for all families who are impacted in some way by the escalating conflict, including those with familial, cultural and spiritual ties to Israel and Gaza who live among us right here in Chapel Hill and Carrboro. I am thinking in particular of our students, their families and our staff members here at home, who are processing these tragic events. 

We recognize that our Jewish and Muslim students, families and staff may feel the ripple effects of this in different ways. We also recognize there are varied opinions, views and perspectives about how a school district should respond. The purpose of my message is to share with each of you that we‚Äôre watching and listening, and we will steadfastly support the peace, safety and wellbeing for all who call this community home. It‚Äôs why I think our role as a district is to share a message about the importance of wholeheartedly looking out for one another during this time, and where you can consider turning for additional support. 

Please know that our district‚Äôs School Support and Wellness teams are prepared to offer their support to students and staff. If you or someone you know is struggling, please don‚Äôt hesitate to speak with a trusted adult at school. 

Thank you for reading, and I offer my gratitude to all who have shared (either with me, or with our schools) their life experiences and thoughtful perspectives as we address the impact here at home. In closing, our schools must always be places of joy and kindness, where we value the diverse backgrounds that make us a community.

Through the anguish and grief, we will support one another."

Sincerely,

Nyah D. Hamlett, Ed. D.
Superintendent

I maintain hope in the next generation's ability to address the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and achieve the peace that eluded my generation. In 2014, I launched "Pathways to Peace" at the University of Illinois @ictrueblue in collaboration with President Jimmy Carter @CarterCenter. This initiative engaged young minds from diverse academic backgrounds in seeking solutions, redefining the conflict, supporting Palestinian rights, proposing a two-state solution, promoting cultural interaction, and revising school curricula to address historical trauma. It not only presented potential solutions but also inspired young leaders to contribute to justice, conflict resolution, and peace. We continue working to bridge differences, propose peaceful solutions, and pursue peace and justice in our region and worldwide. #Palestine #Israel #pathways_to_peace

Through the well-mannered comedy, Salute presents people coming together in the face of uncertain times ahead. 

Set to the irresistible sway of Hans Christian Lumbye‚Äôs waltzes and polkas, links to the nineteenth century continue in how Kobborg uses his Danish heritage as a departure point for Salute, taking elements of Bournonville style and restating them anew for contemporary audiences. A loose story illustrates the relationship between soldiers and the women they leave behind before going off to war; danced vignettes imbued with the blithe innocence of youth feature a comically blustering general and a recruit who isn‚Äôt exactly what they seem.

Times of conflict do not usually give us pause for pleasure, but Johan Kobborg‚Äôs Salute takes something of the gallantry and honor we associate with warfare in bygone times to create a good-humored ballet that is a lighthearted vehicle to display the dancers‚Äô expressive abilities and comic timing.

The US Secretary of State Antony Blinken‚Äôs press conference on Thursday concluding his visit to Israel conveyed three things. One, the Biden Administration will be seen as backing Israel to the hilt by way of meeting its security needs but Washington will not be drawn into the forthcoming Gaza operations except to arrange exit routes in the south for hapless civilians fleeing the conflict zone. Two, Washington‚Äôs top priority at the moment is on engaging with the regional states who wield influence with Hamas to negotiate the hostage issue. Fourteen US citizens in Israel remain unaccounted for. (White House confirmed that the death toll in the fighting now includes at least 27 Americans.)

Three, the US will coordinate with the regional states to prevent any escalation in the situation to widen the conflict on the part of Hezbollah. Although the US cannot and will not stop Israeli leadership on its tracks apropos the imminent Gaza operation, it remains unconvinced. Blinken was non-committal about any direct US military involvement, and the chances are slim as things stand. Most important, even as Blinken could hear the war drums, he also cast his eye on a future for Israel (and the region) where it will be at peace with itself, would integrate into the region and concentrate on creating economic prosperity ‚Äî metaphorically put, beating its swords into plowshares in a Biblical Messianic intent.
M.K.BHADRAKUMAR writes

Ben Shapiro faces backlash after posting 'AI image of burnt Israeli baby'

13 October, 2023

Ben Shapiro faces criticism for sharing an AI-generated image falsely portrayed as a "burnt Jewish baby" following Hamas' attack on Israel, highlighting the spread of misinformation during the Israel-Gaza conflict.

Conservative American columnist Ben Shapiro has faced backlash over the image he shared [Getty]

Right-wing American¬†columnist Ben Shapiro has faced backlash over an image he shared purporting to show a "burnt Jewish baby" after Saturday's attack by Hamas fighters on Israel.
Shapiro‚Äôs post on social media platform X triggered a note warning that the image was generated by artificial intelligence (AI).
The image was confirmed to be AI-generated via the image authenticity detection site aiornot.com, as highlighted by many social media users.
Social media personality Jackson Hinkle was quick to point out Shapiro's alleged deception,¬†posting on X:¬†"The image that Ben Shapiro tried to pass off as a 'burnt baby corpse' was an AI-generated fake image!"

Another X user also accused Shapiro of using a fake image to defend Israel's relentless bombardment and total siege of Gaza, which has so far killed over 1,750 Palestinians, including over 500 children.
Shapiro denied the accusations and claimed that AI content detectors were not always accurate.

"The trigger in our minds for all the dominoes to fall is for Israel to cross into Gaza," Dale Buckner, retired US Army colonel and CEO of the global security firm Global Guardian, told Insider.

"If Israel makes the decision that it's going to attack Gaza in some shape or form ‚Äî whether that's from sea, air, or ground ‚Äî then this escalates materially because now you have all the different cells that Iran backs throughout the region," he said.

Over the weekend, Hamas launched a surprise attack on Israel. Israel said 1,300 people were killed and more than 100 people were taken hostage.

On Sunday, Israel declared a state of war and a day later announced a "complete siege" of Gaza. Israel's retaliations have left more than 1,500 people dead as of Friday, the Palestinian health ministry said.

Late on Thursday, Israel said that civilians living in northern Gaza needed to evacuate the area within 24 hours, suggesting that a large-scale attack could be imminent.

Buckner pointed to signs of escalations across Israel's borders that could tilt a possible Israeli-Hamas war into a regional conflict.

In the north, the Iranian-backed Lebanese militant group Hezbollah launched dozens of rockets and shells against Israeli positions on Sunday in a contested region along the border with the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights.

While in the south, Israeli forces have bombed the crossings of food, medicine, and fuel deliveries from Egypt into Gaza.

Having served as a US Army veteran for 24 years, Buckner said he knows "these escalations have a way of taking life on their own, and that's the risk here."

Israel's incursion into Gaza could create a "domino effect" that triggers all its neighbors in the region to join the conflict, Buckner said.

Hussein Ibish, a senior fellow at the Washington-based Arab Gulf States Institute, made a similar point to The Washington Post.

"This could easily get out of control," he told the newspaper, adding: "Everything is in place for a cascading series of events that will culminate in Israel attacking Iran."

For anyone curious about what the orthodox rabbi making the rounds believes in: 

‚ÄúWhich brings us to one of the more bizarre intellectual outgrowths on the gnarled tree of the Middle East conflict: Neturei Karta.

Chances are you have seen these guys. At any major pro-Palestinian rally, BDS protest or Khomeinist Quds Day march you can‚Äôt miss them: that group of ultra-orthodox Jews, replete with black hats and side curls, always at the frontline and always among those shouting the loudest.

This in itself isn‚Äôt newsworthy. Plenty of Jews throughout Israel and the diaspora actively campaign for Palestinian rights. What marks Neturei Karta out, and earns them so much controversy, is their savagely extremist tone, and the lengths they are willing to go to spread the anti-Zionist message.

Most Western pro-Palestinians operate somewhere between vague support of a two-state solution and actively boycotting Sabra Hummus, but they would (or perhaps should) balk at marching alongside openly racist, genocidal organizations like Hamas or Hezbollah. Neturei Karta, on the other hand, traveled to Gaza in person to hang out with Ismail Haniyeh and offer Hamas material and moral support. When Mahmoud Ahmadinejad hosted his ‚ÄúReview of the Holocaust‚Äù conference in Tehran, featuring keynotes from Ku Klux Klan grandee David Duke and Holocaust deniers Robert Faurisson and Michele Renouf, Neturei Karta were there front and centre. Nor do they confine themselves to fascists in the Middle East. Neturei Karta rabbis have spoken alongside the out-and-out anti-semites of Hungary‚Äôs Jobbik party as well as British far-right groups.

Meanwhile, they even managed to put in a star turn at the launch of former MP George Galloway's bid to become mayor of London.

This seemingly perverse incongruity has earned the sect bewilderment from liberal activists and observers, and loathing, revulsion and anathema from broad swathes of mainstream Jewry.

So, what makes a group of ultra-orthodox Jews utterly dedicate their lives to bringing down the world‚Äôs one Jewish state? What drives them to ally with Hamas, which in the past has described their people as, ‚Äúthe most despicable people on the face of the

Like Middle East wars of the past, the conflict between Israel and Hamas that broke out this past week has the potential to disrupt the world economy ‚Äî and even tip it into recession if more countries are drawn in.
‚Å£
That risk is real, as Israel‚Äôs army prepares to invade Gaza in response to an attack by the militant group. The death toll from the Hamas assault and the ongoing Israeli air strikes on Gaza is already in the thousands. There‚Äôs concern that militias in Lebanon and Syria that support Hamas will join the fighting.‚Å£
‚Å£
A sharper escalation could bring Israel into direct conflict with Iran, a supplier of arms and money to Hamas, which the US and the European Union have designated a terrorist group. In that scenario, Bloomberg Economics estimates oil prices could soar to $150 a barrel and global growth drop to 1.7% ‚Äî a recession that takes about $1 trillion off world output. Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å£
‚Å£

Bitcoin Price Prediction: BTC Slips 3% as Cryptocurrency Market Reacts to CPI Data as JPMorgan Awaits SEC's ETF Verdict

The Consumer Price Index (CPI) data has recently stirred reactions in the crypto space, causing BTC to slip by 3%. As this unfolds, JPMorgan awaits the SEC's verdict on the ETF, poised to be a major determinant of Bitcoin's short-term price trajectory.
 
Adding another layer to the regulatory landscape, the looming deadline for the SEC to address its August 29 setback against Grayscale approaches, with the Commission having only until midnight on Friday to respond. 

The escalating conflict in the Middle East raises concerns for the digital currency industry. Recognizing the situation's urgency, Coinbase's CEO appeals to Congress, emphasizing the need for prompt and rational cryptocurrency legislation in these tumultuous times.

Grayscale vs SEC: Friday Midnight Deadline Looms for August 29 Challenge

Grayscale Investments achieved a significant legal victory when the D.C. Circuit Court ruled in their favour on August 29, allowing them to convert their Bitcoin Trust (GBTC) into an Exchange-traded fund (ETF). 

The court found that the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) had arbitrarily and capriciously denied the proposal. 

The SEC was given a 45-day window to appeal, with the deadline set for October 13 at midnight. If the SEC chooses not to appeal, it is equivalent to approval, potentially paving the way for the first spot Bitcoin ETF in the US.

However, the market speculates that alternative arguments could be used to reject the ETF, possibly related to Coinbase's involvement. The outcome could affect the cryptocurrency market, with potential sell pressure.

Amidst Middle East Tensions, Coinbase CEO Pushes for Swift Crypto Legislation

Coinbase's Chief Legal Officer, Paul Grewal, has urged the US Congress to promptly enact sensible cryptocurrency legislation as the Middle East conflict escalates.

We are aware of recent statements made calling for action as it relates to the conflict in the Middle East. We have no information of any specific or credible threats in our areas and are continuing to assess the situation for any local impact in Los Angeles County.

We are closely monitoring the situation and frequently communicating with our local, state, and federal government partners to share information. We are conducting extra patrol checks and reaching out to our local religious communities to reassure them during this tumultuous time.

We urge the community who attend demonstrations to remain calm and peaceful. The safety and security of all our communities is our number one priority. We remind residents to stay vigilant and report anything suspicious to local law enforcement officials.

- Los Angeles County Sheriff Robert Luna

The Department of International Relations and Cooperation (Dirco) says it‚Äôs been notified that two South Africans have been killed in the conflict currently gripping the Middle East.

In the early hours of Saturday morning, the militant wing of Hamas launched a surprise attack on Israel from Gaza.

The conflict has since descended into a full-blown war, with Israel unleashing a barrage of rockets on Gaza in response.

Thousands have been killed so far.

Dirco spokesperson, Clayson Monyela: "The Department of International Relations and Cooperation can confirm that we have been notified that two South African nationals have died in this ongoing conflict between Palestine and Israel. The verification process is currently underway because one of the individuals is reported to have an Israeli ID number, so we need to determine whether there is dual citizenship or what the picture is."

These people are Arabian/Syrian. The "Palestinian" identity is a relatively new one for them, it's their right to identify as Palestinian, but it doesn't mean these are the same people who have been in that region for thousands of years, because they haven't. 

All Palestine ever was, was a district in that land, which was mainly called Syria.

PS: If I'm wrong, correct me. I'm always willing to learn and clearly not always right. Does anyone have any type of flag, or emblem that Palestinians have had for thousands of years? Does anyone know the name of any King that these people have had? As far as I know there's nothing and they literally copied the Jordanian flag.

Reflecting on the words of Judith Butler, we are reminded of how power and precariousness are always inextricably linked. 

We are reminded of our interdependence as human beings, despite our profound differences.

We hold close in our hearts the growing number of innocent victims in both Israel and Palestine. We mourn these casualties of a conflict rooted in incalculable generational trauma and suffering and the present trauma of terror across the region.

All people deserve freedom, dignity, safety, and protection from the violence of occupation and war. 

May we all have the strength and courage to move beyond the impulse of fear and isolation.

May we find ways to ground deeper into our bodies, to connect to each of our own precarious lives in ways that allow for greater compassion and connection to ourselves and others.

May we join together in pursuit of peace and stability, an end to the attacks against Palestine and an end to the justification of any and all terror falsely committed in the name of liberation.

May peace prevail.

üá¨üáß Within a joint project, His Majesty‚Äôs Ambassador to Azerbaijan Fergus Auld and @undpazerbaijan Resident Representative a.i. Alessandra Roccasalvo visited Barda. The purpose of the visit was to meet with staff and active members of the Women's Resource Center in Barda, as well as visit women who have built successful businesses within the project.

During the visit, Ms. Roccasalvo and Ambassador Auld first met with the head of the Barda region Executive Committee Vidadi Isayev. The guests also met with the members of the Women's Resource Center and listened to their stories. The event was ended by a visit to 3 successful women who established their own small enterprises.

The visit was organized as part of the ‚ÄúEmpowering and creating equal opportunities for vulnerable, conflict affected women in Azerbaijan to overcome barriers towards greater economic and social participation (ECEO)‚Äù project implemented by UNDP and the State Committee for Family, Women and Children Affairs with the support of the UK Government.

Reminder for visitors to the popular Samish River Unit of Skagit Wildlife Area, commonly known as the East 90 or Edison site: there are now specific zones for different recreation opportunities to support quality experiences and safety during hunting season. These rules began during the 2022-23 season and are in place Oct. 14, 2023 through Feb. 3, 2024.

There is a Hunters Only Zone that is the southern and eastern portion of the property encompassing the Edison West (371) and Edison East (372) hunting access sites, and a wildlife viewing zone outside the Hunters Only Zone. The Hunters Only Zone includes a safety buffer of approximately 250 yards.

All users in the Hunters Only Zone must park in the designated parking spot and follow all posted rules for their designated area including being fully licensed as a Washington hunter.

The new access rules are posted at the field entrances and there is increased signage at the boundary of the Hunters Only Zone. Violations of these site rules may be subject to prosecution under the Revised Code of Washington.

This is a seasonal access rule, applying from the beginning of the general waterfowl hunting season and running through the first Saturday in February. Spatially separating user groups on this small Wildlife Area Unit will increase safety and improve experiences for all users while reducing the potential for negative interactions or conflict.

Photo: Google Earth satellite image and map of Hunters Only Zone. To learn more, visit the Samish River Wildlife Area Unit webpage at the link in our profile. #WDFWLands #SamishRiver #East90 #Samish #SkagitCounty

And don‚Äôt forget‚Ä¶ GO TRAIN. The world is in a strange place, but it‚Äôs been here before. The best thing anyone can do who‚Äôs not actively involved in conflict is start preparing like it‚Äôs coming. With conflict and natural disasters the most important thing you can have is a safe and secure place to hunker down. Have water and provisions available, and a way to get information from the outside world. Power outages in hospitals, refuge in bomb shelters, limited supplies‚Ä¶ etc. So if you are continuing to monitor social media this is the time to take notes. Items you need especially medical, tactics of invading forces/infiltrators, issues with mass evacuations‚Ä¶ everything in real time. Train like your life depends on it‚Ä¶ because it does.

We have the whispers of the divine serpent calling us to do the work of transformation. 

Pitr Paksha, the ancestral ritual portal ended on the cusp of a powerful and quite volatile solar eclipse. The eclipse was the threshold of Navaratri, the 9 nights & days of Devotion to the Divine Mother.

Yoga is a journey of interiorizing awareness for transformation and divine discovery. And this is what eclipses and NavarƒÅtri invite us to do. So take the cosmic invitation. 

At this time old patterns whip into the present - including ancestral themes and past lifetimes. Conflict, illusion, retaliation are some of the themes. But it is also a time of transformation and disentanglement. This time can also press us forward. The question is, in what way are we stepping forward?

This is a time - individually & collectively - to use spiritual wisdom, practice and remedy to work with our deep rooted unconscious patterns, called sa·πÉskƒÅra. 

To make right wise action, we have to make internal change. At the glob level this means system change and change amongst those in power. At the individual level this means inner transformation... letting go of old patterns and establishing new ones. 

For individuals, we call on yoga nidra and mantra to work at the samskara level and change the inner patterns. 

May we as a human family be divinely guided to respond deliberately & dharmically moment to moment. 

If you are a seeker on the path of yoga heed the call. 

Love, 
Kaya

nasoceana Happy 248th Birthday, United States Navy! ü•≥ 248 years of Power, Presence, and Protection The U.S. Navy is always ready to defend our shores, maintain sea control, and protect our national security and economic interests. We are 100% on watch 24 hours a day, seven days a week‚Äîand have been for 247 years. Since our Nation‚Äôs founding, through peace, war, and every challenge in between, the U.S. Navy has stood the watch to protect America‚Äôs economic vitality, sustain our Nation‚Äôs influence, support our Allies and partners, deter conflict, and when called upon, defended our freedom through combat. For generations, a strong Navy has ensured American influence across the world, expanded economic opportunities for the American people, and guaranteed the rules-based order underpinning global security and prosperity. #NavyBirthday #Navy #248yearsüá∫üá∏

I am so deeply proud of our composer and sound designer for RAGING GRACE @jon__clarke for winning BEST ORIGINAL COMPOSITION IN A FEATURE FILM @musicandsoundawards. It's about gaddamn time!! I asked for the impossible and he and his team delivered. It's not hyperbole when I say his work on this film is iconic ‚ù§Ô∏èüî•

How does one design a soundscape and score that encompasses the complexities and nuances of immigrant life in colonial society, the weight of generational trauma, and the struggle to belong in a hostile society all while sounding uniquely Filipino. Jon has created a sound and score more than the sum of its parts. When the budget could not afford the imagery, Jon‚Äôs sound and score painted the picture. Big sound and loud crashes are to be expected in horror films but Jon‚Äôs  use of silence was just as effective. To achieve the authenticity I wanted, he used uniquely Filipino sounds and instruments like the tropical clacks of Tinikling bamboos and the brass gongs of the Kulingtan. I had never heard of that instrument before but there was a specificity to his choice that elevated everything. He chose the Kulingtan to reflect Joy and Grace‚Äôs place in society. The sound it produces does not fit within any western music scale but Jon found a way to have them exist in unison with western instruments but also utilised their discordance to heighten conflict and horror. The result is truly incredible. It‚Äôs not hyperbole when I say what he‚Äôs done is iconic and like the film itself, his score simply hasn't been done before and he delivered spectacularly.

The people of Palestine and Israel are nobody‚Äôs enemy.

They are victims.

Caught in the crossfire of a decades long conflict‚Äîa centuries old tribal war. Stuck between the rock of Hamas and the hard place of Isreal. Bombarded by one, exploited and abused by the other. 

I do not care for your flags, your borders, your divide and conquer narratives; your ancient death-cults, or your endless war machine.

I care for people‚Äîhumans, like you or I. With hopes and dreams and children, like mine. 

Their deaths are needles in my spine.

I will not hate them for you.
I will not demonise them for you. 
I will not abandon my humanity for you.

I will not cheer when buildings fold. 
I will not sing songs of victory. 
I will not pump my fists to missile melodies. 
I will not froth at the mouth at the thought of vengeance.
I will not celebrate your wars.
I will not worship at your slaughterous altars. 

People are not my enemy.
Children are not my enemy.

I will not hate them for you.
I will not demonise them for you. 
I will not abandon my humanity for you.

Please comfort the families who have experienced and are currently experiencing indescribable loss, pain, trauma and the horrors of war that are happening in the Middle East. Please protect and shield the innocent lives of those caught in the middle of this ongoing conflict. May you touch the hearts of everyone involved and touch the hearts of world leaders to bring an end to the daily suffering taking place on both sides.

We know life is more precious to You than fine gold. Please create the capacity in us to center humanity first in this conflict and in conversations around the conflict in Palestine and Israel. Please soften our hearts for our fellow man, woman, and child and remind us that we are all precious and accepted in your sight. Help us to prioritize Life and the preservation of Life, no matter the background, religion, culture or creed. Allow whoever is reading this, to feel the sincerity of this prayer and the gentleness of this plea. Bless and bring supernatural comfort to the victims and the families of the victims in both Israel and Palestine. 

Help us to center Humanity today, tomorrow and always. 

In Your name we pray. Amen. üôè

This Sunday begins Navaratri - the nine night celebration of the Goddess Durga who awakens courage, the warrior of love and the sacred activist in all of us. She is one of the deities that I have the most potent connection with - and this time is always one of deep transformation and power for me. I am offering a practice over these days of chanting, meditation - with an opening and closing ceremony. I will share with you the mythology and we will have a group to connect to each other over the time. You will be invited to fast, let go of habits and create sacred space during this time. We will be offering up our energies and prayers to all who need it at this time - especially the souls passing in the Palestine/Isreal conflict and all those effected. Prayer isn‚Äôt enough but it is something. The mantras and the transmission open up this deep courage as we enter into the heart of transformation. If you want to join and connect with Durga, the info is in the link in my profile. You are welcome to join in this sacred practice. 
#durga #navaratri #sacredactivism #goddess #courage

212 Indians from Israel return home under 'Operation Ajay.

Operation Ajay was launched to facilitate our citizens who wish to come back.

New Delhi, Oct 13: Amid the ongoing war in Israel, at least 212 Indian citizens arrived in the national capital from the first flight under 'Operation Ajay'.

The first flight under the 'Operation Ajay' arrived in the national capital around 6 a.m.

and they were greeted by Union Minister Rajeev Chandrasekhar at the airport. The Minister also interacted with the students who returned from Tel Aviv to Delhi.The special flight with 212 people had left from Tel Aviv on Thursday for Delhi. 

Addressing a flurry of questions on the Israel-Palestine conflict, which escalated last week after the Hamas group launched rocket attacks on Tel Aviv, Ministry of External Affairs spokesperson Arindam Bagchi said that the government's prime focus is to bring back 18,000 Indians stuck there.

"Our focus is to bring back Indians who want to come out of Israel. There are 18,000 Indians there, including students," he said, informing that the government has launched 'Operation Ajay' to bring back Indian citizens from war-torn Israel.

"Yesterday, Operation Ajay was launched to facilitate our citizens who wish to come back. The first flight will reach Tel Aviv tonight and is likely to reach India tomorrow (Friday) with 230 people," Bagchi informed.

Open to discourse. And waiting for the bots to start trolling my comments. Hamas does not represent the voice the majority of wonderful Palestinian people. And if you‚Äôve never been to Israel, you can‚Äôt possibly understand the conflict. In Israel, Arabs and Jews live in peace. Work side by side. Eat at each others restaurants. Israel is one of the most modern, liberal and technologically advanced countries on the planet. Almost every one is touched by the technology advanced and pioneered by Israeli minds. Including that cell phone. Meanwhile. 10 miles away it‚Äôs a living hell hole. Same land. Same dirt. Same opportunity.

I interviewed a Palestinian journalist in Gaza City and an Israeli newspaper editor in Jerusalem for this week's Inside the Hive podcast. Here are a few clips. 

All of Israel "is one big war zone at the moment," @avimayer said. For journalists, it's "our duty to get these stories out to the world." We talked about the physical dangers and psychological toll of the war. And I asked about how our paths diverged, since, twenty years ago, we were both college freshmen in Maryland. In Jerusalem, he said, "there's a purpose to my presence here."

In Gaza, "it's really tragic and intense," @mohamhawish said, and "knowing that I can be a target at any moment is just very horrific." When I heard a child's voice in the background, I asked how his two year old is coping with the explosions in the distance. Mohammed said the worst part is not knowing how or when the conflict will end. "Entire families are being wiped out here," he said.

Hear the full podcast episode: listen.vanityfair.com/insidethehive

Message from Chancellor Carol Christ to the Berkeley campus community: 

We are increasingly concerned by the growing prevalence of online threats, doxxing and harassment connected to the conflict between Israel and Hamas. We decry any calls for violence in any form or support for terrorism as we continue to mourn the loss of innocent life. We understand this rhetoric is creating deep fear and concern among many members of our campus community. With that in mind, we want to share an extraordinary message, written by two of our faculty, one who is Palestinian and one who is Israeli:

To our students,

We are two professors on this campus who disagree, vehemently. But we have always treated one another with respect and dignity. We love this campus with its diverse communities and all of our students and are heartbroken to hear of incidents of near violence between students in recent days. We will not tolerate our students harming one another. Disagreement and differing points of view are an essential part of campus life, and we expect that you treat one another with the same respect and dignity that we are modeling here.

- Dr. Hatem Bazian (Lecturer of Middle Eastern Languages and Cultures and Asian American and Asian Diaspora Studies)
- Dr. Ron Hassner (Professor of Israel Studies)

We want to assure you that the campus is taking steps necessary to support public safety for all at events and protests related to the conflict and across the campus the general. 

Link in bio for full message, including information about Dealing with Threats and Harassment and links to Campus Support Resources.

Lakewood Station wants our residents to know that we are aware of recent statements made, calling for action, as it relates to the conflict in the Middle East. We have no information of any specific or credible threats in our area and are continuing to assess the situation for any local impact.

We will continue to closely monitor the situation and are frequently communicating with our local, state, and federal government partners to share information. As it relates to the area Lakewood Station serves, we are conducting extra patrol checks and reaching out to our local religious communities to reassure them during this tumultuous time.

We urge the community who attend demonstrations to remain calm and peaceful. The safety and security of all our communities is our number one priority. We remind residents to stay vigilant and report anything suspicious to (562) 623-3500. If you have any emergency, please call 911. 

Anonymous tips can be submitted by calling 1-800-222-8477, or by visiting www.lacrimestopper.org. 

Be safe everyone.

@paramountpublicsafety @lakewoodcity @Paramount_Posts @bellflower_city_hall #paramountpublicsafety #Bellflowercityhall @officialcityofArtesia #cityofArtesia @Hgcityca #hawaiiangardens @lasdhq #lasdhq

Something about the noise in the pencil marks does communicate a lot about what's going on in my head these days. 

Tensions are escalating, conflict is rising, the world is ending. And I don't know if this is going to get better or worse. If there is going to be relief from all this anger. I am praying for justice for the Palestinians, as we witness present day colonialism in the region. 

I am hoping for guidance and understanding amongst all this misinformation. It's easy to read a few Instagram posts and develop an opinion about the issue, but are you open to a different perspective? Have you really dug into the history of this conflict outside your social media time?  Emotions are high, and we know that's when we do our least rational thinking. 

I'd listen to all my friends, regardless of which side of the fight they're on, and really understand why they're hurting. It is not their fault that their families and loved ones are at the expense of this genocide. They want justice, they want to hold someone responsible. Many people don't want a part of this, and are just desperate to live normal lives with the absence of conflict. And then cue the propaganda, which further polarises our views, and we forget the one basic thing that we share - we are all human. We treat the other side as if they are animals, and dehumanize them before wishing them death. It's a disgusting side to humanity.

There is no bigger message here. I'm writing this to process what's going on in my head. To find the truth in the noise

King Philip IV ordered all the Knights Templar in the kingdom to be arrested, falsely accusing them of heresy. Accusing them of spitting on the Cross, deny the Divinity of Christ, worshipping a silver idol, sorcery and witchcraft. Strength and Honour, my Brother Templars.

Never forget the Martyrs of our Holy Order.

Israel: The situation in Israel is still unpredictable; mortar and rocket fire may take place without warning. Commercial flights are available but extremely limited. Some U.S. citizens have been successful departing Israel into Jordan via the border crossings, including Allenby Bridge. We encourage you to take advantage of those options if possible. 

The U.S. government is facilitating transportation for U.S. citizens to leave Israel by air or sea. Chartered transportation will be to nearby safe locations, not back to the United States. You will not be able to choose your destination or mode of transportation ‚Äì we will assign you to the next available departure. 

U.S. citizens who wish to depart with U.S. government assistance must express their interest via our crisis intake form at https://cacms.state.gov/s/crisis-intake. Do not fill out this form if you have already completed it. 

Gaza: The military conflict between Israel and Hamas is ongoing, making departure options for U.S. citizens complex. We are working on potential options for departure from Gaza for U.S. citizens. Please complete the crisis intake form at https://cacms.state.gov/s/crisis-intake to provide contact information should we need to reach out to you on short notice. We have U.S. government officials working 24/7 to try to assist. 

More at https://il.usembassy.gov/security-alert-7-u-s-embassy-jerusalem-october-13-2023/

On October 7th, Hamas, an internationally recognized terrorist organization currently in control of Gaza, launched its largest offensive against Israel in 'Operation Al-Aqsa Flood,' intensifying the enduring conflict between Israel and Palestine.

The Israeli-Palestinian conflict began a century ago when Jewish immigrants arrived in the British Mandate of Palestine, leading to tensions between local Arabs and Jewish settlers, each claiming Palestine as their homeland. The 1947 UN Partition Plan was accepted by Israel but rejected by Arab representatives, sparking the first Israeli-Palestinian war. The Six-Day War in 1967 resulted in Israel's occupation of Gaza and the West Bank. The 1973 Yom Kippur War was a significant turning point.

The Oslo Accords of 1993-1995 made progress toward a two-state solution, but support has waned. Palestinians oppose Israeli settlement policies and Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) actions, while Israel remains distrustful due to historical hostilities and terror attacks. Recent radical settlement policies and forced displacements under Benjamin Netanyahu's leadership exacerbated tensions. Hamas used these tensions to justify its recent attacks.

The Israeli government, which is led by sixth-time Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, turned increasingly radical in its settlement policy and therefore alienated the Palestinian population even further, which often entails the forced displacement of Palestinian residents from their homes, frequently with the assistance of the IDF and the government. Conversely, Israel's apprehension toward Palestine is rooted in a history marked by unanticipated hostilities, armed conflicts, and acts of terrorism perpetrated by Palestinians in Israel.

This incident was used by Hamas to justify their attack on Israel last week. Israel, which declared a state of war, was bombarded by thousands of rockets and attacks from land, air and sea, which left over a thousand Israelis and other nationalities dead and hundreds of hostages taken by Hamas.

Just some of the headlines as we mark day seven of this heartbreaking conflict in the Middle East‚Ä¶ one that affects America and has so many global concerns.

The human suffering is unimaginable, and our world changed overnight. 

Working in news, you become a nonstop student of what‚Äôs happening in the world. I‚Äôve always felt humbled and grateful to live a life of studies and insight to local national and world affairs.

It is with a heavy heart that I go about my day in Los Angeles, that I post on social media about normalcy here which is one largely of peace, safety, and security compared to this war torn region with the most gut wrenching of stories, and an unthinkable human tragedy. 

With this in mind, I am humbled, and in awe and grateful I get to do stories of people working to uplift humanity here in Southern California. Thank you, Fox 11 News for 30 years of that!üôè

My promise is to continue to be a student. To value this planet we live on. To commit to projects that work to uplift my fellow human. To love my friends and family, and those I meet along the way.üá∫üá∏

Tabatabai had the opportunity to shape the intelligence to meet her needs.



Last month I wrote about the revelations¬†involving Ariane Tabatabai,¬†currently the Chief of Staff to the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Special Operations and Low Intensity Conflict, who has a security clearance, but who emails show had collaborated with the Iranian regime.

In 2014, a year before Tabatabai began working as a NATO consultant, she joined an initiative by the Iranian Foreign Ministry to mobilize ‚ÄúIranians who have established affiliations with the leading international think-tanks and academic institutions, mainly in Europe and the US.‚Äù

Tabatabai, along with Dina Esfandiary, her co-author on the proposal to have the United States ally with Iran, who is currently a senior Middle East advisor to George Soros‚Äô Crisis Group, allegedly became members of the ‚Äúcore group‚Äù of Iran‚Äôs influence operation.

Before Tabatabai testified about the Iran Deal in Congress, she allegedly checked in with the head of an Iranian Foreign Ministry think tank. ‚ÄúI am scheduled to go to the Congress to give a talk about the nuclear program. I will bother you in the coming days,‚Äù she wrote.

Jennifer Van Laar at Red State reports¬†that sources have said that Tabatabai was sabotaging counterterrorism materials.

Counterterrorism analysts speaking to RedState on condition of anonymity, whose reports would have crossed Tabatabai‚Äôs desk, say that for at least the past year their product has been watered down, misquoted, or outright quashed. Tabatabai had the opportunity to shape the intelligence to meet her needs, the analysts say, and they say it‚Äôs likely that the overt intel collected during that period went to Iran.

Deeply troubling. Especially as the Biden administration has continued to stand by Tabatabai.

On Oct. 7, Hamas launched a surprise attack on Israel, utilizing sea, ground and air tactics. The attack led to around 900 Israeli casualties, 2,500 wounded and over 100 kidnapped. Palestinian casualties exceeded 1,000 in Gaza, with at least 11 American citizens killed, according to the U.S. State Department.

Jewish student organizations at UO expressed support for those affected, organizing vigils and prayers. Oregon politicians, including Senator Jeff Merkley and Congresswoman Val Hoyle, condemned Hamas's attacks and affirmed Israel's right to self-defense.

‚ÄúCitizens of Israel, we are at war,‚Äù Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said. ‚ÄúI convened the heads of the security establishment and ordered ‚Äì first of all ‚Äì to clear out the communities that have been infiltrated by terrorists.‚Äù

The conflict between Palestine, backed by Hamas, and Israel has deep historical roots, with the Oct. 7 attack marking another chapter in this ongoing strife. World leaders, such as President Joe Biden, condemned the attacks and advocated for Israel's right to defend itself, while international calls for diplomacy are increasing. 

This is a developing story.

The Union County Board of County Commissioners stands in solidarity with the nation of Israel, denouncing the recent attacks by the Hamas terrorist organization. These distressing events highlight the urgent need for lasting solutions that ensure the safety and well-being of all individuals, regardless of their background.

While Union County currently faces no immediate threats, the Union County Board of County Commissioners, Union County Sheriff Peter Corvelli, in collaboration with community members of faith, are taking a proactive approach and have collaborated to enhance security around houses of worship in response to the ongoing events in the Middle East.

‚ÄúOur commitment to creating an inclusive and unified community remains firm during these turbulent times,‚Äù said Commissioner Chairman Sergio Granados. ‚ÄúOur number one priority is the safety of our residents and we remain dedicated to providing a secure and welcoming environment for all community members. We pray for a swift and equitable resolution to the conflict, one that brings enduring peace and stability to the region, benefiting both Israelis and Palestinians.‚Äù

‚ÄúA dedicated team of officers will be offering additional security for houses of worship throughout Union County as an extra sense of peace for those who gather to worship, ensuring that they can do so without fear,‚Äù said Union County Sheriff Peter Corvelli. ‚ÄúAs the Sheriff of Union County, it is my duty to safeguard all of our residents, and this added layer of protection emphasizes our promise to that mission.‚Äù

The Union County Board of County Commissioners continue to share their thoughts and prayers to the people in the regions of both Israelis and Palestinians, as well as to all the victims and their families during this devastating time.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has vowed to ‚Äúcrush and destroy‚Äù the militant group Hamas in response to its surprise weekend attack that has shaken the Middle East and the world.‚Å†
‚Å†
Netanyahu said every Hamas member is a ‚Äúdead man,‚Äù as Israeli troops mass near the Gaza border while airstrikes rain down on the region. Roughly 2,800 peopled have died on both sides of the conflict so far.‚Å†
‚Å†
But what is Hamas? Here is everything you need to know.‚Å†
‚Å†
Hamas is an acronym for Harakat al-Muqawama al-Islamiya, or the Islamic Resistance Movement. It was founded in 1987 during the first Palestinian Intifada, or uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank, Gaza, and East Jerusalem.‚Å†
‚Å†
It was founded by Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, a Palestinian cleric.‚Å†
‚Å†
According to the U.S. Office of the Director of National Intelligence‚Äôs counter-terrorism guide, Hamas has roots in ‚Äúthe Palestinian branch of the Muslim Brotherhood,‚Äù which was established in Egypt in the 1920s.‚Å†
‚Å†
It is one of a broad group of actors in the region including Iran, Syria and the Shi‚Äôite Islamist group Hezbollah in Lebanon, which broadly oppose U.S. policy in the Middle East and Israel.‚Å†
‚Å†
In 1988, Hamas published its charter, calling for the destruction of Israel and the establishment of an Islamic society for Palestinians, the Council on Foreign Relations states on its website.‚Å†
‚Å†
Hamas presented a new document in 2017 that suggested it would accept an interim Palestinian state along the ‚ÄúGreen Line‚Äù border established before the 1967 Six-Day War, but refused to recognize Israel.‚Å†
‚Å†
Hamas has a militant wing, which has sent gunmen and suicide bombers into Israel. Hamas calls its armed activities resistance against Israeli occupation.‚Å†
‚Å†
Hamas won 2006 legislative elections and in 2007, violently seized control of the Gaza Strip from the internationally recognized Palestinian Authority, the Associated Press reported. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The Palestinian Authority, dominated by the rival Fatah movement, administers semi-autonomous areas of the Israeli-occupied West Bank.‚Å†
‚Å†

The Cambridge Police Department is closely monitoring the ongoing Israel/Hamas conflict overseas. We are working with our state and federal partners. At this time, there are no specific or credible threats in our area. Out of an abundance of caution, we are assigning extra officers throughout the weekend and are directing additional patrols all week to monitor faith-based centers across Cambridge. 

We recognize that this is a time of grief, uncertainty, and increased tension. If you feel physically threatened, including online harassment or intimidation, please contact Cambridge Police at 617-349-3300. We take all concerns and threats seriously and will investigate and take actions as appropriate. For emergencies, please call 911 immediately.
I‚Äôm a chronic asker of questions.

I find myself wandering among these living works of art as my mind ponders the boundaries of human creation. Are we creators or simply interpreters of an architecture already written in the folds of the universe? The space cities that emerge here seem an answer, but also a new enigma to be deciphered.
And as the wind whispers through the leaves and the sun's rays filter through the plant canopies, I realise that these liveable architectures reformulate more than a landscape. They reformulate the way we see the world, the way we connect with it.
